titleStmt.title: A new guide for constables, headboroughs, tythingmen, church-wardens, overseers and collectors for the poor, surveyors for amending the highways and bridges with directions for keepers of fairs and markets, and treasurers for the relief of poor maimed soldiers and mariners : containing not only whatsoever may be useful to them in the execution of their several offices, that is already extant in any book of this kind, but also the heads of all those statutes which do concern any of the said offices that have been since made in the reigns of the late King Charles, King James, and their present Majesties, King William and Queen Mary : being the most compleat of any work of this nature / collected by J.P. Gent.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

Containing not only what≈øoever may be u≈øeful to them in the Execution of their ≈øeveral Offices, that is already Extant in any BOOK of this Kind.

div.head: THE DUTY OF CONSTABLES, &c.
CHAP. I. Of the Original, Office and Juri≈ødiction of High Con≈øtables, Petty Con≈øtables, Headboroughs, Bor≈øholders and Tythingmen.
div.p:
THE S ‚Ä¢ xon Chri≈øtian King Alfred (King of England) for the more peaceable Government and Ea≈øe of his Subjects, divided this whole Realm of England fir≈øt into Shires, then cau≈øed tho≈øe Shires to be ≈øubdivided into Hundreds, Rapes, Ridings, Wapentakes; and divided the≈øe al≈øo into Tythings, Leets or Boroughs, and in all the≈øe Divi≈øions were appointed Officers for the better pre≈øervation of the Peace, ≈øuch are High Con≈øtables, Petty Con≈øtables, Headboroughs, Bor≈øholders and Tythingmen; the Office of all the≈øe latter, is one and the ≈øame, only different in Title, according to the Cu≈øtom of the Country; in
Middle≈øex, be≈øides the High Con≈øtables of the Hundreds, they have Petty Con≈øtables and Headboroughs in the re≈øpective Pari≈øhes, and they are in number more or le≈øs, according to the greatne≈øs or ≈ømalne≈øs of the Pari≈øh; in Kent the≈øe Petty Officers of the Pari≈øhes are called Bor≈øholders; but in Hamp≈øhire, and all the We≈øtern Parts, Tythingmen, and their Divi≈øions of Pari≈øhes, Tythings; in Su≈ø≈øex the Hundreds are called Rapes; and in the North, Ridings and Wapentakes.

There was antiently in England, a great Officer called the High Con≈øtable of England, and he kept an Office (which is ≈øuppo≈øed to come hither with William the Conqueror out of Normandy) or Court, called the Con≈øtables Court, or the Court of the High Con≈øtable, wherein he had Authority to hear and determine Contracts, touching Deeds of Arms out of the Realm, and to determine all things concerning War within the Realm; as Combats, Blazon, Armory, &c. but not to deal with Battel in Appeals, that belonging to the Common Law of the Land.

Among≈øt the re≈øt of the Conquerors Laws, this is one, That if a French-man do Appeal an Engli≈øh-man of Perjury or Murder, the French-man may defend him≈øelf by Battail, Which in Engli≈øh was then called Earne≈øt, which Word we yet retain; and the Officer to ≈øee this performed, was the High Con≈øtable; but this Officer, Court and Practice, is long ≈øince di≈ø≈øolved.

The Etymology of this word Constable, proceeds from the old word Conning or Cyng, and Staple or Stable; the word Conning
or Cyng, ≈øignifies a King, and Stable, a Stay or Prop; which is as much as to ≈øay, the ≈øtay or Prop of the King; that great Officer the Con≈øtable of England, having that Title given by rea≈øon of the great Authority that he had, was a principal Prop or Stay unto the Kings Government; from whence is this Title and Office of this Lower Con≈øtable≈øhip derived and continued (though with le≈ø≈øer Authority unto this hour) and is a Branch of that Original.

By the Statute of Winche≈øter, made in the time of King Edward the Fir≈øt, the≈øe Con≈øtables of Hundreds were appointed to keep Watching and Warding, for the better keeping of the Peace, and prevention of Thieveries and Robberies, and apprehen≈øions of Felons and Rogues, &c. and that the High Con≈øtables in every Hundred and Franchi≈øe, ≈øhould take the view of Armor, &c.

Hereby it appears, that the Name of a Con≈øtable in an Hundred or Franchi≈øe, is an Officer to a≈ø≈øi≈øt and ≈øupport the King's Maje≈øty in the Maintenance and Per≈øervation of his Peace, within his Hundred or Franchi≈øe, and he is called the High Con≈øtable, in re≈øpect of the Con≈øtables or Petty Con≈øtables, and Headboroughs or Tythingmen, which be in the re≈øpective Towns, Villages, Pari≈øhes, or Precincts within his Hundred or Franchi≈øe under his Juri≈ødiction; and it is al≈øo the part and duty of the≈øe inferiour Officers to execute the High Con≈øtables Office in his ab≈øence, in maintaining and keeping the Peace in their ≈øeveral Tythings and Limits, and in the High Con≈øtables
pre≈øence to be aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto him.

The High Con≈øtables of every Hundred, or Rape, or Riding, are cho≈øen by the Ju≈øtices in each County, mo≈øt u≈øually at their General Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, or in their ≈øeveral Divi≈øions. From the Ju≈øtices they receive their Authority, and are by them again di≈øcharged of their Office as they ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe. At the entrance into their Office they take an Oath, the u≈øual Form whereof followeth.

div.head: The High Con≈øtables Oath.
div.p:
YOU ≈øhall ≈øwear, That you ≈øhall well and truly ≈øerve our Sovereign Lord the King, in the Office of a Con≈øtable. You ≈øhall ≈øee and cau≈øe His Maje≈øty's Peace to be well and truly kept, and pre≈øerved according to your Power. You ≈øhall Arre≈øt all ≈øuch Per≈øons as in your ≈øight and pre≈øence ≈øhall ride or go armed offen≈øively, or ≈øhall commit or make any Riot, Affray, or other Breach of His Maje≈øty's Peace. You ≈øhall do your be≈øt endeavour (upon complaint to you made) to apprehend all Felons, Barretors, and Rioters, or Per≈øons riotou≈øly a≈ø≈øembled: and if any ≈øuch Offenders ≈øhall make re≈øi≈øtance [with force] you ≈øhall levy Hue and Cry, and ≈øhall pur≈øue them until they be taken. You ≈øhall do your be≈øt endeavour, that the watch in and about your Hundred be duly kept, for the apprehending of Rogues, Vagabonds, Nightwalkers, Eve≈ødroppers, Scouts, and other ≈øu≈øpected Per≈øons, and of ≈øuch as go armed, and the like; and that Hue and Cry be duly rai≈øed and pur≈øued according to the Statute of Winche≈øter, again≈øt Murderers, Thieves,
and other Felons; and that the Statutes made for the puni≈øhment of Rogues and Vagabonds, and ≈øuch other idle Per≈øons as come within your Bounds and Limits be duly put in Execution‚ñ™ you ≈øhall have a watchful Eye to ≈øuch Per≈øons as ≈øhall maintain or keep any Common Hou≈øe or Place, where any unlawful Game is or ≈øhall be u≈øed; as al≈øo to ≈øuch as ≈øhall frequent or u≈øe ≈øuch Places, or ≈øhall u≈øe or exerci≈øe any unlawful Games, there or el≈øewhere, contrary to the Statutes. At your A≈ø≈øizes, Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace or Leet, you ≈øhall pre≈øent all and every the Offences done contrary to the Statutes made 1 Jacobi, 4 Jacobi, and 21 Jacobi Regis, to re≈øtrain the inordinate haunting and tippling in Inns, Alehou≈øes, and other Victualling hou≈øes, and for repre≈ø≈øing of Drunkenne≈øs; you ≈øhall there likewi≈øe true Pre≈øentment make of all Blood≈øheddings, Affrays, O ‚Ä¢ tcries, Re≈øcous, and other Offences committed or done again≈øt the Kings Maje≈øty's Peace within your Limit ‚Ä¢ : you ≈øhall once every Year, during your Office, pre≈øent at the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions all Popi≈øh Recu≈øarts within your Liberty, and their Children above nine, and their Servants, (≈øcil. their Monthly Ab≈øence from the Church) 3 Jac. 4. You ≈øhall well and duly execute all Precepts and warrants to you directed from the Ju≈øtice of the Peace of this County, or higher Officers; you ≈øhall be aiding to your Neighbours again≈øt unlawful Purveyances: in time of Hay or Corn-harve≈øt, upon reque≈øt, you ≈øhall cau≈øe all Per≈øons, meet, to ≈øerve by the day for the Mowing, Reaping, or getting in of Corn or Hay; you ≈øhall in Ea≈øter Week cau≈øe your Pari≈øhioners to chu≈øe Surveyors for the mending of the High-ways in your Pari≈øh or Liberty; and you ≈øhall well and duly ac ‚Ä¢ ording to your Knowledge, Power,
and Ability, do and execute all other things belonging to the Office of a Con≈øtable, ≈øo long as you continue in the ≈øaid Office.
In this Oath is briefly comprehended the whole Duty of a Con≈øtable, and the principal Matters of his Office at large.

div.head: The Form of the Petty Con≈øtable or Tythingmans, &c. Oath runs thus.
div.p: YOU ≈øhall Swear, That you ≈øhall well and truly execute the Office of a Tythingman of the Tything of H. (or Headborough, &c.) His Maje≈øty's Peace in your own Per≈øon you ≈øhall keep, and ≈øee it kept in all others, as much as in you lieth. In the pre≈øence of the High Con≈øtable, you ≈øhall be aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting unto him; and in his ab≈øence you ≈øhall execute his Office, and do all other things belonging to your Office, according to your Knowledge and Power, until another be cho≈øen in your room, or you be legally di≈øcharged thereof.

There are in ≈øeveral Counties of this Realm other Officers; that is, by other Titles, but not much inferiour to our Con≈øtables; as in Warwick-≈øhire a Thirdborough, and in other places a Borough-head, in others a Chief-pledge.
The Authority of the≈øe (as I ≈øaid) is much like that of the Con≈øtables: but yet the Office of the Con≈øtable is di≈øtinct, and of greater Authority and Re≈øpect than the≈øe.

But in Towns where there be no Con≈øtables, and that the only Officers for the Peace, there be Headboroughs, Thirdboroughs, Bor≈øholders, or ≈øuch others; and in ≈øuch ca≈øes where their Power and Authority is declared to be equal with the Con≈øtable; in all ≈øuch things their Office is all one in a manner: and divers Statutes do appoint Offenders to be puni≈øhed by the Con≈øtable, or other inferiour Officers, which mu≈øt needs be the Tythingmen, &c. 1 Jac. cap. 7.
12 H. 7. f. 8. The High Con≈øtables of Hundreds, are Con≈øervators of the Peace within their ≈øeveral Hundreds and Franchi≈øes at the Common Law.
Brook Peace 13. Fitz. 127. All Petty Con≈øtables by virtue of their Office, within their ≈øeveral Liberties of their ≈øeveral Towns, are Con≈øervators of the Peace at the Common Law.

Bacons u≈øe of the Law
‚Ä¢ , 6. In ancient time High Con≈øtables of the Hundreds, and Petty Con≈øtables in every Town, were yearly appointed by the Sheriff in his Turn, and were there ≈øworn.

Direct. Judges 29. Con≈øtables lawfully cho≈øen, if they ≈øhall refu≈øe to be ≈øworn, the Ju≈øtices of the Peace may bind them over to the A≈ø≈øizes or Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, and for ≈øuch his Contempt, he is there to be indicted, fined, and impri≈øoned.

Coke 8.43. Every Per≈øon that is cho≈øen to be a Con≈øtable, ought to be idoneus Homo, a Man apt and fit for the Execution of the ≈øaid Office: and to be idoneus Homo, the Law requireth in him three qualifications, viz.
1. Hone≈øty: to execute his Office truly, without Malice, Affection or Partiality.
2. Knowledge: to under≈øtand his Duty wh ‚Ä¢ he ought to do.
3. Ability: as well in E≈øtate as in Body, tha ‚Ä¢ ≈øo he may attend and execute his Office diligently, and not neglect the ≈øame through Wan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or Impotency.

For ≈øuch as are cho≈øen out of the meane ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Sort, are either ignorant what to do, or ≈øtand in awe of the greater; ≈øo that they dare no ‚Ä¢ do what th ‚Ä¢ y ought, or el≈øe are not able to ≈øpare time; therefore they ought to be cho≈øen out of the better ≈øort of Pari≈øhioners, and not either by the Hou≈øe, or other Cu≈øtom.
If a Man be cho≈øen Con≈øtable, not able and qualified as afore≈øaid, he may be di≈øcharged of his ≈øaid Office by Law, and another fit Man appointed in his place.
Co. 8.42. If Leets chu≈øe unable or unfit Petty Con≈øtables, it is cau≈øe of Forfeiture of the Leet, and ≈øuch choice is void.

14 Car. 2. c. 12. Two Ju≈øtices of the Peace may appoint and ≈øwear new Con≈øtables, Headboroughs, &c. in ca≈øe of death or removal of ≈øuch Officers out of the Pari≈øh. And if in default of holding Court Leets they continue above the Year, they may be di≈øcharged at the Se≈ø≈øions, and others put in.

Idem Stat. Con≈øtables, Headboroughs and Tythingmen, which are out of Pur≈øe for their Charges, they may with the Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor, and other Officers of the Pari≈øh, make Rates upon all Occupiers of Lands and Inhabitants, and all others chargeable to the Poor, by the Stat. 42 El. which being
confirmed under the Hands and Seals of two Ju≈øtices of the Peace, may by their Warrants be levied by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Goods of ≈øuch as refu≈øe to pay the ≈øame.

I ≈øhall now ≈øet forth every particular Branch of the Con≈øtables Office, and of the Tythingmen, Headboroughs, and Bor≈øholders: their Duties are the ≈øame in effect, and their Authority; yet the later are inferiours to the former.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Con≈øtables Office about Affrays.
div.p:
IF one makes an Affray, or A≈ø≈øault upon another, in a Con≈øtables pre≈øence, or in his pre≈øence ≈øhall threaten to kill, beat or hurt another, or ≈øhall be in a Fury ready to break the Peace. In the≈øe Ca≈øes, the Con≈øta≈øtable may commit the Offenders to the Stocks, or to ≈øome other ≈øafe Cu≈øtody for the pre≈øent, until ≈øuch time as he can carry them before ≈øome Ju≈øtice of the Peace, or to the Goal, until they ≈øhall find Sureties for the Peace. The Con≈øtable may take Security for the Peace, by Obligation to be ≈øealed and delivered to the Kings u≈øe, which Bond the Con≈øtable was to ≈øend to the Exchequer or Chancery, from whence the Proce≈øs ≈øhould i≈ø≈øue to levy the Debt to the Kings u≈øe, if the Peace were broken. This was the Opinion of three of the Judges of the Common Pleas in Skirrets Ca≈øe, Trin. 35 Eliz. Com. Banc. Rot. 1458. But Ander≈øon Chief Ju≈øtice ≈øaid, That the Con≈øtable ought to carry
the Party, that he ≈øhould ≈øee breaking o ‚Ä¢ the Peace, before a Ju≈øtice to find Sureties ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Peace which is the u≈øual Practice at this day. 3 H. 4. 9 & 10. Bacons u≈øe of the Law, fol. 5. Dalt. J.P. c. 1. fol. 4, 5.

Dalt. J. P. c. 8. fol. 33. The Con≈øtable, where he ≈øeeth an Affray made, or ≈øuch as are about to make an Affray, ought to command the Affrayers, in the Kings Name, to ≈øurcea≈øe, and depart on Pain of Impri≈øonment; and if a Con≈øtable being pre≈øent at an Affray, doth not his be≈øt endeavour to part them, it being pre≈øented by the Jury at the Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, ≈øuch Con≈øtable may be fined for it.

3 H. 7. 1. 3, H. 7. 20. Lamb. 136. 38. E. 3. 8. Dalt. J. P. c. 8. fol. 33. If any be dangerou≈øly hurt in an Affray, the Con≈øtable, or any other may ≈øtay the Offender, and carry him to a Ju≈øtice of Peace, who is either to Bail him till the next Goal delivery, or to commit him to the Goal, until it be known whether the Party hurt will live or dye thereof.

Lamb. 135. 1 H. 7. 7. 3 H. 7. 10. If Affrayers will not depart, but do draw Weapons, or give any Blow, the Con≈øtable may command A≈ø≈øi≈øtance of others to cea≈øe the Affray; and if they make re≈øi≈øtance, may ju≈øtifie the bearing, and wounding of them: and if either the Con≈øtable, or any of his A≈ø≈øi≈øtants be killed, it is Murder in the Affrayers.

Lamb. 135. 7 E. 3.19. Where there is a great and dangerous Affray, the Con≈øtable may make Proclamation in the Kings Name, that the Affrayers ≈øhall keep the Peace, and depart. And if the Affray be in a Hou≈øe, the Con≈øtable may break into the Hou≈øe (if the Doors be ≈øhut) to
≈øee the Peace kept, though none of the Parties have taken any hurt; and if the Affrayers fly into another Mans Hou≈øe, the Con≈øtable upon fre≈øh pur≈øuit may break into ≈øuch Hou≈øe, and apprehend them.

Dalt. c. 8. fol. 34. &c. 118. fol. 340. Cromp. 146. b. & 172. b. Where the Affrayers fly into another County, the Con≈øtable ≈øeeing it, may fre≈øhly pur≈øue, or cau≈øe them to be pur≈øued, and taken there: and then the Con≈øtable may carry them before ≈øome Ju≈øtice of Peace, of the County where they are taken, to find Sureties for the Peace.
And if they flie into a Franchi≈øe, only within the ≈øame County where the Affray was, the Con≈øtable (≈øeeing this) may fre≈øhly pur≈øue them, and take them out thence.

Dalt. J. P. c. 8. f. 34. 38 H. 8. After the Affray is over, the Con≈øtable cannot Arre≈øt the Affrayers without a Warrant; except ≈øome Per≈øon hath received ≈øuch hurt there, that he is in danger of death. But before the Affray begun, and at the time thereof, he may Arre≈øt them without a Warrant.

Dalton ibid. It is not properly an Affray, unle≈øs ≈øome blow be given or offered to be given; for hot words is no Affray, neither can the Con≈øtable apprehend them for Words, unle≈øs they threaten to kill, beat, or hurt one another; in ≈øuch Ca≈øe the Con≈øtable may take ≈øuch Per≈øons and carry them before a Ju≈øtice to find Sureties for the Peace, and yet ≈øuch Threatning is no Affray

If an Affray, or an A≈ø≈øault be made upon the Con≈øtable him≈øelf, he may not only defend him≈øelf, but may al≈øo put the Parties offending
in the Stocks till ≈øuch time as he can carry the ‚Ä¢ to a Ju≈øtice of Peace, or to the Goal; an ‚Ä¢ if he be not able to arre≈øt them him≈øelf, h ‚Ä¢ may then call others to his A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, wh ‚Ä¢ may ju≈øtifie to arre≈øt the Offenders, Dalt. c. 8‚ñ™ fol. 35. 5 Hen. 7. 6.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Con≈øtables Office about Alehou≈øes, &c.
div.p: IF any one keep an Alehou≈øe, or ≈øell Beer or Ale without Licence, he forfeits 20 s. to the u≈øe of the Poor, to be levied by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, by the Con≈øtable and Churchwardens, by Warrant from a Ju≈øtice of Peace, before whom the Offence i ‚Ä¢ proved; which Goods are to be ≈øold within three days after the Di≈øtre≈øs taken, and the Overplus to be returned, if any be: and in default of Di≈øtre≈øs, the Delinquent is to be openly whipped by the Con≈øtable. If the Con≈øtable refu≈øe, or neglect to execute his Warrant, he forfeits 40 s. to the Poor; and the Ju≈øtice may commit the Con≈øtable to the Goal, until he cau≈øeth the Offender to be whipped, or payeth the 40 s. to the u≈øe of the Poor, 3 Car. 1. c. 3. Dalt. J.P. c. 7. f. 31, 32.

If a common Inn keeper or Alehou≈øe-keeper refu≈øeth to lodge a Traveller, he profering to pay ready Mony for his Victuals, &c. the Con≈øtable may cau≈øe ≈øuch an inn keeper or Alehou≈øe-keeper, to be indicted at the Se≈ø≈øions or A≈ø≈øi≈øes, where he may be fined and impri≈øoned, or the Party grieved may have his Action of the
Ca≈øe again≈øt the Inn-keeper or Alehou≈øe keeper. But they are not bound to lodge, or find Victuals without ready Mony fir≈øt paid, if it be required, Co. 9. lib. Rep. fol. 87. b. 10 H. 7. 8. Daltons J.P. c. 7. f. 28.

In the Condition of the Recognizance, which every Alehou≈øe-keeper enters into, that is licen≈øed to ≈øell Drink, it is one Clau≈øe, That he ≈øhall keep one or more ≈øpare Beds for lodging of Strangers.

Were this well looked into, in and about London, abundance of forfeited Recognizances would be found; and a great many lazy Knaves, that Live at their Ea≈øe, by ≈øelling Drink, might be ≈øet to work for their livings.

They are bound likewi≈øe not to ≈øuffer any Gaming in their Hou≈øes or Back≈øides, which now is the main Prop of mo≈øt of them; and there they draw in Apprentices, and Servants, to their ruin: were they puni≈øhed according to the Statute for this, the≈øe Caterpillars would not ≈øwarm ≈øo thick as they do.

If any Inn-keeper, Alehou≈øe-keeper, or Victuallers do ≈øell le≈øs than a full Ale Quart of the be≈øt Ale or Beer, or two Quarts of the ≈ømall for one Penny, he forfeits 20 s. for every Offence. If he ≈øuffers Town≈ømen, or others, to ≈øit tipling in his Hou≈øe, he forfeits 10 s. for which the Con≈øtables and Churchwardens, upon a Warrant from a Ju≈øtice of Peace, ought to di≈øtrain and levy the Forfeitures, according to the Statute; and if there be no Di≈øtre≈øs to be found, or if the Officers neglect within 20 days to certifie the ≈øame Default to the Ju≈øtices, the Officer forfeirs 40 s. to the u≈øe of the Poor, to be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs on
their Goods, by Warrant made to any indifferent Per≈øon, from any one or more Ju≈øtices of the Peace, under their Hand and Seal. And, for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, the Ju≈øtice may commit the Offenders to the Goal, there to remain till they have paid the ≈øaid Forfeitures. In all the≈øe Ca≈øes, the Di≈øtre≈ø≈øes are to be kept ≈øix days, and if the Parties do not pay the Forfeitures within that time, then the Di≈øtre≈øs is to be appri≈øed and ≈øold, and the Overplus returned to the Owners, if any be, 1 Jac. c. 9. 1 Car. 1. c. 4.

If the Con≈øtable, or other Officer of the Pari≈øh, neglect to ≈øerve the Ju≈øtices Warrant again≈øt Town≈ømen, or others, for Tipling in any Inn, Alehou≈øe, or Victualling-hou≈øe, or again≈øt Men for being Drunk, viz. for Tipling, 3 s. 4 d. and for being Drunk, 5 s. to be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs on the Offenders Goods, and ≈øale thereof after ≈øix days default of payment, rendring the overplus to the Owner, and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, and not able to pay, the Tipler is to be ≈øet in the Stocks four hours, and the Drunkard ≈øix hours; and if in any of the≈øe ca≈øes the Con≈øtable neglect to do his Duty, he forfeits 10 s. to be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of his Goods to the u≈øe of the Poor. The≈øe Offences are to be enquired after within ≈øix Months after they are committed, and the Con≈øtables, and other Officers of the Pari≈øh may be charged upon their Oaths to pre≈øent them. 21 Jac. c. 7. Dalt. J.P. c. 7. f. 28.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The Con≈øtables Office about Arms, &c.
div.p: IF any Per≈øon ≈øhall ride, or go armed offen≈øively before the Kings Ju≈øtices, or before any other the Kings Officers or Mini≈øters during their Office, or in Fairs or Markets, or el≈øewhere, by Night or by Day, in Affray of the Kings People, and Breach of the Peace; or wear, or carry any Guns, Daggers, or Pi≈øtols charged; in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Con≈øtable upon the ≈øight hereof, may ≈øeize and take away their Armor, and other Weapons, and cau≈øe them to be apprized, and an≈øwered to the King as forfeited, and carry them before a Ju≈øtice, to find Sureties for the Peace, 2 E. 3. c. 3. 7 R. 2. 13. Co. 3. part In≈øt. fol. 162. Dalt. J. P. c. 9. fol. 35, & 159.

But the Kings Servants in his Pre≈øence, Sheriffs, and their Officers, and other the Kings Mini≈øters, and ≈øuch as be in their Companies a≈ø≈øi≈øting them in their Office, and all others pur≈øuing Hue and Cry, where any Felony, or other Offences again≈øt the Peace be committed, may lawfully bear Armor or Weapons, 2 E. 3. c. 3.

All High Con≈øtables, Petty Con≈øtables, and other Officers within their ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes, are to be aiding and a≈ø≈øi≈øting to ≈øuch Per≈øons as ≈øhall have Warrants from the Lord Lieutenants, or any two of their Deputies, under their Hands and Seals, to ≈øearch for, and ≈øeize all Arms in the cu≈øtody and po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion of any Per≈øon or Per≈øons whom the ≈øaid Lieutenants or their Deputies ≈øhall judge to be
dangerous to the Peace of the Kingdom, and to ≈øecure the ≈øame, and give account thereo ‚Ä¢ to the ≈øaid Officers; but ≈øuch ≈øearch is to be made in the day-time, only between Sun ri≈øe and Sun ≈øet, and not otherwi≈øe, unle≈øs it be in Cities and their Suburbs, Towns Corporate ‚Ä¢ and Market Towns, or Hou≈øes within the Bill ‚Ä¢ of Mortality, in which places ≈øearch may be in the night, if the Warrant ≈øo direct.

No dwelling hou≈øe of any Peer of the Realm i ‚Ä¢ to be ≈øearched, unle≈øs the Warrant be from the Kings Maje≈øty, under his Sign-Manual, or in the Pre≈øence of the Lieutenant, or one of the Deputy Lieutenants of the ≈øaid County o ‚Ä¢ Riding. And in all Places and Hou≈øes afore≈øaid where ≈øearch is made, in ca≈øe of Re≈øi≈øtance, to enter with force; and ≈øuch Arms ≈øo ≈øeized where the Lieutenants, or their Deputies, or any two of them think fit, may be re≈øtored to the Owners again, 14 Car. 2. c. 3.

The Con≈øtables by Warrant under the Hand and Seal of the Lord Lieutenant, or any three or more of the Deputy Lieutenants, are to levy ≈øuch Sums, Forfeitures, Penalties and Payments, as ≈øhall be charged upon any Per≈øon or Per≈øons within their ≈øeveral Liberties, for the furni≈øhing of Arms, Hor≈øe or Foot, or Payment of Soldiers, 14 Car. 2. c 3. & 15 Car. 2. c. 4.

And where ≈øufficient Di≈øtre≈øs cannot be had, then the Lord Lieutenants and their Deputies, by like Warrant to the Con≈øtable, may commit ≈øuch Offender to pri≈øon, until he ≈øhall make ≈øatisfaction according to the ≈øaid Forfeiture, Payment or Penalty, ibid.

‚Ä¢ he Con≈øtables are likewi≈øe by Warrant from ‚Ä¢ he Ju≈øtices of the Peace, Ma≈øter and Wardens ‚Ä¢ f the Corporation, or any thirteen of them, ‚Ä¢ o levy ≈øuch Fines, Penalties and Forfeitures, „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhall grow due from any Clothier, by vir

Clothiers mu≈øt pay their Spinners, and other Workfolks, their Wages in ready Mony, and ‚Ä¢ ot in Wares, and ≈øhall deliver their Wool in ‚Ä¢ ue weight, on pain to forfeit ≈øix pence for ‚Ä¢ very Default; and the Carders, Spinners, Wea
‚Ä¢ ers, and other Workfolks, are to do their Work faithfully, on pain to forfeit double Damages to the Party grieved, 4 E. 3. c. 1. Fitz. ‚Ä¢ .P. 103.

The Ma≈øter, or Head Officer in a Corporation, where there is no Ma≈øter, and out of a Corporation, every Ju≈øtice of Peace, High Con≈øtable and Stewards of Court-Leet, ≈øhall hear ‚Ä¢ nd determine the Complaints, as well for non-payment of the Workfolks Wages, as the Damages afore≈øaid, by examining the Parties; for which Damages they have Power to commit the Offenders to the Goal, until the Party grieved be ≈øatisfied, Stat. idem.

The Ju≈øtices of Peace, and High-Con≈øtables, may ≈øearch any Hou≈øe, or other Place for Tenters, Ropes, Rings, Headwrinches, or other Engines for ≈øtretching of Cloth, and if they find any, to deface them; and if the Owner u≈øe them again, the≈øe Officers may take them away and ≈øell them, and give the Mony to the Poor, 39 Eliz. c. 20.

BY the 14 Car. 2. Such Per≈øon or Per≈øons are authorized by Writ of A≈ø≈øi≈øtance, u ‚Ä¢
der the Seal of his Maje≈øty's Court of Excheque ‚Ä¢ are to take a Con≈øtable, Headborough, or oth ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ publick Officer inhabiting near the Place, and the day-time are to enter, and go into any Hou ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Shop, Cellar, Warehou≈øe, Room, or other Plac ‚Ä¢ and in ca≈øe of Re≈øi≈øtance, break open t ‚Ä¢ Doors, Che≈øts, Trunks, and other Packag ‚Ä¢ there to ≈øeize, and from thence to bring a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ kind of Goods, Merchandize what≈øoever, pr ‚Ä¢
hibited and uncu≈øtomed, and to put, and ≈øec ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the ≈øame in his Maje≈øty's Store-hou≈øe, in the Po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ next to ≈øuch Place where the ≈øeizure ≈øhall „Äà‚óä„Äâ made, 13 Car. 2. c. 11.

All Officers belonging to the Admiralty, Ca ‚Ä¢
tains, and Commanders of Ships, Forts, Ca≈øtl ‚Ä¢ and Block-hou≈øes, and all Ju≈øtices of Peace, Ma ‚Ä¢

div.head: CHAP. XII. The Con≈øtables Office about Setting-Dogs, &c.

THE Con≈øtable, Tythingman, or Headborough of any place (upon a Warrant ‚Ä¢ nder the Hands and Seals of two or more Ju

But they cannot ≈øearch the Hou≈øes of any who have Free Warren, or any Lord of any Mannor, or ≈øuch as have 40 l. per ann. or more ‚Ä¢ n Free-hold, or ≈øome E≈øtate of Inheritance, ‚Ä¢ or 80 l. per ann. for Life, or be worth in Per≈øonal E≈øtate 400 l. The≈øe may keep Nets and Dogs to take Phea≈øants or Partridges in their own Ground, Stat. idem, Dalt. ibid.

div.head: CHAP. XIII. The Con≈øtables Office about E≈øcapes and Arre≈øts.
div.p:
IF a Con≈øtable, or any other Officer, which hath a Pri≈øoner in cu≈øtody for Felony, or Su≈øpicion thereof, voluntarily letteth, or ≈øuffereth
the Pri≈øoner to go where he will at liberty (though this be breaking of Pri≈øon) yet it „Äà‚óä„Äâ Felony in the Goaler, Con≈øtable, or him th ‚Ä¢ letteth ≈øuch Pri≈øoner e≈øcape, but it is no Felon ‚Ä¢ in the Pri≈øoner; but if ≈øuch a Pri≈øoner ≈øhe e≈øcape by the Negligence of his Keeper, an ‚Ä¢ again≈øt his Will and Knowledge, then it is Felony in the Pri≈øoner, becau≈øe a Breach of Pr ‚Ä¢
≈øon, and the Goaler or Con≈øtable, &c. ≈øhall b ‚Ä¢ Fined by the Judges or Ju≈øtices for ≈øuch E≈øcape Dalt. J.P. c. 106. fol. 272. Bro. Coron. 112, 22 ‚Ä¢ 316, 454. & Bro. E≈øcape 31 Stamford fol. 32.

If a Con≈øtable, or other Officer, ≈øhall voluntarily ≈øuffer a Thief (being in his Cu≈øtody) t ‚Ä¢ go into the Water, and drown him≈øelf, th ‚Ä¢ E≈øcape is Felony in the Con≈øtable, and the Thie ‚Ä¢ is Felo de ≈øe; but if the Thief ≈øhall ≈øuddenly (without the a≈ø≈øent of the Con≈øtable) kill, hang or drown him≈øelf, this is then but a neglige ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ E≈øcape in the Con≈øtable, and Fineable, as afore≈øaid, Dalt. J. P. c. 106. fol. 272.

The voluntary letting a Felon e≈øcape before he be arre≈øted for the Felony, is no Felony i ‚Ä¢ the Party that ≈øuffereth him to e≈øcape; but „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Con≈øtable ≈øuffer one to e≈øcape, whom he knows hath committed a Felony, he is finable, i ‚Ä¢ it do not make him acce≈ø≈øary, Dalt. ibid.

Where a Felony is committed, and one is Arre≈øted for the ≈øame, or Su≈øpicion thereof‚ñ™ though the Con≈øtable, &c. ≈øhall after have certain intelligence and knowledge that the Party arre≈øted is not Guilty of the Offence; yet they may not ≈øet the Party at liberty, for he mu≈øt not be delivered but by due cour≈øe of Law, Cromp. 40, 44. Dalt. J.P. c. 106. f. 275.

If a Con≈øtable convey a Felon to the Goal, and the Goaler will not receive him, then the Con≈øtable mu≈øt bring him back to the Town where he was taken, and that Town ≈øhall be charged with the keeping of him until the next Goal-delivery; and in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Goaler ≈øhall be puni≈øhed by the Ju≈øtices, Dalt. J. P. c. 118. fol. 340.

The Con≈øtable, or other Officer, that ≈øhall Impri≈øon any Felon in the Stocks, may lock the Stocks, and if need be, may al≈øo put Irons on the Pri≈øoner, and when he conveyeth him to the Goal, or to the Ju≈øtice, he may Pinion him, or otherwi≈øe make him ≈øure, ≈øo that he cannot e≈øcape, ibid.

div.head: CHAP. XIV. The Con≈øtables Office about Exci≈øe.
div.p: THo≈øe Officers under the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Exci≈øe, called Gagers, are to have the Con≈øtable along with them, when they enter by night into the Hou≈øes of any Brewer, Inn-keeper, Victualler, &c. to gage their Coppers, Fats, or Ve≈ø≈øels, or to take an Account of their Beer, Ale, Worts, Perry, Syder, Strong-waters, Metheglin, Mead, Coffee, Chocolate, Sherbet or Tea, brewed; made or di≈øtilled in the ≈øaid Hou≈øes, 12 Car. 2. c. 23, 24.

Such Per≈øons as ≈øhall be convicted before the Ju≈øtices of Peace, or Commi≈ø≈øioners of Exci≈øe, of any Offence and Forfeiture within the Acts for Exci≈øe, the Con≈øtables, upon Warrant to them directed from the Ju≈øtices of Peace, are to levy
the Penalties upon the Goods of the Offenders, by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale thereof, rendring the overplus to the Owners, and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, they are to carry the Party to the Goal, there to remain till ≈øatisfaction be made, 12 Car. 2. c. 23, 24.

The Con≈øtables are al≈øo upon Warrant to them directed, to ≈øummon all Alehou≈øe-keepers, &c. to appear before the Commi≈ø≈øioners of Exci≈øe, at ≈øuch days and places as ≈øhall be appointed in the ≈øaid Warrant, from time to time.

div.head: CHAP. XV. The Con≈øtables Office about Fi≈øh.
div.p: THE Con≈øtables and Churchwardens, by Warrant from any one or more Ju≈øtices of the Peace (where any Offence is committed in de≈øtroying the Spawn and Breed of Fi≈øh, along the Sea-≈øhore, or in any Haven or Creek, or within five Miles of the Mouth of any Haven or Creek, by Fi≈øhing with Nets of le≈øs Me≈øh than three Inches and an half between knot and knot) are to levy the penalty by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, rendring the overplus to the Owners; the penalty is ten ≈øhillings and forfeiture of their Nets, 3 Jac. c. 12. Wingatts Abr. Stat. Tit. Fi≈øhers and Fi≈øhing.

The Ju≈øtices of Peace of the Counties of Worce≈øter, Salop and Glouce≈øter, upon their own knowledge, or upon information that any Per≈øon hath made u≈øe of any Net, Engine, or Device in the River of Severn, whereby any Salmon, Trout o ‚Ä¢
Barbel, under the length appointed by the Stat. of 1 Eliz. ≈øhall be taken or killed, or hath fi≈øhed
with any Net for Salmon, Salmon-mart, Salmon-p ‚Ä¢ al, Pike, Carpe, Trout, Barbel, Chub or Grayling, the Me≈øh whereof is under two Inches and a half ≈øquare, from knot to knot, allowing to each Me≈øh four knots, or above twenty yards in length, and two yards in breadth, or above fifty yards in length, and ≈øix yards in breadth, in the wing of the Net, in the ≈øaid River from Ripplelochelake to Glouce≈øter Bridge, or above ≈øixty yards in length below Glouce≈øter Bridge, and ≈øix yards in breadth, in the wing of the Net, or hath fi≈øhed with two of tho≈øe Nets fixed together, or u≈øed any Net or Device for taking the Fry of Eels, or whereby the Spawn of Fi≈øh ≈øhall be de≈øtroyed, ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue out Warrants under the Hands and Seals of any two of them, in their re≈øpective Countles, to the Under Con≈øervators of the ≈øaid River, or to any Con≈øtable, Tythingman or Headborough, to ≈øearch in the day-time, in all ≈øu≈øpected places, for ≈øuch unlawful In≈øtruments, and to ≈øeize them, and bring them to the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions to be burnt or de≈øtroyed, 30 Car. 2. c. 9.

If any Ling, Herring, Cod, or Pilchard, fre≈øh or ≈øalt, dried or bloated, or any Salmons, Eels or Congers, taken by Foreigners, Aliens to the Kingdom of England, ≈øhall be imported, uttered, ≈øold, or expo≈øed to ≈øale in this Kingdom; in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Con≈øtable, Headborough, &c. or any other Per≈øon may take and ≈øeize the ≈øame, and one half thereof mu≈øt go to the u≈øe of the Poor of the Pari≈øh where the ≈øame is ≈øo found and ≈øeized, and the other half to the u≈øe of the Party that ≈øeizes the ≈øame, 18 Car. c. 2.

div.head: CHAP. XVI. The Con≈øtables Office about forcible Entries, &c.
div.p: IF a Con≈øtable, or any private Per≈øon of the ≈øame County do refu≈øe to attend and a≈ø≈øi≈ø ‚Ä¢ the Ju≈øtices of Peace, upon reque≈øt to remove a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Force, or to convey the Parties to the Goal, he may be impri≈øoned for his neglect, and make Fine ‚Ä¢ to the King, 15 R. 2. c. 2. div.head: CHAP. XVII. The Con≈øtables Office about Hedge-breaking, &c.
div.p: SUch as are convicted before a Ju≈øtice of Peace, for cutting and taking away of Cor ‚Ä¢ growing, robbing of Orchards, breaking Hedges, and their Procurers and Receivers knowing the ≈øame, are to give the Party grieved ≈øuch Satisfaction as a Ju≈øtice of Peace ≈øhall think fit; and i ‚Ä¢ they cannot give ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction, then the Ju≈øtice may commit the Offenders to the Con≈øtable to be whipped for the fir≈øt Offence, and the like pain for the ≈øecond Offence; and if the Con≈øtable, or other Officer, do not by him≈øelf, or ≈øome other, ≈øee the ≈øame done accordingly, then the Ju≈øtice may commit ≈øuch Officer to the Goal, there to remain without Bail, until he procure the Offender to be whipped as afore≈øaid, 43 El. c. 7.

The Con≈øtables, Headboroughs, or other Per≈øon, in every County, City, Town-Corporate, or other Place, where they ≈øhall be Officers
and Inhabitants have power to apprehend, or ‚Ä¢ au≈øe to be apprehended ≈øuch Per≈øons as they ‚Ä¢ u≈øpect, for having, carrying, or conveying any Burthen or Bundles of any kind of Wood, Underwood, Poles, or young Trees, or Bark of ‚Ä¢ ny Trees, or Gates, Stiles, Po≈øts, Rales, Pales, Hedge-wood, Broom or Furze; and any Con
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ able, Headborough, &c. by Warrant under the Hand and Seal of one Ju≈øtice, may enter into the Hou≈øes, Out-hou≈øes, Yards, Gardens, or other Places belonging to the Hou≈øes of ≈øuch Per≈øons as they ≈øhall ≈øu≈øpect, &c. and where they ≈øhall find any, to apprehend the Parties ≈øu≈øpected for cutting the ≈øame, and tho≈øe in who≈øe ‚Ä¢ u≈øtody, &c. any ≈øuch Wood or Underwood ≈øhall be found, and carry them before a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, and if the Party cannot give a good account to the Ju≈øtice how he came by the ≈øaid Wood, &c. by the con≈øent of the Owner, or ≈øhall not within the time the Ju≈øtice ≈øhall appoint, prove who he bought it of, then ≈øuch Per≈øon ≈øhall be deemed convicted of the cutting and ≈øpoiling of Wood, within the Statute of 43 Eliz. and for the fir≈øt Offence ≈øhall give ≈øuch ≈øatisfaction to the Owner within ≈øuch time as the Ju≈øtice ≈øhall appoint, and pay over and above pre≈øently to the u≈øe of the Poor where the Offence is committed, ≈øo much Mony as the Ju≈øtice ≈øhall appoint, not exceeding ten ≈øhillings: And for default of performance hereof, the Ju≈øtice may commit the Offender to the Hou≈øe of Correction for ≈øo long time as he ≈øhall think fit, not exceeding one Month, or otherwi≈øe to be whipped by the Con≈øtable, or other Officer; and for the ≈øecond Offence, the Offender is to be ≈øent to the Hou≈øe
of Correction for one Month, and there he ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to hard Labour; and if he be convicted th ‚Ä¢ third time, then to be puni≈øhed as an incor ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
gible Rogue, 15 Car. 2. c. 2.

If any Per≈øon buy any Burthens of Woo ‚Ä¢ Underwood, Sticks, &c. of any who may j ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ly be ≈øu≈øpected to have come by the ≈øame ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
lawfully, upon complaint to a Ju≈øtice, Head O ‚Ä¢
ficer, &c. and if upon Examination by Oa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ it appears, That the ≈øame were bought of ≈øu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Per≈øon as afore≈øaid, the Ju≈øtice may order „Äà‚óä„Äâ Buyer to pay the treble value thereof to hi ‚Ä¢ from whom they were ≈øtollen; and for no ‚Ä¢ payment, the Ju≈øtice may grant his Warrant the Con≈øtable, to levy the ≈øame by di≈øtre≈øs „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, rendring to t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Owner, the overplus, and for want of ≈øuch d ‚Ä¢
≈øtre≈øs, then to commit the Party to the G ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ at his own charge, there to remain one Mon ‚Ä¢ without Bail, Stat. ibid.

None is to be puni≈øhed by this Statute, th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ have been puni≈øhed by any former Law for th ‚Ä¢ ≈øame Offence, and all Offenders within th ‚Ä¢ Statute, mu≈øt be pro≈øecuted within ≈øix Wee ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ after the Offence committed.
Highways. See the Office of Surveyors of High-ways and Bridges.

div.head: CHAP. XVIII. The Con≈øtables Office about Stoned-Hor≈øes.
div.p: NOne ought to put to feed upon Fore≈øts or Commons (except they be Commons where Mares are not u≈øually kept) any ≈øtoned-Hor≈øe, being above two years old, and not fifteen hands high from the lower part of the Hoof to the upper part of the Wither (every hand containing four Inches Standard mea≈øure) on pain to forfeit the ≈øame Hor≈øe, 32 H. 8. c. 13.

If any Stoned-Hor≈øe of le≈ø≈øer Stature be put to feed in any ≈øuch Common (unle≈øs it be in Fen-grounds of the I≈øle of Ely, and of the Counties of Cambridge, Huntington, Northampton, Lincoln, Norfolk or Suffolk, where they need be but thirteen hands high) any Man may ≈øeize them to his own u≈øe, ≈øo that fir≈øt by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of the Keeper of the Ground, or Con≈øtable, Bailiff, Headborough, or other ≈øuch Officer of the Pari≈øh adjoyning, ≈øuch Hor≈øe be brought to the next Pound, and there by ≈øuch Officer, in the pre≈øence of three other ≈øufficient Men, he be mea≈øured, and found lower than the Statute, 32 H. 8. c. 13. 8 Eliz. c. 8. Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. Hor≈øes.

Tho≈øe that refu≈øe to mea≈øure, or to be pre≈øent at mea≈øuring, do foreit 40 s. a piece for every ≈øuch default, to be divided between the King and Pro≈øecutor. But note, That an Hor≈øe that makes an E≈øcape into ≈øuch Common, ≈øhall not be que≈øtioned, ≈øo that he ≈øtay not above four days after
notice thereof at the Owners Hou≈øe, or in h ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Pari≈øh Church, 32 H. 8. c. 13.

Fore≈øts, and Common Grounds mu≈øt be drive ‚Ä¢ yearly at Michaelmas, or within fifteen days after by the Keepers, Con≈øtables, or other Office ‚Ä¢ above≈øaid, on pain of forty ≈øhillings; and th ‚Ä¢ have power to drive them at any other time „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Year, at their plea≈øure, and ≈øuch likewi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ have the Owners of the Ground. And if up ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Drift any unlucky Tits ≈øhall be found, the ‚Ä¢ may be killed, 32 H. 8. c 13. Wingates Abr. St ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Tit. Hor≈øes.
Note, That this Act of the 32 H. 8. c. 13. not to extend to the County of Cornwal, 21 J ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ c. 28.

div.head: CHAP. XIX. The Con≈øtables Office about Hue and Cry.
div.p: THE Con≈øtables or Tythingmen of ever ‚Ä¢ Town, Pari≈øh or Village, to whom H ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and Cry ≈øhall come, ought to ≈øearch in „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øu≈øpected Hou≈øes and Places within their liberties, and as well the Officers, as all other Per≈øons which ≈øhall pur≈øue the Hue and Cry may take and ≈øtay all ≈øuch Per≈øons as in their Search and Pur≈øuit they ≈øhall find to be ≈øu≈øpicious, and ≈øhall carry them before ≈øome Ju≈øtice of the County where they are taken to be examined, where they were at the time of the Felony committed; and if any default be in the Officers, they may be fined by the Ju≈øtices for their neglect, Dalt. J.P. c, 28. fol. 75.

Where a Hundred is ≈øued for a Robbery, and ‚Ä¢ amages are recovered again≈øt one or ≈øome ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ w Inhabitants of the Hundred, and the re≈øt ‚Ä¢ efu≈øe to contribute thereunto; in ≈øuch ca≈øe ‚Ä¢ wo Ju≈øtices of the Peace (one of the Quorum) ‚Ä¢ welling within or near the Hundred, may for the levying thereof, ≈øet a Tax upon every Pari≈øh within that Hundred; according to which the con≈øtables or Tythingmen of every Pari≈øh mu≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ax the particular Inhabitants within their Liberties, and then levy the Mony upon ≈øuch ‚Ä¢ s refu≈øe, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of their Goods, ‚Ä¢ e≈øtoring the overplus, if any be, and after the ‚Ä¢ ony is gathered, they are to re≈øtore the ≈øame ‚Ä¢ o the Ju≈øtices, or ≈øome of them that made the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ate, within ten days, 27 Eliz. c. 13. Dalt. J.P.
‚Ä¢ . 48. fol. 132.

That Hundred where Fre≈øh Suit ≈øhall cea≈øe, ≈øhall an≈øwer half the Damages to the Hundred where the Felony was committed, to ‚Ä¢ e recovered in any Court at We≈øtmin≈øter, in the Name of the Clerk of the Peace of the County where the Felony was committed; in which ca≈øe the Death or Change of the Clerk of the Peace, ≈øhall not abate the Suit. And this Recovery is to be taxed and levied as the former, 27 Eliz. c. 13.

Where any one of the Robbers is apprehended, or where the Action is pro≈øecuted within one Year after the Robbery committed, the Hundred is not chargeable for the Robbery. Ob≈øerve likewi≈øe, that the Hue and Cry ≈øhall not be judged legal, unle≈øs the Pur≈øuit be both by Hor≈øe and Foot, Bract. lib. 3. fol. 121. Dalt. J.P. f. 133.

He that goeth not at the command of th ‚Ä¢ Sheriff or Con≈øtable at the Cry of the County that is, upon Hue and Cry to arre≈øt Felon ‚Ä¢ after Attainder, ≈øhall be grievou≈øly fined a ‚Ä¢ impri≈øoned, We≈øtm. 1. c. 9. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
172.

div.head: CHAP. XX. The Con≈øtables Office about Labourers, &c.
div.p: THE Con≈øtable in the time of Hay an ‚Ä¢ Corn Harve≈øt, upon reque≈øt to him made by any Man that wants Labourers, to ge ‚Ä¢ in his Harve≈øt, to prevent lo≈øs thereof, may cau≈øe all ≈øuch Artificers as he ≈øhall ≈øee mee ‚Ä¢ to labour, to ≈øerve by the Day for Mowing Reaping, or otherwi≈øe, for the getting in o ‚Ä¢ Corn or Hay abroad, according as they ≈øee ‚Ä¢ fit and able to perform. And if ≈øuch Per≈øons ≈øhall refu≈øe to work, after they are reque≈øted thereunto, the Con≈øtable may ≈øet then in the Stocks, by the ≈øpace of two days and one night; and if the Con≈øtable neglect to perform his Office herein, he forfeits forty ≈øhillings, 5 Eliz. c. 14.

div.head: CHAP. XXXI. The Con≈øtables Office about Riots and Routs.
div.p: SHeriffs, Con≈øtables, and all other the Kings Officers, ≈øhall ≈øuppre≈øs Rioters, and impri≈øon them, and all other Offenders again≈øt the Peace, 27 R. 2. c. 8.

Where three Per≈øons or more ≈øhall come and a≈ø≈øemble them≈øelves together, to the intent to do any unlawful Act with force or violence again≈øt the Per≈øon of another, his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øions or Goods, as to kill, beat, or otherwi≈øe to hurt, or to impri≈øon a Man; to pull down a Hou≈øe, Wall, Pale, Hedge or Ditch; wrongfully to enter upon, or into another Mans Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion, Hou≈øe or Land, &c. or wrongfully to cut or take away Corn, Gra≈øs, Wood, or other Goods; or to hunt unlawfully in any Park or Warren, or to do any other unlawful Act, (with force or violence) again≈øt the Peace, or to the manife≈øt Terror of the People; if they only meet to ≈øuch a purpo≈øe or intent, although they ≈øhall after depart of their own accord, without acting any thing, yet it is an unlawful A≈ø≈øembly, becau≈øe of their Intention at fir≈øt, Bro. Tit. Riot. 4, 5. Co. 2 Part In≈øtitutes, fol. 176. Dalt. J. P. c. 85. fol. 217.

And if after ≈øuch Meeting they ≈øhall ride, move or go forward, towards the execution of ≈øuch Act, whether they put their intended purpo≈øe in execution or not, this is a Rout. And if they do act any ≈øuch thing indeed, then it is a Riot.

div.head: CHAP. XXXII The Con≈øtables Office about Rogues and Vagabonds
div.p: THE Con≈øtable, Tythingman or Headborough, a≈ø≈øi≈øted by the Mini≈øter, and one other of the Pari≈øh, is to ≈øee (or do it him≈øelf) Rogues and Vagabonds, which ≈øhall be taken begging, ≈øtripped naked from the Middle upwards, and openly whipped till their Body be bloody, and then forthwith to be ≈øent away from Pari≈øh to Pari≈øh, or Tything to Tything, the next ≈øtreight way to the place of their Birth; and if that cannot be known, then to the pla ‚Ä¢ e where they la≈øt dwelt, by the ≈øpace of one whole year, before ≈øuch puni≈øhment; and if that cannot be known, then to the Town through which they la≈øt pa≈ø≈øed unpuni≈øhed: and when they come there, if it cannot be di≈øcovered where they were born, or la≈øt dwelt, as afore≈øaid, then are they by that Con≈øtable to be conveyed to the Hou≈øe of Correction, or common Goal of that County, to be imployed in Work, or placed in ≈øome Service, and ≈øo to continue by the ≈øpace of one year; or in ca≈øe they be not able in Body, that Town is to keep them, till they may be placed in ≈øome Alm≈øhou≈øe within the ≈øame County, 39 Eliz. c. 4. Wingates Stat. Tit. Vagabonds, Re≈øolu. Judges ≈øect. 717. Bol≈øt. 2 part Rep. fol. 258.

After ≈øuch puni≈øhment, the Vagabond is to have a Te≈øtimonial under the Hand and Seal of the Con≈øtable, Tythingman, &c. and the Mini≈øter of the place, te≈øtifying the day and the place of his
puni≈øhment, the place to which he is to be ‚Ä¢ onveyed, and the time limited for his pa≈ø≈øage ‚Ä¢ hither; which time if by his own default he ‚Ä¢ xceeds, he ≈øhall incur the like puni≈øhment ‚Ä¢ rom time to time, till he arrive at the place ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ mited. The ≈øub≈øtance of the Te≈øtimonial is ‚Ä¢ o be entred by the Mini≈øter in a Regi≈øter Book, which he is to keep for that purpo≈øe on pain of 5 s. Dalt. f. 129.

div.p: W. W. a ≈øturdy vagrant Beggar (aged about forty years) tall of ≈øtature, red haired, and long lean vi≈øaged, and ≈øquint-eyed, was this 24th day of A. in the 22th year of the Reign of Our Gracious Sovereign Lord King Charles the Second, &c. openly whipped at T. in the County of G. according to the Law for a wandering Rogue; and is a≈ø≈øigned to pa≈øs forthwith from Pari≈øh to Pari≈øh, by the Officers thereof, the next ≈øtreight way to W. in the County of B. where he confe≈ø≈øeth he was Born; and he is limited to be at W. afore≈øaid, within twelve days now next en≈øuing, at his peril. Given under the Hands and Seals of C.W. Mini≈øter of T. afore≈øaid, and of J.G. Constable there, the day and year afore≈øaid.

vey him or her to the next Con≈øtable; or if „Äà‚óä„Äâ do receive him, and not convey him to the ne ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Con≈øtable, he forfeits five pounds, and may „Äà‚óä„Äâ bound to the Good Behaviour, 39 Eliz. c. Dal ‚Ä¢ on c. 47. fol. 128. Re≈øolu. Judges ≈øect. 1 ‚Ä¢ 14.

Every Per≈øon ≈øhall apprehend, or cau≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ be apprehended ≈øuch Rogues as he ≈øhall „Äà‚óä„Äâ or know to re≈øort to his Hou≈øe to beg, or r ‚Ä¢
ceive any Alms, and him or them ≈øhall car ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or cau≈øe to be carried to the next Con≈øtable; „Äà‚óä„Äâ el≈øe ≈øhall forfeit for every ≈øuch Default „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øhilling, and the Con≈øtable is to whip and co ‚Ä¢
vey ≈øuch Rogues, as before is directed, on p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of twenty ≈øhillings, 1 Jac. c. 7. Dalt. c. 47. f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
128. Re≈øolu. Judges, ≈øect. 13, 14.

Two Ju≈øtices of Peace, (one of the Quo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
by Warrant under their Hands and Seals, m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ cau≈øe to be levied, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of th ‚Ä¢ Offenders Goods, all the Fines and Forfeiture afore≈øaid, after Conviction of the Party, which mu≈øt be either by Confe≈ø≈øion of the Party; „Äà‚óä„Äâ Proof of two Witne≈ø≈øes before the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices, 39 Eliz. c. 4. Con≈øtables or Tythingmen neglecting t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øearch for Rogues upon the Ju≈øtices Warrant or to appear at their Meeting, to give an account what Rogues have been puni≈øhed, or ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction; or if they neglect to convey ≈øuch to the Hou≈øe of Correction, as by Warrant are to be ≈øent thither, they are
liable to ≈øuch Fine as the Ju≈øtices plea≈øe, not exceeding forty ≈øhillings, 7 Jac. c. 4.

Any Ju≈øtice of the Peace may reward any Per≈øon or Per≈øons, who ≈øhall apprehend, and bring before him any Rogue, Vagabond, or ≈øturdy Beggar, by granting to ≈øuch Per≈øon a Warrant under his Hand and Seal, to the Con≈øtable or Tythingman of the place through which the Rogue did pa≈øs unapprehended; ordering the ≈øaid Con≈øtable, &c. to give ≈øuch Per≈øon two ≈øhillings for every Rogue ≈øo taken: And if the Con≈øtable, &c. refu≈øe to pay it, the Ju≈øtice of the Peace may proceed again≈øt ≈øuch Officers, according to the Stat. 1 Jac. 7. and compel him to pay his Forfeiture by the ≈øaid Statute, and to allow the ≈øaid two ≈øhillings out of the ≈øaid Forfeiture, to ≈øuch Per≈øon, with ≈øuch further Allowance for lo≈øs of time, as the Ju≈øtice ≈øhall think fit, 1 Jac. 7. 14 Car. 2. c. 12.

If any Per≈øon ≈øhall apprehend any Rogue, at the Confines of any County, which pa≈ø≈øed through any Pari≈øh of another County unapprehended, then the Per≈øon ≈øo apprehending ≈øuch Rogue, mu≈øt carry him to ≈øome Ju≈øtice of Peace of the County through which he pa≈ø≈øed unapprehended, who (upon a Certificate under the Hand of ≈øome Ju≈øtice of Peace of the County where ≈øuch Rogue was apprehended) is to grant his Warrant to the Con≈øtable, &c. to pay two ≈øhillings, as afore≈øaid; which if he refu≈øe or neglect, then the Ju≈øtice is to proceed again≈øt the Con≈øtable, &c. and cau≈øe him to pay ten ≈øhillings to the Party, or ≈øo much thereof for lo≈øs of time as the Ju≈øtice ≈øhall think fit, 14 Car. 2. c. 12.

And al≈øo, That whereas Con≈øtables, Tythingmen, &c. are at great Charges in Relieving, carrying with Pa≈ø≈øes, and conveyin ‚Ä¢ Rogues, &c. all Con≈øtables, Tythingmen, &c. ≈øo out of Pur≈øe, with the Churchwardens as Over≈øeers of the Poor, and other Inhabitan ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of the Pari≈øh, may make a Rate, and tax „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Inhabitants of the Pari≈øh, which a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ chargeable by the 43 of Eliz. which Rate mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be confirmed under the Hands and Seals o ‚Ä¢ two Ju≈øtices of the Peace. And if any Per≈øo ‚Ä¢ refu≈øe to pay his Rate, then the Con≈øtable, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Warrant from two Ju≈øtices of Peace, may Je ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the ≈øame upon the Goods of the Party refu≈øing rendring them the Overplus, if any remai ‚Ä¢ thereof, 14 Car. 2. c. 12.

All the≈øe Per≈øons hereafter named, are accounted and adjudged Rogues, Vagabonds, an ‚Ä¢ ≈øturdy Beggars: That is to ≈øay, All ≈øuch Per≈øons above the Age of ≈øeven years, Man o ‚Ä¢ Woman, Sole or Covert, that wander from their u≈øual place of Abode, abroad, every where begging; or if they do not beg, yet „Äà‚óä„Äâ they wander and loiter about without a lawfu ‚Ä¢ Pa≈øport, and give no good account for their Travel, are accounted Rogues, 39 Eliz. c. 4. & 17. 43 Eliz. c. 2. 1 Jac. c. 7. 21 Jac. c. 28. 7 Jac. c. 24. 5 Eliz. c. 4. Dalt. c. 47. fol. 123, 124, 125.

All Scholars and Seafaring men which beg, wandring Per≈øons that u≈øe unlawful Games, ≈øubtil Craft or Plays, or pretending them≈øelves to have skill in Phy≈øiognomy, Palmi≈øtry, or the like; or to be Fortune-tellers, or Figure-ca≈øters.

All Proctors, Patent-gatherers, (except for Fire) Collectors for Goals, Pri≈øoners or Ho≈øpitals, wandring abroad; Fencers, Bearwards, (tho≈øe are Rogues in Grain) common Players of Interludes, and Fidlers or Min≈øtrels, wandring abroad.

All Juglers, Hocus Pocus, and Slight of Hand Arti≈øts, Tinkers, Pedlars, and Petty Chapmen and Gla≈øs-men, wandring abroad, e≈øpecially if they be not well known, or have not a ≈øufficient Te≈øtimonial; all counterfeit Egyptians, not being Felons; all Per≈øons delivered out of Goals, which beg for their Fees, or otherwi≈øe do travel begging; ≈øuch as go to ‚Ä¢ or from the B ‚Ä¢ ths, and do not pur≈øue their Licen≈øe, Soldiers and Mariners that beg, and counterfeit a Certificate of their Commanders.

All Labourers which wander abroad out of the Pari≈øh, and refu≈øe to work for Wages rea≈øonably taxed, having no living otherwi≈øe to maintain them≈øelves; and ≈øuch as go with a General Pa≈øport, which is not directed from Pari≈øh to Pari≈øh.
All the≈øe are accounted Rogues, Vagabonds, and ≈øturdy Beggars.

All Servants that depart out of their Service, (viz. out of one City, Town or Pari≈øh to another, or out of one Hundred or County to ≈øerve in another) without a Te≈øtimonial, or with a fal≈øe one; and ≈øuch Per≈øons as are ≈øick of the Plague, and wilfully go abroad in Company, again≈øt the command of Officers, are to be puni≈øhed as Vagabonds; but none are to be ≈øent to the place of Birth or la≈øt Habitation, but wandring Rogues. Tho≈øe which beg in
their own Pari≈øh, or in High ways, (witho ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the appointment of the Over≈øeers) are to b ‚Ä¢ ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction.

A Wife and Children under ≈øeven years „Äà‚óä„Äâ Age, being vagrant, mu≈øt be placed with th ‚Ä¢ Husband; and if the Husband be dead, the ‚Ä¢ with the Wife where ≈øhe was born, or l ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dwelt; and vagrant Children above ≈øeve ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ years of Age, mu≈øt be ≈øent to the place „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Birth; and if the Vagrant Parents, wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ their Children under ≈øeven years of Age, „Äà‚óä„Äâ placed at the place of Birth of the Parents, „Äà‚óä„Äâ at the place of Dwelling; if afterwards th ‚Ä¢ Parents, or either of them die, or run away yet the Children once ≈øettled, mu≈øt rema ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ there ≈øtill, and may not be ≈øent to the place „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Birth, though afterwards they attain t ‚Ä¢ the Age of ≈øeven years, 39 Eliz. c 4. Dalt. J.P‚ñ™ c 47. fol. 135. Re≈øolu. Judges, ≈øect. 4, 5.

The Wife being but a vagrant Rogue, ough ‚Ä¢ to be ≈øent to her Husband, though he be b ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ a Servant in another Town or Pari≈øh; and th ‚Ä¢ Rogue who≈øe place or dwelling cannot be know ‚Ä¢ having Wife or Children under ≈øeven years „Äà‚óä„Äâ Age, they mu≈øt go with the Husband to the place where they were la≈øt ≈øuffered to pa≈øs through unpuni≈øhed; where the Children mu≈ø ‚Ä¢ be relieved with the Work of their Parents though their Parents be committed to the Hou≈øe of Correction.

div.head: CHAP. XXXIII. The Con≈øtables Office about keeping the Sabbath.

The Ju≈øtice of Peace, or Chief Officer of the City, Borough, &c. before whom the Offender ‚Ä¢ s convicted, by View, Confe≈ø≈øion, or Oath of ‚Ä¢ one Witne≈øs, ≈øhall give Warrant to the Con≈øta
‚Ä¢ les or Churchwardens, to ≈øeize the Goods ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ried, or put to ≈øale, and to ≈øell them, and to ‚Ä¢ evy the other Penalties by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of Goods, and in ca≈øe of inability, &c. to ≈øet the Offenders in the Stocks for two hours: the Penalties to be to the Poor of the Pari≈øh where the Offence ‚Ä¢ s committed, ≈øaving that the Ju≈øtice or Head Officer may reward Informers, the Reward not exceeding a third part of the Penalties. But Pro≈øecution mu≈øt be made upon this Act within ‚Ä¢ en days after the Offence committed, 29 Car. 2. c. 7.

Dre≈ø≈øing of Meat in Families, Inns, Cooks

No Writ, Proce≈øs, Warrant, &c. ≈øhall be ≈øerved on the Lords day, except for Trea≈øon, Felony, or Breach of the Peace; but the Service ≈øhall be void, and the Party ≈øerving it ≈øhall an≈øwer Damages, as if done without Warrant, 29 Car. 2. c. 7.

Note, Where no Di≈øtre≈øs is to be had, th ‚Ä¢ Offender, if above twelve years of Age, ≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by Warrant, as afore≈øaid, be ≈øet in the Stoc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ three whole hours; but if the Offender be ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
der the Age of twelve years, and ≈øhall not forth with pay the ≈øaid Sum of twelve pence per Oath then he or ≈øhe is to be whipped by the Con≈øtable ‚Ä¢ or by the Parent, or Ma≈øter, in the Con≈øtable pre≈øence, 21 Jac. c. 20. 3 Car. 1. c. 4. Dalt. J.P. c. 55. fol. 138.

div.head: CHAP. XXXV. The Con≈øtables Office about Tobacco Planting.
div.p:
ALL Sheriffs, Ju≈øtices of Peace, Mayors, Bailiffs, Con≈øtables, and every of them, ‚Ä¢ pon Information or Complaint made to them, „Äà‚óä„Äâ any of them, by any of the Officers of the ‚Ä¢ u≈øtoms, or by any other Per≈øon or Per≈øons ‚Ä¢ hat≈øoever, that there is any Tobacco ≈øet, ≈øown, ‚Ä¢ anied, or growing within their Juri≈ødictions „Äà‚óä„Äâ Precincts, (except ≈øuch as is growing in any ‚Ä¢ hy≈øick Garden of either Univer≈øity, or in any ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ her private Garden, where the quantity of ‚Ä¢ round planted exceeds not one half of one ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ble, in any one Place or Garden) they are with

And if any Per≈øon or Per≈øons ≈øhall re≈øi≈øt, or ‚Ä¢ ake forceable oppo≈øition again≈øt any Per≈øon or ‚Ä¢ er≈øons in the due execution of this Office as a

‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ent Sureties in ten pounds Penalty, not to do „Äà‚óä„Äâ commit the like Offence again, 12 Car. 2. c. 34. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
Car. 2. c. 7.

And now by the Stat. 22 & 23 Car. 2. It further provided, That the Ju≈øtice of Peace „Äà‚óä„Äâ a month before every Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, „Äà‚óä„Äâ Warrants to High Con≈øtables, Petty Con≈øtabl ‚Ä¢ and Tythingmen, to make ≈øearch what To ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ is then ≈øown, planted or made, and by who ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and to make Pre≈øentment thereof in Wri ‚Ä¢ upon Oath at the next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions; wh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Pre≈øentment ≈øhall be a conviction in Law, „Äà‚óä„Äâ le≈øs the Party (having ten days notice before „Äà‚óä„Äâ Se≈ø≈øions) traver≈øe the ≈øame there, and find S ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ties to pro≈øecute his Traver≈øe the next Quar ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Se≈ø≈øions after ≈øuch Traver≈øe entred, 22 & „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Car. 2. c. 26.

Con≈øtables, Tythingmen, and other pub ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Officers, ≈øhall from time to time, within fourt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ days after Warrant from two or more Ju≈øti ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of Peace, calling to them ≈øuch as they find c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
venient, de≈øtroy all Tobacco planted or gr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ing in any Ground: If ≈øuch Tobacco be „Äà‚óä„Äâ con≈øumed fourteen days after receipt of „Äà‚óä„Äâ Warrant, ≈øuch Con≈øtables, Tythingmen, or ot ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Officers re≈øpectively ≈øhall forfeit five ≈øhilli ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for every Rod ≈øo ≈øet or planted, &c. and p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
portionably for a greater or le≈øs quantity; „Äà‚óä„Äâ moiety to the King, the other to him that ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ t ≈øue for the ≈øame, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 26.

Per≈øons refu≈øing to a≈ø≈øi≈øt the Con≈øtable, ‚Ä¢ being convicted before two Ju≈øtices of Peac ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall forfeit five ≈øhillings, to be levied by di≈øtr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and ≈øale of Goods, and for want thereof ≈øhall „Äà‚óä„Äâ committed for a week: And Per≈øons forc ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ re≈øi≈øting any Con≈øtable, &c. being convicted afore≈øaid, ≈øhall forfeit five pounds, to be levied afore≈øaid, and in default thereof, ≈øhall be co ‚Ä¢
mitted for three months, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 26.

Phy≈øick Gardens, and Gardens for Chirurgery ‚Ä¢ xcepted, as in the former Acts. div.head: CHAP. XXXVI. The Con≈øtables Office about Weights and Mea≈øures
div.p: ALL Cities, Boroughs, and Market Towns in England, ought to keep common Weights and Mea≈øures ≈øealed, at which the Inhabitants may weigh freely; and all Foreiners mu≈øt pay for every Draught under forty pounds, one Farthing; for a Draught between forty and an hundred, an Half-penny; and for a Draught between an hundred and a thou≈øand, one Penny; wherewith the Weights are to be maintained; and the Officers which attend that Service are to be rewarded at the di≈øcretion of the Inhabitants, 8 H 6. c. 5.

Every City which wants ≈øuch Weights and Mea≈øures, forfeits 10 l. to the King, every Borough 5 l. and every Market Town 40 s. and the chief Officers of ≈øuch places (upon reque≈øt to them made) are to Mark and Seal ≈øuch Weights and Mea≈øures to any of the Kings Subjects, taking for the marking of every
Bu≈øhel one Penny; and none ought to „Äà‚óä„Äâ with any other Weights and Mea≈øures, but ≈øuc ‚Ä¢ as are marked or ≈øealed, 8 H. 6. c. 5. 11 H.
‚Ä¢

The Mayors and chief Officers in Cities, & ‚Ä¢
are once every year, at lea≈øt, to view all Me ‚Ä¢
≈øures and Weights in their Juri≈ødictions, „Äà‚óä„Äâ to break or burn ≈øuch as they find defective and to puni≈øh the Offenders for the fir≈øt O ‚Ä¢
fence ≈øix ≈øhillings eight pence, for the ≈øecon ‚Ä¢ thirteen ≈øhillings four pence, and for the thi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Offence, twenty ≈øhillings; and be≈øides, „Äà‚óä„Äâ adjudge the Offenders to the Pillory, ‚Ä¢ 1 H.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVII. The Con≈øtables Office about Watches.
div.p: A Watch is to be kept in every Town, Pari≈øh, Village and Tything, every nigh ‚Ä¢ from A≈øcen≈øion till Michaelmas, from Sun-≈øet to Sun-ri≈øe, which the Con≈øtables, &c. mu≈øt con≈øtantly cau≈øe to be ≈øet, and, that by two o ‚Ä¢ four Men, according to the greatne≈øs of the place, 13 Edw. 1. c. 4. Dalt. c. 60. f. 140. P ‚Ä¢ ul ‚Ä¢ Watch. 1.

The≈øe Watchmen are to apprehend and examine all Strangers that pa≈øs by them in the Night, and if they find cau≈øe of ≈øu≈øpition „Äà‚óä„Äâ them, then they may ≈øecure them till the Morning; and if the Parties refu≈øe to obey the Watchmen, they may levy Hue and Cry to take them, and upon their re≈øi≈øtance, the Watchmen may ju≈øtifie the beating of them, and ≈øet
them in the Stocks or Cage till Morning; and ‚Ä¢ hen if no ≈øu≈øpition be found in the Parties, ‚Ä¢ hey may let them go; but if there be found ≈øu≈øpition in them, then the Watchmen may de
‚Ä¢ iver them to the Con≈øtable, or Tythingmen, &c. who is to convey them before a Ju≈øtice of Peace, who after Examination of them, may bind them over, commit or acquit them as he ≈øhall ≈øee cau≈øe. The≈øe Watchmen are al≈øo to apprehend all ≈øuch as ride or go armed, and all Rogues, Vagabonds, Noctivagants, Nightwalkers, Eve≈ødroppers, Scouts, and ≈øuch like, 1 Dalt. c. 60. fol. 140. 5 Ed. 3. 14. 5 H. 7. 5.
The≈øe three particulars following, have been held for Law concerning Watches, viz. Dalt. J.P. c. 60. fol. 141.

list.item: 1. The Watchmen mu≈øt be Men of able Body, well and ≈øufficiently armed, and no Man is compellable to watch, unle≈øs he be an Inhabitant within the ≈øame Town or Pari≈øh where he is required to watch.

2. Such as are Inhabitants within the Town, are not compellable to watch at the will of the Con≈øtable, but only when their turn comes, according to the u≈øe and cu≈øtom of the place, which is mo≈øt commonly by Turn or Hou≈øe.

3. It hath been held by ≈øome, That if a Man, who is compellable to watch, ≈øhall contemptuou≈øly refu≈øe to watch, upon command of the Con≈øtable, that in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Con≈øtable might, ex Officio, ≈øet the Party in the Stocks for his contempt, Dalt. ibid.

div.p: But the ≈øafe≈øt way is for the Con≈øtable „Äà‚óä„Äâ pre≈øent ≈øuch Per≈øon for his Default at the A≈ø≈øi≈ø ‚Ä¢ or Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, or el≈øe to compl ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of him to a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, who „Äà‚óä„Äâ bind the Offender to the Good Behaviour, a ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øo over to the next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, there „Äà‚óä„Äâ an≈øwer, &c.

div.head: CHAP. XXXVIII. The Con≈øtables Office about Executing Warrants.
div.p:
THE Con≈øtable, or other ≈øworn Officers whom any Warrant ≈øhall be directe ‚Ä¢ and delivered, ought with all ≈øpeed and ≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
cy to ≈øeek and find out the Party, and then „Äà‚óä„Äâ execute his ≈øaid Warrant.

A known ≈øworn Officer (be he Sheriff, U ‚Ä¢
der Sheriff, Bailiff or Con≈øtable, &c.) need not to ≈øhew his Warrant to a Man when „Äà‚óä„Äâ comes to ≈øerve it upon him, though he d ‚Ä¢
mandeth it; but if the Ju≈øtice will direct „Äà‚óä„Äâ Warrant to his Servant, or to another (wh ‚Ä¢ is no ≈øworn Officer) to ≈øerve it, they m ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhew their Warrant to the Party, if he deman ‚Ä¢ it, or otherwi≈øe the Party may make re≈øi≈øtance, and needs not to obey it, Bro. Faux I ‚Ä¢ pri≈ø. 23.
A ≈øworn and known Officer, if he will no ‚Ä¢ ≈øhew his Warrant yet he ought to declare to the Party the Contents thereof upon ≈øerving it Co. 6.54. & 9.68.

An Officer giveth ≈øufficient notice what he is when he ≈øaith to the Party, I Arre≈øt you in the Kings Name, &c. and in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Party, at his
peril, ought to obey him, though he knoweth ‚Ä¢ im not to be an Officer; and if he have no ‚Ä¢ awful Warrant, the Party gieved may have ‚Ä¢ is Action of Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment again≈øt him,
‚Ä¢ o. 6.69.

If a Con≈øtable, or other Officer, do arre≈øt a Man for the Peace, or the like, before he hath ‚Ä¢ ny Warrant, and then afterwards doth pro
‚Ä¢ ure a Warrant (or a Warrant cometh after to ‚Ä¢ im) to arre≈øt the Party for the ≈øame cau≈øe, ‚Ä¢ he fir≈øt Arre≈øt was unlawful, and the Officer is ‚Ä¢ able to an Action of Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, Dyer
‚Ä¢ 44. Stat. 43 El. c. 6.

Where a Warrant is granted again≈øt I. H. the Son of T. H. and the Officer thereupon arre≈øteth I. H. the Son of W. H. although in truth he ‚Ä¢ e the ≈øame Per≈øon that offended, and again≈øt whom the complaint was made, yet this Arre≈øt is wrongful, and the Officer is ≈øubject to an Action of Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment, 10 E. 4. fol. 12.
‚Ä¢ r. Fal≈øe Impri≈ø. 38.

If a Con≈øtable, or any other Per≈øon, hath arre≈øted a Man by virtue of his Warrant, which he hath from a Ju≈øtice of the Peace, and then taketh his Word, that he will come to him again at another time, to go with him to the Ju≈øtice according to his Warrant, (and ≈øo latteth the Party go) who comes not again at the time appointed, it ≈øeems the Officer cannot afterwards arre≈øt, or take him again by force of his former Warrant, becau≈øe this was done by the con≈øent of the Officer; but if the Party arre≈øted had e≈øcaped (of his own wrong) without the con≈øent of the Officer, the Officer may take him again, and again, upon fre≈øh Suit ≈øo often as he e≈øcapeth, although he be out of
view, or that he fly into another Town „Äà‚óä„Äâ County. Cromp. 214. a. & 184. Cro. 53.144.

When an Officer hath received a Warrant he is bound to ob≈øerve and pur≈øue the effe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ of his Warrant in every behalf and particul ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or otherwi≈øe his Warrant will not excu≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ of that which he hath done.

If a Con≈øtable, or other Officer, having lawful Warrant to arre≈øt another, and he ≈øh ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be re≈øi≈øted or a≈ø≈øaulted by the Party, or by a ‚Ä¢
other Per≈øon, then may that Officer ju≈øtifie t ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ heating or hurting of ≈øuch Per≈øons, and other (upon his reque≈øt) may and ought to aid hi ‚Ä¢ 21 H. 7.39.

If a Ju≈øtice of Peace ≈øhall i≈ø≈øue our any Wa ‚Ä¢
rant for a Matter wherein he hath Juri≈ødictio ‚Ä¢ although it be beyond his Authority, yet it „Äà‚óä„Äâ not di≈øputable by the Con≈øtable, or other ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Officer, but mu≈øt be obeyed and executed „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Con≈øtable, or other Officer, to whom it „Äà‚óä„Äâ brought. As if a Ju≈øtice of Peace ≈øhall ≈øe ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ forth his Warrant to arre≈øt one for the Pea ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ or Good Behaviour without cau≈øe, the Office ‚Ä¢ that ≈øerves this Warrant, ≈øhall not be puni≈øhe ‚Ä¢ for the executing thereof; but if a Ju≈øtice „Äà‚óä„Äâ Peace ≈øhall make his Warrant to do a thi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ out of his Juri≈ødiction, or in a Cau≈øe where ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ the Ju≈øtice of Peace is no Judge, if the Offic ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhall ≈øerve ≈øuch a Warrant, here he is puni≈øhable; for the Officer is not bound to obey him who is not Judge of the Cau≈øe no more tha ‚Ä¢ a meer Stranger, for the Officer is bound „Äà‚óä„Äâ take notice of the Authority and Juri≈ødiction „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Judge, 14 H. 8.16. Br. Faux Impri≈ø. 8. Co. 10 26. Cromp. 74.

But if any Ju≈øtice ≈øends his Warrant to a Con≈øtable, or any other Officer, to bring him to an≈øwer all ≈øuch Matters as ≈øhall be objected again≈øt him, and doth not ≈øpecifie the Cau≈øe in his Warrant, wherefore he i≈ø≈øued forth the ≈øame, this Warrant is unlawful, and the Officer is liable to an Action of Fal≈øe Impri≈øonment if he executes it.

So if a Ju≈øtice of Peace ≈øend a Warrant to take one for Cozenage, to take and bring to a Ju≈øtice, or to Goal, one that another doth ≈øu≈øpect for Felony, where the Matter is ≈ømall, or the Su≈øpition ≈ølight, or to licen≈øe a petty Chapman to ≈øell from Hou≈øe to Hou≈øe, to ≈øend a poor Body to a place otherwi≈øe than the Law directs, ≈øuch kind of Warrants are not Warrantable.
All Warrants not ≈øpecifying the Cau≈øe, are utterly again≈øt Law, Cooks Inst. part 4. Tit. de Frangent. Pri≈øon.

p.hi: Except for Trea≈øon, or Warrants from the Council, Secretaries of State, or Lord Chief Ju≈øtice, the≈øe need not ≈øet forth the Cau≈øe for Rea≈øons of State.

div.p: If any Man ≈øhall contemn or abu≈øe the Ju≈øtice of Peace his Warrant, as by ca≈øting it into the Dirt, or treading it under his Feet, &c. ≈øuch Offender may be bound to his Good Behaviour for it, and be indicted and fined, it being a contempt again≈øt the Kings Proce≈øs. Cromp. 144.

div.head: THE Churchwardens OFFICE.
CHAP. I. The Antiquity of the Churchwardens Office, and how they are to be cho≈øen.
div.p: THE Antiquity of the Office of a Churchwarden (when they fir≈øt received that Title) is very uncertain; but ≈øome are of Opinion, that it was about eighty ≈øeven Years after Britain had received the Chri≈øtian Faith, which mo≈øt Hi≈øtorians do agree, was planted here in the Reign of King Lucius, in the Year of Chri≈øt CLXXX, who is hitherto ≈øtilled the fir≈øt Chri≈øtian King of this I≈øle; and that Diony≈øius In the Year CCLXVII did divide (both in Rome and other places) to Bi≈øhops their Dioce≈øes; and Pari≈øhes, Churches and Churchyards to Prie≈øts, Vicars and Curats; whether at that time, or how long after Churchwardens were in≈øtituted, is not certainly known.

But all Authors do agree, that they are very ancient Officers, that the≈øe Churchwardens of Pari≈øhes are at the Common Law taken in the manner of a Corporation, 12 H. 7. ult. that „Äà‚óä„Äâ to ≈øay, Churchwardens at the Common Law are per≈øons enabled by that Name to take Moveable Goods or Chattels, and to ≈øue, or be ≈øued at the Law concerning ≈øuch Goods for the u≈øe and profit of their Pari≈øh. And they are to take care, ≈øee to, and pre≈øerve the Goods of the Church, viz. The Church-Books Communion Cups, &c. and other decent Ornaments and Furniture of the Church, which they do find there at their coming into their Office.

In the Book of Con≈øtitutions and canons Eccle≈øia≈øtical, agreed upon in the Synod beg ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ at London Anno Dom. 1603. and in the fir≈øt Yea ‚Ä¢ of King James, it is appointed, that Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, Sidemen, or A≈ø≈øi≈øtants „Äà‚óä„Äâ every Pari≈øh, ≈øhall be cho≈øen by the joynt Con≈øent of the Mini≈øter and the Pari≈øhioners, if i ‚Ä¢ may be; but if they cannot agree upon ≈øuch a choice, then the Mini≈øter ≈øhall chu≈øe one, and the Pari≈øhioners another; and without ≈øuch a joynt or ≈øeveral Choice, none ≈øhall take upon them to be Churchwardens; neither ≈øhall they continue any longer than one Year in that Ofifice, except they be cho≈øen again in like manner; and they are to be yearly cho≈øen in Ea≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Week; Canon 89, 90.

But notwith≈øtanding this Canon, where there is an ancient Cu≈øtom in any Pari≈øh for the choic ‚Ä¢ of Churchwardens contrary to the Canon, in ≈øuc ‚Ä¢ ca≈øe the Cu≈øtom is to be ob≈øerved before th ‚Ä¢
Canon, as ≈øhall be in≈øtanced in ≈øeveral ca≈øes here after mentioned.

If the Pari≈øhioners of a Pari≈øh have u≈øed time out of mind, &c. to chu≈øe one Churchwarden, and the Par≈øon or Vicar another, and afterwards a Canon is made, that the Vicar ≈øhall elect two, and he do ≈øo accordingly; and the Pari≈øhioners elect one, according to their Cu≈øtom, and the Ordinary di≈øallows him, and confirms the other two cho≈øen by the Vicar, in this ca≈øe a Prohibition ≈øhall be granted, The Pari≈øhioners Ca≈øe of Rovenden in Kent, Rolls Ca≈øes, part 2‚ñ™ f. 287. Pa≈ø. 5 Jac. B. R.

A Prohibition was granted again≈øt a Churchwarden cho≈øen by the Par≈øon of St. Magnus by London Bridge by force of a Canon, upon a Surmi≈øe, that the Pari≈øh had a Cu≈øtom to chu≈øe two Churchwardens, Trin. 7 Car. 1. B.R. between Shirley and Brown, Rot. 1391. Rolls 2 part, fol. 287.
Warners Ca≈øe, B. R. Pa≈ø. 17 Jac. The like was granted again≈øt a Churchwarden cho≈øen by the Par≈øon of St. Alhallows London.
Pa≈ø. 5 Jac. Cro. 2 part Rep. The Ca≈øe of the Pari≈øhioners of Walbrook London.
Pa≈ø. 15 Car 1. B.R. The like again≈øt a Churchwarden cho≈øen by the Par≈øon of St. Thomas in London, Cro. 3 part, Evelyns Ca≈øe.
