An Attorny cannot be made a Churchwarden; but if he be put in, and refu≈øe, and be ≈øued in the Spiritual Court, he may have a Prohibition, Wil≈øons Ca≈øe, Pa≈ø. 14 Car. 1. B. R. & Bakers Ca≈øe, Trin. 14. Car. 1. B. R. Rolls Ca≈øes, 2 part, f. 272.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Churchwardens Office about Profanation of the Sabbath, and of the Church.
div.p: THE Churchwardens are diligently to ≈øet that all the Pari≈øhioners duly re≈øort to their Pari≈øh Church on Sundays and Holydays, and there continue the whole time of Divine Service; and none to walk, or ≈øtand idle, or talking in the Church, Church-yard or Church porch, during that time; and all ≈øuch as ≈øhal be found ≈ølack or negligent in re≈øorting to the Church, (having no great or urgent cau≈øe of Ab≈øence) they ≈øhall earne≈øtly call upon them, and if they amend not after due Admonition, they mu≈øt pre≈øent their Names to the Ordinary of the place, Canon 90. 5 Ed. 6. c. 1.

If the Churchwardens find any Per≈øon ab≈øent from the Church upon Sundays or Holy days in the time of Divine Service, Preaching, or other Holy Exerci≈øe, ≈øuch Per≈øon is to pay 12 d. to the u≈øe of the Poor. And this extends as well to all Women Covert, as to other Per≈øons; or the Churchwardens may pre≈øent ≈øuch Offenders in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court; but they mu≈øt not pay 12 d. and be pre≈øented too, 1 Eliz. c. 1. Hob. Rep. f. 97.

If the Officer find any Tipling, in any Inn or Alehou≈øe, in the time of Divine Service, then they forfeit 3 s. 4 d. more for Tipling, be≈øides the 12 d. for being ab≈øent from the Church; And the Ma≈øter of the Hou≈øe that ≈øuffers them to drink, forfeits 10 s. which Forfeitures are to the u≈øe of the Poor, 4 Jac. c. 5.

The Churchwardens, or Que≈øtmen, and ‚Ä¢ heir A≈ø≈øi≈øtants, ≈øhall ≈øuffer no Plays, Fea≈øts, Banquets, Suppers, Church Ales, Drinkings, Temporal Courts or Leets, Lay Juries, Mu≈øters, or any other Profane U≈øage to be kept in ‚Ä¢ he Church, Chapel, or Church-yard; neither the Bells to be rung ≈øuper≈øtitiou≈øly upon Holydays or Eves abrogated by the Book of Common Prayer, nor at any other times without good cau≈øe, to be allowed by the Mini≈øter of the place, and by them≈øelves, Can. 88.

Neither the Mini≈øter, Churchwardens, nor any other Officer of the Church, ≈øhall ≈øuffer any Man to preach within their Churches nor Chapels, but ≈øuch as by ≈øhewing their Licen≈øe to preach ≈øhall appear unto them to be ≈øufficiently authorized thereunto, Can. 50, 85.

And the Churchwardens and Que≈øtmen are al≈øo to ≈øee that in every Meeting of the Congregation the Peace be well kept, and that all Per≈øons excommunicated, and ≈øo denounced, be kept out of the Church.

Every of the Per≈øons appointed by the ≈øaid Act, to take the Oaths of Supremacy and Allegiance, in the re≈øpective Court where he takes the ≈øaid Oaths, ≈øhall fir≈øt deliver a Certificate of his receiving the Sacrament of the Lords Supper, as in and by the ≈øaid Act is likewi≈øe appointed, under the Hands of the re≈øpective Mini≈øter and Churchwardens, and ≈øhall then make proof of the Truth thereof, by two credible Witne≈ø≈øes at the lea≈øt upon Oath, 25 Car. 2. c. 2.

div.head: CHAP. III. Some few ca≈øes concerning Actions for, and again≈øt Churchwardens.
div.p: NOte, As I have ≈øaid before, the Lo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ doth make Churchwardens a kind „Äà‚óä„Äâ Corporation, and enables them by that Name t ‚Ä¢ take moveable Goods and Chattels, and to ≈ø ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and be ≈øued at Law concerning ≈øuch Goods fo ‚Ä¢ the u≈øe and benefit of their Pari≈øh; yet they cannot take an E≈øtate of Lands to them by Name of Churchwardens; for if a Feoffme ‚Ä¢ be made to the u≈øe of the Churchwardens of „Äà‚óä„Äâ this u≈øe is void, for they have no capacity „Äà‚óä„Äâ take ≈øuch Purcha≈øe, Finch lib. 2. c. 17. p. 179 Rolls Ca≈øes, 1 part, fol. 393.
Neither can Churchwardens pre≈øcribe to have Lands to them and their Succe≈ø≈øors, for they are no Corporation to have Lands, but for Goods of the Church only.

If a Man buy a Bell, and hang it up in the Steeple, or do make a Pew, and ≈øet it up is the Church, and do neither make any Word o ‚Ä¢ Writing there of, yet by this is the Bell o ‚Ä¢ Pew dedicated or given to the Church, 11 „Äà‚óä„Äâ 4. 12. 8 H 7. 12.

The Churchwardens have no Action at the Common Law to recover a Legacy, nor any thing which they never had; but if any Goods or Ornaments of the Church, be once in their Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion and Cu≈øtody, they may maintain as Appeal of Robbery again≈øt him that ≈øtealeth them, and an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs again≈øt him that ≈øhall wrongfully take them away, although
‚Ä¢ t be the Vicar or Par≈øon him≈øelf: and the Damages that ≈øhall be recovered thereby, ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ e to the u≈øe of the Pari≈øh, and not to their own u≈øe, 37 H 6. 30. & 34. 11 H. 4. 12.

But if tho≈øe Churchwardens (from whom ‚Ä¢ he Goods were ≈øo taken) ≈øhall happen to die before any Action by them brought for the Goods, the ≈øucceeding Churchwardens ≈øhall have an Action for the ≈øame Goods, Fitz. N.B.
‚Ä¢ 1. K.
If a Bell be broken, the Churchwardens may have an Action again≈øt him that brake it, and ≈øhall recover Damages, which ≈øhall be to the u≈øe of the Pari≈øh, and not to their own u≈øe.
The Churchwardens have no ≈øuch property in the Goods of the Church, as thereby to have power to give, ≈øell, relea≈øe, hurt, or impair them, without the a≈ø≈øent of the Sidemen or Ve≈øtry.

If the Churchwardens ≈øhall give or impair the Goods of the Church in their Cu≈øtody, the Pari≈øhioners may chu≈øe new ones, who may have an account again≈øt their Predece≈ø≈øors, Finch lib. 2. c. 17. p. 179.

If the Organs be taken out of the Church, the Churchwardens may bring an Action of Tre≈øpa≈øs for the ≈øame; for the Organs belong to the Pari≈øhioners, and not to the Par≈øon; and therefore the Par≈øon cannot ≈øue the Party in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court that took them, Trin. 21 Jac. B.R. Rolls Ca≈øes, 1 part. fol. 393.

If the Walls, Windows or Doors of the Church be broken down, or the Trees in the Church-yard be cut down, or the Grafts thereof
be eaten up; in this ca≈øe the Par≈øon or Vicar, and not the Churchwardens, ≈øhall ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ an Action for it. A Par≈øon may bring his action for breaking and entring into his Hou≈øe and Clo≈øe, when it is the Church and Church-yard, 10 H. 4. fol. 9. 8 H. 6. fol. 9.

The Churchwardens by the a≈ø≈øent and agreement of the Pari≈øhioners, may take a ruino ‚Ä¢ Bell, and deliver it to a Bell-Founder, as agree with him that he ≈øhall have four Pound ‚Ä¢ for ca≈øting it, and that he ≈øhall retain the ≈øa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ till the four pounds be paid: And ≈øuch agreement of the Pari≈øhioners ≈øhall excu≈øe the Churchwardens in a Writ of Account brought again≈øt them by their Succe≈ø≈øors Churchwardens, M. 3 ‚Ä¢ 38 El. B. R. Methold and Winne ‚Ä¢

If the Churchwardens pre≈øent in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, That one A.B. (one of their Pari≈øhioners) is a Railer, and Sower of Di≈øco ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ among≈øt his Neighbours; in ≈øuch ca≈øe there lies a Prohibition; for this belongs to the Lee ‚Ä¢ and not to the Spiritual Court, unle≈øs ≈øuch Railing were in the Church or Church-yard Mich. 16 Jac. If the Churchwardens of H. ≈øue R. A. in the Eccle≈øia≈øtical Court, for that he and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he hath in ≈øuch an Hou≈øe, &c. at the Perambulation or Proce≈ø≈øion of the Pari≈øhioners of the Pari≈øh, did u≈øe to provide „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Refre≈øhing for them, with Bread, Cakes, Chee≈øe, and Ale, &c. and ≈øuffer them to re≈øt there; in this ca≈øe a Prohibition will be granted, for that they claim it in the nature of a Corrody.

div.head: CHAP. IV. The Churchwardens Office about di≈øpo≈øing of Seats in their Church.
div.p: THE Churchwardens are to look to the Repair of the Seats in the Church, but the di≈øpo≈øing of the Seats in the Body of the Church belongs of common Right to the Ordinary of the Dioce≈øs, ≈øo that he may place and di≈øplace whom he plea≈øes, except in ≈øome ca≈øes.

As if a Man and his Ance≈øtors, and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate he hath in a certain Me≈ø≈øuage, have u≈øed time out of mind to repair an I≈øle of the Church, and to ≈øit there, and none el≈øe; in ≈øuch place the Ordinary cannot di≈øplace him, becau≈øe he hath it by Pre≈øcription for a rea≈øonable con≈øideration.

If a Man pre≈øcribe, that he and his Ance≈øtors, and all tho≈øe who≈øe E≈øtate they had in a certain Me≈ø≈øuage, did u≈øe to ≈øit in a certain Seat in the Body of the Church, time out of mind, in con≈øideration that he and they have u≈øed time out of mind to repair the ≈øaid Seat, if the Ordinary remove him from ≈øuch Seat, a Prohibition may be brought, for the Ordinary hath no power to di≈øpo≈øe of it; for it is a
good Pre≈øcription, and by intendment a go ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Con≈øideration for the ≈øame.
But if a Man pre≈øcribe to have a Seat in th ‚Ä¢ Body of the Church generally, without con≈øideration to repair the ≈øame, in ≈øuch ca≈øe the Ordinary may di≈øplace him.
But the Ordinary hath nothing to do with th ‚Ä¢ Seats in the Chapels belonging to the Hou≈øes of Noblemen, Trin. 12 Jac. C.B. Rolls Ca≈øes, 2 par ‚Ä¢ fol. 288.

But if a Lay-man by the di≈ø≈øolution of Mona≈øteries hath a Mona≈øtery in which there is „Äà‚óä„Äâ Church, parcel of it, and he ≈øuffers the Pari≈øhioners for a long time to come to it, and do Divine Service, and to u≈øe it as their Pari≈øh-Church‚ñ™ this (unle≈øs for all the whole time the Party hath u≈øed to place Men in their Seats him≈øelf) ≈øhall give Juri≈ødiction to the Ordinary to order the Seats; for that now in Fact is the Pari≈øh-Church, although that before it were not ≈øubject to the Ordinary, Tr. 12 Jac. C. B. Buzzards Ca≈øe, Rol ‚Ä¢ s 2 part, f. 228, 289.

If there be a Cu≈øtom in a Pari≈øh that twelved the Pari≈øhioners may chu≈øe Churchwardens, which Churchwardens have power by the Cu≈øtom to repair the Seats, and make new ones is the Body of the Church, and to appoint what Per≈øons ≈øhall ≈øit in them; and the Churchwardens ≈øo elected, do erect a new Seat in the Body of the Church, and appoint a certain Man to ≈øit there, and afterwards the Ordinary decrees, that another ≈øhall have the Seat, here a Prohibition lies; for the Cu≈øtom hath fixed the power of di≈øpo≈øing the Seats in the Churchwardens, P. 16 Jac. B. R. Barbin and Tredennicks Ca≈øe for a Seat in Breock Church in the County of Cornwal: but the
rea≈øon of granting the Prohibition in this Ca≈øe, ‚Ä¢ as partly becau≈øe that the Sentence of the Or
‚Ä¢ inary was, That Tredennick ≈øhould have the Seat ‚Ä¢ o him and his Heirs, and that none ≈øhould di≈ø≈øturb him on pain of Excommunication, which „Äà‚óä„Äâ unrea≈øonable, and by ≈øuch Sentence he and his ‚Ä¢ eirs ≈øhould have it, though they were no In
‚Ä¢ abitants within the ≈øame Pari≈øh, Rolls Ca≈øes, ‚Ä¢ part, fol. 289.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Some Ca≈øes wherein the Churchwardens are equally concerned with the Con≈øtables and Over≈øeers of the Poor.
div.p: THE Churchwardens are to joyn with the Con≈øtables in making of Rates for the Relief of the poor maimed Soldiers and Mariners, and for conveying Pri≈øoners to the Goal, and to execute Warrants for the ≈øame.

The Churchwardens are to joyn with the Con≈øtables in chu≈øing of Surveyors for the High Ways, and in the ≈øetting down of Days for the Work, and in the over≈øight of the High Con≈øtables Account for the Mony they do receive upon any Forfeitures about the High Ways. And they may with the aid of two Ju≈øtices (one of the Quorum) force High Con≈øtables to account for, and pay in what Mony they have received forfeited for default of High Ways; and to execute the Ju≈øtices Warrants for the Penalties and Forfeitures about
clean≈øing the Streets, and repairing the High Ways, 14 Car. 2. c. 2.

The Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor are to execute the Ju≈øtices Warrant for levying the Penalties of five pounds upon the Parties Goods that is not buried in Woollen‚ñ™ which Penalty is to be imployed to the u≈øe of the Poor, 18 Car. 2. c. 4.

The Churchwardens in London, We≈øtmin≈øter, and Borough of Southwark, &c. upon every Monday or Tue≈øday in Ea≈øter Week, together with the Con≈øtable, Over≈øeers of the Poor, and Surveyors of High Ways in every Pari≈øh re≈øpectively, or the greater number of them; giving notice, or calling together ≈øuch other Inhabitants of their Pari≈øhes as have formerly born the like Offices, they, or the greater number of them are to make choice of, and ≈øhall nominate and appoint two or more able Per≈øons, that are Trade≈ømen of their Pari≈øh, to be Scavengers for the Streets, Lanes, and other open Pa≈ø≈øages of each Ward or Divi≈øion within the ≈øaid Pari≈øh for the Year next following, and until others be cho≈øen and ≈øettled in their places, 2 W. & M.

div.head: CHAP. VII. The Churchwardens Office about pa≈ø≈øing Accounts, together with the Heads of mo≈øt of the things which they are to pre≈øent in the Vi≈øitation Court.
div.p: THE Churchwardens at the end of their Year, or within one Month after at the mo≈øt, are before the Mini≈øter and Pari≈øhioners to give up a ju≈øt Account of their Receipts and Disbur≈øements; and at their going out of their Office, they are to deliver up to the Pari≈øhioners what Mony, or other things of right belonging unto the Church which they have remaining in their Hands, that it may be delivered over by them unto the next Churchwardens, by Bill indented, Canon 89.

If the Churchwardens refu≈øe to do this, they may be pre≈øented at the next Vi≈øitation Court for it, or the ≈øucceeding Churchwardens may bring their Action of Account again≈øt them at the Common Law, and compel them to it; and in this Account they ≈øhall be allowed their needful Disbur≈øements and Expences about the Pari≈øh Bu≈øine≈øs.

The Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, or Side≈ømen ≈øhall not be bound to exhibit their Pre≈øentments above once a Year where it hath been no oftner u≈øed, nor above twice a Year in any Dioce≈øs what≈øoever, except it be at the Bi≈øhops Vi≈øitation; for the which Pre≈øentments of every Pari≈øh Church or Chapel, the Regi≈øter of the Court where they are to be exhibited, ≈øhall not receive above 4 d. in one
Year, under pain of Su≈øpen≈øion from the execution of his Office the ≈øpace of one Mo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ for every Offence toties quoties. But the Church ‚Ä¢ wardens may voluntarily pre≈øent oftner if the ‚Ä¢ plea≈øe, Canon 116.

No Churchwardens, Que≈øtmen, or Side≈øm ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhall be called or cited but only at the time „Äà‚óä„Äâ times before limited, to appear before „Äà‚óä„Äâ Eccle≈øia≈øtical Judge what≈øoever, for refu≈øing „Äà‚óä„Äâ other times to pre≈øent any Faults committe ‚Ä¢ in their Pari≈øhes, and puni≈øhable by Eccle≈øia≈øtical Laws. Neither ≈øhall they or any of the ‚Ä¢ (after their Pre≈øentments exhibited at any „Äà‚óä„Äâ tho≈øe times) be any further troubled for „Äà‚óä„Äâ ≈øame, except it evidently appear that they „Äà‚óä„Äâ willingly and wittingly omit to pre≈øent ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ publick Crime or Crimes, as they knew „Äà‚óä„Äâ have been committed, or could nor be ‚Ä¢ g ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
rant that there was then a publick Fame „Äà‚óä„Äâ them; or unle≈øs there be very ju≈øt cau≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ call them to explain their former Pre≈øentment ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ And in ca≈øe of wilful omi≈ø≈øion, their Ordinarie ≈øhall proceed again≈øt them in ≈øuch ≈øort, as „Äà‚óä„Äâ Ca≈øes of wilful Perjury in a Court Eccle≈øia≈øtical it is already by Law provided, Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
117.

One of the two times of Pre≈øentments is ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
ways to be about a Week or Fortnight after Ea≈øter, at which time al≈øo the old Churchwardens are to leave their Office, and new one ‚Ä¢ are to come in; but the new ones are not „Äà‚óä„Äâ be ≈øworn till the old ones have given in the Pre≈øentments; and every Par≈øon or Vicar, „Äà‚óä„Äâ their Curats in their ab≈øence, are to joyn „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Pre≈øentment with the Churchwardens, & ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
and if the Churchwardens refu≈øe to pre≈øent
then every ≈øuch Par≈øon and Vicar, or in their ab≈øence their Curats may them≈øelves pre≈øent to their Ordinaries at all ≈øuch times, and when el≈øe they ≈øhall think fit, Canon 113, 118.

div.head: The Sum of the Articles u≈øually given to the Churchwardens to make their Pre≈øentments upon, are the≈øe, viz.
div.p: I. WHether their Church and Chancel, Bells and Ropes be in good repair, and the Ten Commandments, Lords Prayer and Creed, drawn out in fair Letters, the Kings Arms ≈øet up, A≈ø≈øe≈øsments made for the Repair of the Church, and Who refu≈øes to pay?

If they have a Font, Communion Table, Carpet, Table-Cloth, Flagons, with Cups and Cover for Bread and Wine, a Reading Desk, a Pulpit, with a Cu≈øhion and Covering for it, a fit Common Prayer Book of the large≈øt Volume, the Bible in Folio, of the la≈øt Tran≈ølation, with a Book of Homilies, and Book of Canons, and a Surplice?
If the Tombs, Monuments and Gravi-≈øtones be ≈øafely kept from removing and breaking?

A Book of Parchment for Regi≈øtring Chri≈øtnings, Weddings and Burials, &c. a Che≈øt with three Locks to put the ≈øame and the Church Ornaments in, with a Box for Alms, and a Table of Degrees prohibiting Marriage hung up in the Church?
If the Par≈øonage Hou≈øe, and Out-Hou≈øes, be in good Repair, and the Church-yard will fenced to keep out Swine, &c.

II. Whether the Par≈øon, Vicar or Curate, read the Common Prayer at Morning and Evening Service, wear his Surplice, bid Days, preach every
Sunday, or read an Homily, Catechi≈øe, ob≈øervet ‚Ä¢ fifth of November, thirtieth of January, twen ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ninth of May, and ≈øecond of September;
„Äà‚óä„Äâ ob≈øerve Perambulations, or going the Bounds „Äà‚óä„Äâ Rogation Week, preach ≈øound Doctrine, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ no Sedition again≈øt the King or Government; cel ‚Ä¢
brate the Lords Supper three times every Year „Äà‚óä„Äâ lea≈øt, whereof at Ea≈øter for one; baptize Infa ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ with Godfathers and Godmothers, vi≈øit the Sick and Pray with them, bury the Dead according t ‚Ä¢ the Book of Common Prayer, Marry none cla ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øtinely, preach in his Gown, be a Man of a fi≈ø ‚Ä¢ and cha≈øt Life, a Peace-maker among≈øt his Neighbours, and one that takes care to reduce Sectarius Recu≈øants, Separati≈øts, and refractory Per≈øons to the Obedience and Doctrine of the the Church; and reads the Book of Canons to the People at lea≈ø ‚Ä¢ once every Year, and the XXXIX Articles twi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ every Year.

III. Whether all their Pari≈øhioners of due „Äà‚óä„Äâ re≈øort to the Church to Divine Service, b ‚Ä¢ ha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ them≈øelves reverently there, kneel, ≈øtand up, and make An≈øwer to the Rubrick of the Common Pray ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Book? Whether any Work, or ≈øell Wares on Sundays or Holydays? Or whether Vintners, Victuallers, Innkeepers, or others do receive any to drink i ‚Ä¢ their Hou≈øes in the time of Divine Service?
Whether any Marry within the Degrees forbidden, or be Adulterers, Swearers, Bla≈øphemers, Drunkards?
If any above 16 Years of Age do not receive the Lord Supper three times a Year, whereof Ea≈øter to be one?

If any keep their Children unchri≈øtned, Women that come not to be churched, or any bring not
their Dead to be buried after the Service of the Church? Or if any be married without Banes or Licen≈øe at unlawful hours?

And whether their Alm≈øhou≈øes, Ho≈øpital, School or Spittle, if they have any, be well and godly u≈øed, or any thing detained from it? What Legacies given to pious u≈øes; and if the Pari≈øhioners be placed into Pews or Seats without offence or contention.
IV. Whether their Pari≈øh Clerk and Sexton (if they have any) be duly cho≈øen, can Write and Read, be of an hone≈øt Life, and make the Re≈øpon≈øes to the Hymns and other Suffrages?

And if the Schoolma≈øter, Phy≈øician, Chirurgion, and Midwife (if they have any) teach or practi≈øe without Licen≈øe? If the Churchwardens be duly cho≈øen according to the Canon or Cu≈øtom? And if the old Churchwardens have been diligent to keep the Church in good Repair, to pre≈øerve all the Furniture thereof, and walk out of the Church u≈øually about the mid≈øt of Divine Service, to ≈øee who are abroad in Alehou≈øes, or el≈øewhere ab≈øent or evilly imployed.

The≈øe are the Heads of mo≈øt of the Articles that are inquired of at the Vi≈øitation Courts; but it is probable there may be ≈øome ≈ømall alteration, according to the u≈øe of the ≈øeveral Dioce≈ø≈øes in ≈øeveral places.

div.head: THE OFFICE OF THE Over≈øeers of the Poor.
CHAP. I. Of the Antiquity of the≈øe Officers, of their Qualifications, and how, and when to be cho≈øen.
div.p: THo≈øe to be cho≈øen to this Office, ought to be ≈øub≈øtantial P ‚Ä¢ r≈øons, Men of Wi≈ødom and a good Con≈øcience; they mu≈øt be Hou≈øholders, for this Name and Office may be≈øeem the Be≈øt, and not the meane≈øt Men, (it being an Office of great Antiquity and Excellency;) For as God him≈øelf hath a ≈øpecial Re≈øpect to the Mi≈øeries of the Poor, ≈øo they be like God that provide for the Nece≈ø≈øities of the Poor, Dalt. J.P. 143.

The Over≈øeers of the Poor are to be cho≈øen yearly, and joyned with the Churchwardens of the Pari≈øh in the over≈øight and ordering of the Poor of the Pari≈øh. They are to be cho≈øen by two or more Ju≈øtices of the Peace, (one whereof to be of the Quorum) who are
yearly under their Hands and Seals at Ea≈øter, or within one Month after, to appoint four, three, or two ≈øub≈øtantial Hou≈øholders, according to the greatne≈øs of the Pari≈øh, to be joyned with the Churchwardens to look to the Poor of the Pari≈øh, Stat. 43 Eliz. c. 2. 21 J ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . c. 28.

The major part of the≈øe Officers, without the re≈øt of them, may do any thing belonging to their Office. But they are to have the allowance and con≈øent either in particular, or in general, of two Ju≈øtices of the Peace (Quor. unus) to every thing they do about their Office. And the≈øe Officers, or ≈øuch of them as ≈øhall not be let by ju≈øt excu≈øe (to be allowed by two Ju≈øtices) are to meet monthly in the Church, on Sunday after Evening Prayer, and there are to con≈øider of ≈øome meet directions about their Office, and they are to u≈øe all po≈ø≈øible diligence in their Office on pain to forfeit for every ≈øuch Default twenty ≈øhillings, 43 El. c. 2. Wing ‚Ä¢ tes Stat. Tit. Poor People.

And if it happen that Over≈øeers be not appointed according to the 4 ‚Ä¢
El. then every Ju≈øtice of Peace, or Head Officer of that Divi≈øion or Corporation ≈øhall forfeit 5 l. to be levied by a Se≈ø≈øions Warrant, and imployed to the u≈øe of the Poor of the Pari≈øhes where ≈øuch default is made, 43 El. c. 2. Wingates Stat. Tit. Po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ People.

div.head: CHAP. II. Of the ≈øeveral ≈øorts of Poor People, and what Poor the Over≈øeers are to provide for, and relieve, or to ≈øet to work.
div.p: THere are three ≈øorts or degrees of Poor, as fir≈øt, the Poor by Impotency and Defect, as the Aged and Decrepit that are pa≈øt their Labour; the Infant, Fatherle≈øs and Motherle≈øs, and not able to work; the Per≈øon naturally di≈øabled either in Wit or Member, as an Ideot, Lunatick, Blind, Lame, &c. not being able to work; and the Per≈øon vi≈øited with grievous Sickne≈øs or Di≈øea≈øe, though ca≈øually, yet thereby for the time being impotent. All the≈øe the Over≈øeers are to provide for, that they have nece≈ø≈øary Relief, and Allowances proportionable, and according to the continuance and mea≈øure of their Maladies and Needs, and of the≈øe it may be ≈øaid, Si non pavi≈øti, occidi≈øti, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 169.

Then ≈øecondly, The Poor by Ca≈øualty, as a Per≈øon ca≈øually di≈øabled or maimed in his Body, as the Soldier or Labourer, &c. maimed in their lawful Callings, the Hou≈øholder decayed by ca≈øualty of Fire, Water, Robbery, Sureti≈øhip, &c. and the poor Man over-charged with Children: All the≈øe (and ≈øuch like others) having Ability, and ≈øtrength of Body, but not ≈øufficient Means to maintain them≈øelves, are to be ≈øet to work by the Over≈øeers, and being not able to live by their Work, they are in Charity to be relieved in ≈øome rea≈øonable proportion, according
to their ≈øeveral Wants and Nece≈ø≈øities, D ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ J.P. c. 73. f. ibid.

Then la≈øtly, The thri≈øtle≈øs Poor, as the ri ‚Ä¢
tous and prodigal Per≈øon, that con≈øumes all wi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Play or Drinking, &c. the di≈ø≈øolute Per≈øon, as th ‚Ä¢ Strumpet, Pilferer, &c. the ≈ølothful Per≈øon th ‚Ä¢ refu≈øeth to work, &c. and the Vagabond th ‚Ä¢ will abide in no place or ≈øervice; and for all the ‚Ä¢ the Hou≈øe of Correction is the place where they are to be ≈øent to, and being of able Bodies, the ‚Ä¢ they are to be held to hard Labour, and to maintain them≈øelves by their Labour and Work, without charging the Town or County for any Allowance, 7 Jac. c. 4 Dalt. J.P. c. 73. fol. 170.

But it ≈øeemeth, that if any of the≈øe la≈øt ≈øo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Poor happen to prove impotent, and al≈øo „Äà‚óä„Äâ ca≈øes of manife≈øt extremity, then they are to be relieved by the Town, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. ibid.

If the Parents be able to work, and may have Work, they are to find their Children by thei ‚Ä¢ labour, and not the Pari≈øh; but if they be overcharged with Children, they may help, by having ≈øome of their Children put out Apprentices by the Over≈øeers, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 157.

The Father, Grandfather, Mother, Grandmother, and the Children and Grandchildren of every poor impotent Per≈øon not able to work, being of ≈øufficient Ability, ≈øhall relieve ≈øuch poor Per≈øons in ≈øuch manner, as the Ju≈øtices o ‚Ä¢ Peace of that County (where ≈øuch ≈øufficient Per≈øon dwelleth) at their General Quarter Se≈ø≈øion ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall A≈ø≈øe≈øs; and if ≈øuch Per≈øon refu≈øe to able the Order, they forfeit 20 s. for every mon ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ to the Poor of the Pari≈øh, which Forfeiture ‚Ä¢ s „Äà‚óä„Äâ be levied by the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers, or one of them, by Warrant from any two Ju≈øtices
of the Peace (Quor. unus) within their Limits, by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, and want of di≈øtre≈øs, any two ≈øuch Ju≈øtices may commit the Offender to pri≈øon, there to remain without Bail till the ≈øaid Forfeiture be paid, 43 El. 2. Re≈øol. Judges 16, 17. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 156.

But if a Man marry a Grandmother that hath no E≈øtate, the Grandfather in Law is not chargeable: But if ≈øhe hath an E≈øtate cau≈øed without ≈øuch Marriage, or that comes after Marriage by de≈øcent, or otherwi≈øe to her, here he may be charged: But where they have rai≈øed them≈øelves an E≈øtate by their own Indu≈øtry, there it is doubtful. But in no ca≈øe ≈øhall he be charged longer than his Wife lives; and it ≈øeems al≈øo Ba≈øtard Children are not within this Law, neither can the Ju≈øtices do any thing therein again≈øt a Man that lives out of their County. See Boul≈øt. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ p. 2 part, f. 245, 246, 247.

No Poor may beg but in their own Pari≈øh, and there by Licence of the Over≈øeers of the Poor; and they may not licence them to beg in the High-ways there, and without the Licence of the Over≈øeers they may not beg at all, Re≈ø. Judges 15. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 157. 39 El. 3.

No Inhabitants may ≈øerve any Poor at their Door, but tho≈øe of their own Pari≈øh, that have licence from the Over≈øeers of the Poor to beg there, under pain of 10 s for every time they do ≈øo, 1 Jac. 7. Dalt. J.P. c. 83. f. 20.

The≈øe Officers are to make provi≈øion for a poor Man that wants an Hou≈øe (but not for a common Herd≈øman or Sheperd) with con≈øent of the Lord of the Mannor fir≈øt had in writing under his Hand and Seal, either by them≈øelves, or with
a Se≈ø≈øions Order, may erect a Cottage upon any part of the Wa≈øte of a Mannor, and lodge Inmates therein, notwith≈øtanding the Stat. 31 El.
‚Ä¢ . But ≈øuch Cottage may not be afterwards employed otherwi≈øe than to lodge impotent Per≈øons there, for if it be, then it falls within the penalty of the 31 El. afore≈øaid, 43 El. c. 2 Wingates. Stat. Tit. Poor People.

All ≈øuch Per≈øons married or unmarried, having no Means to maintain them, u≈øing no ordinary and daily Trade of Life to get their Living by, and ≈øuch Per≈øons al≈øo as can get no Work, are to be ≈øet on Work by the Over≈øeers; and any one Ju≈øtice of Peace may ≈øend to the Hou≈øe of Correction, or Common Goal, ≈øuch as ≈øhall not imploy them≈øelves to work being appointed thereto by the Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor of the Pari≈øh, 43 El. c. 2. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 143.

And to this purpo≈øe the Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor may, by, and with the con≈øent of two or more Ju≈øtices of the Peace (Q ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r. unus) &c. Set up u≈øe, and occupy any Trade, My≈øtery or Occupation, only for the ≈øetting on Work, and better Relief of the Poor of the Pari≈øh, Town or Place where they are Over≈øeers, &c. 3 Car. 1 c. 4. Dalt. J P. c. 73. f. 148. Wingates Stat. Tit. Poor People.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Duty of the Over≈øeers about putting forth, and binding of Apprentices, with the Form of the Indenture for that purpo≈øe.
div.p: IN the putting out of Children Apprentices, there ought to be regard had to the Ma≈øter, the Child, and the Parents; Fir≈øt, to the Ma≈øter, that he be of Ability and Hone≈øty, otherwi≈øe by ≈øome device or hard intreaty they may provoke their Apprentices to depart or run away; and regard is al≈øo to be had to his Trade or Faculty, le≈øt the Apprentice con≈øume his time without learning any thing: Secondly, Regard is to be had to the Apprentices to put them out timely, and while they are young and tractable (≈øo that they be above the Age of ≈øeven years) otherwi≈øe by rea≈øon of their idle and ba≈øe Educations, they will hardly keep their Service, or imploy them≈øelves to work: Then la≈øtly, Regard is to be had to the Parents, to take away ≈øuch from them as are brought up to live idly and loo≈øly, or el≈øe ≈øuch as are a burthen and charge to their Parents, Dalt. J. P. c. 73. f. 150, 151.

The choice of the≈øe Apprentices, are to be out of the poore≈øt ≈øort of Children, who≈øe Parents are the lea≈øt able to relieve them, and they are to be above 7, and under 15 years of Age, when they are fir≈øt bound, 7 Jac. c. 3. Wingates Stat. Tit. Poor People.

And the≈øe Officers are to have the con≈øent of two Ju≈øtices of the Peace in the placing out of ≈øuch Apprentices; and they may bind the Man-child
till 24 years of Age, and the Woman-child till 21 years of Age, or till ≈øhe be married, which ≈øhall fir≈øt happen: And the≈øe Apprentices „Äà‚óä„Äâ be bound to Weavers, Ma≈øons, Dyers, Fullers, „Äà‚óä„Äâ any other Trade, as well as to Husbandry „Äà‚óä„Äâ Hou≈øewifery, See 43 El. c. 2. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 14 ‚Ä¢
Wingates Stat. Tit. Poor People.

Now this placing of Apprentices may be „Äà‚óä„Äâ any Man, whom the Officers and Ju≈øtices think „Äà‚óä„Äâ to receive them, within the ≈øame Pari≈øh or el ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
where in other Pari≈øhes within the ≈øame Hundred, either with, or without Mony; therefore it is fit in this ca≈øe to con≈øider, if the Child be young, and the Party to whom they place it is not very able, then they may give Mony, if they plea≈øe, as the Party and they ≈øhall agree, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Judges 1633. Que≈øt. 1.

All Men that-have, or may have u≈øe for Servants, as Knights, Clergy-men, Gentlemen, and Yeomen, as well as Trade≈ømen, are bound to take Apprentices; yea, though wealthy Men Table them≈øelves, or live ≈øo privately, that they have no u≈øe for a Servant, yet they may be compelled to take them, or el≈øe to pay a Sum of Mony for putting them Apprentices el≈øewhere; and if they refu≈øe to pay the Sum impo≈øed upon them, two Ju≈øtices of the Peace may make their Warrant to levy the ≈øame by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, Re≈ø. Judges 1633. Quest. 4. Po ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ . 24. Dalt. J P. c. 73. f. 151.

Or the Refu≈øers to take Apprentices, may be pre≈øented and indicted for the ≈øame, upon the Stat. 43 El. c. 2. at the A≈ø≈øizes or Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. ibid. Re≈ø. Judges 1633. Que≈øt. 7.

An Apprentice put to a Man in re≈øpect of his Farm, when his Lea≈øe expireth, the Apprentice ≈øhall go ≈øtill with the Farm, if the fir≈øt Ma≈øter be ≈øo plea≈øed; otherwi≈øe it is where an Apprentice is put to a Man in regard of his Ability, or for other Re≈øpects. And where any differences are between the Officers and the Man that is to receive an Apprentice, about Mony, and what Mony ≈øhall be given or otherwi≈øe, ‚Ä¢ here the Ju≈øtices thereabouts, or in their Defaults, the Se≈ø≈øions mu≈øt end it, Re≈ø. Judges 1633. Que≈øt. 2. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 151.

If the Parents of poor Children ≈øhall refu≈øe to let their Children be put forth Apprentices (without good cau≈øe ≈øhewed) ≈øuch Parents may be bound over, by the Ju≈øtices, to an≈øwer their ≈øaid Default, and if the Children ≈øhall refu≈øe, the Ju≈øtices may ≈øend them to the Hou≈øe of Correction, there to remain till they be content to be bound and ≈øerve, Dalt. J. P. c. 73. & 58. f. 153. & 119.

Note, That this binding mu≈øt be by Indenture, and may not well be done by a verbal Agreement; and the Indenture mu≈øt be either between the Ju≈øtices, Churchwardens and Over≈øeers, or them and the Apprentice on the one part, and him that takes the Apprentice of the other part, as appears by the Form of the Indenture in the end of this Chapter; and he mu≈øt be named by the Name of Apprentice expre≈øly, or el≈øe he is no Apprentice, though he be bound, Cromp. 184. Dalt. J.P. c. 5. f. 120.

And this binding is as effectual to all purpo≈øes, as if the Children were of full Age, and did bind them≈øelves by Indentures and Covenants; and all ≈øuch as are bound by the Over≈øeers, as
above≈øaid, may ≈øafely be received and kept „Äà‚óä„Äâ Apprentices by their Ma≈øters, 1 Jac. c. 25. „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Jac. c. 28. Dalt. J. P. c. 58. fol. 120. 3 Car. 1. c.
‚Ä¢ 5 El. c. 4. Cromp. 184. b.

Such Mony as is given to put out poor Children Apprentices, is to be employed in Corporate Towns, by the Corporations, and in other places by the Par≈øon or Vicar, together with the Con≈øtables Churchwardens, and Over≈øeers of the Poor, or the mo≈øt part of them; who ≈øhall „Äà‚óä„Äâ forbear to refu≈øe to employ the ≈øame accordingly, on pain to forfeit five marks, each o ‚Ä¢ them ≈øo making default, to be divided betwi ‚Ä¢ the Poor of the Pari≈øh and the Pro≈øecutor, 7 Jac. c. 3. Wingates Stat. Tit. Poor People.

The Party taking any Mony with ≈øuch Apprentice, ≈øhall give good Security by Obligation to repay it at the end of ≈øeven years next en≈øuing the date of the ≈øaid Obligation, or within the three months after the end of the ≈øaid ≈øeve ‚Ä¢ years; and if ≈øuch Apprentice ≈øhall die within ≈øeven years, then within one year after his or her death; and if the Ma≈øter, Mi≈øtre≈øs or Dame happen to die within the ≈øeven years, then within one year after their death; ≈øo as the Mony may be employed in placing the Apprentic ‚Ä¢ with ≈øome other of the ≈øame Trade, to ≈øerve out his time, at the di≈øcretion of the Parties tru≈øted as afore≈øaid, 7 Jac. c. 3.

And the Mony ≈øo given ≈øhall be imployed within three months after the Receipt thereof, and if there ≈øhall not be apt Per≈øons found in the places where it is given to the Apprentices, it ≈øhall then be imployed in the Pari≈øhes next adjoyning, by the Parties that are tru≈øted with it, in the place where it was ≈øo given, and
‚Ä¢ here al≈øo Bond ≈øhall be taken, as afore is declared, 7 Jac. c. 3.
If the Ma≈øter ≈øhall put his Apprentice into ‚Ä¢ pparel, it is a Gift in Law, and he cannot afterwards take it away, though he ≈øhould part with his Apprentice, Br. Tran≈øgr. 93.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Several Ca≈øes about Settlements, and al≈øo touching Ba≈øtards, &c.
div.p: TOuching ≈øettling of poor People, the Ju≈øtices are to meddle with none but tho≈øe who are impotent, and ≈øuch as are like to be chargeable to the place where they are Boul≈øt. Rep. 1 part, 347.

By 13 & 14 Car. 2. cap. 12. It is Enacted, that upon complaint by the Churchwardens, ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d Over≈øeers of the Poor, to any Ju≈øtice of ‚Ä¢ eace within forty days after any poor Per≈øon ‚Ä¢ ometh to ≈øettle in a Tenement under 10 l. ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ r annum, two Ju≈øtices of Peace, whereof one „Äà‚óä„Äâ be of the Quorum, may by Warrant remove ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch Per≈øon to the Pari≈øh where they were la≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ gally ≈øettled for forty days, unle≈øs they give ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ curity to be allowed by the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices for di≈øcharge of the Pari≈øh: Per≈øons aggrieved may ‚Ä¢ ppeal to the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions.

But Per≈øons having a Certificate from the ‚Ä¢ ini≈øter of the Pari≈øh, and one Churchwarden, ‚Ä¢ nd one Over≈øeer of the Poor, declaring them inhabitants there, may go into any Pari≈øh to ‚Ä¢ ork, and the not returning of ≈øuch Per≈øons, ‚Ä¢ hen their Work is fini≈øhed, or falling Sick whil≈øt they are at Work, ≈øhall not be accounted „Äà‚óä„Äâ Settlement: If any return to the Pari≈øh from ‚Ä¢ hence they are removed, a Ju≈øtice of Peace ‚Ä¢ ay ≈øend them to the Hou≈øe of Correction, to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e puni≈øhed as Vagabonds, or to a publick Work hou≈øe to be imployed in Labour: and if ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of any Pari≈øh to which any are removed, refu≈øe to re≈øolve them, and provide them Work, &c. a ‚Ä¢ u≈øtice of Peace may bind over ≈øuch Officers to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e A≈ø≈øizes or Se≈ø≈øions.

Churchwardens and Over≈øeers for the Poor ‚Ä¢ here any Ba≈øtard-Child ≈øhall be born, may ‚Ä¢ ize ≈øo much of the Goods and Profits of the ‚Ä¢ ands of the Putative Father and Lewd Mother, „Äà‚óä„Äâ two Ju≈øtices of Peace ≈øhall order towards ‚Ä¢ i≈øcharge of the Pari≈øh, to be confirmed at the ‚Ä¢ e≈ø≈øions: who may make an Order for the
Churchwardens, &c. to di≈øpo≈øe of the Goo ‚Ä¢ by ≈øale or otherwi≈øe as they ≈øhall think „Äà‚óä„Äâ and receive the Profits of ≈øo much of the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Lands, as ≈øhall be ordered by the Se≈ø≈øions.

The Poor in every Town-≈øhip or Village „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Lanca≈øhire, Che≈øhire, Darby≈øhire, York≈øhire, N ‚Ä¢
thumberland, Bi≈øhoprick of Durham, Cumberland and We≈øtmoreland ≈øhall be provided for in th ‚Ä¢ Town≈øhip and Village where they inhabit, „Äà‚óä„Äâ were la≈øt legally ≈øettled: And two or more over≈øeers ≈øhall be cho≈øen in every Town≈øhip &c. who ≈øhall execute all powers for the Belief of the Poor under the Penalties mentioned in 43 Eliz. c. 2.

This Act of 13 & 14 Car. 2. c. 12. was „Äà‚óä„Äâ continue no longer than to the end of the fir≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of the next Parliament, but revived by 1 Jac. 2. c. 17. to continue for ≈øeven years, an ‚Ä¢ to the end of the fir≈øt Se≈ø≈øion of the next Parliament.

And whereas poor Per≈øons at their fir≈øt coming to a Pari≈øh, do commonly conceal them≈øelves, the forty days intended by the ≈øaid Act to make Settlement, ≈øhall be accounted from the time of their deliveries of notice in wri ‚Ä¢
ing of their Hou≈øe of Abode, and the number of their Family, if they have any, to one of the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers of the Poo ‚Ä¢ of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, 1 Jac. 2. c. 17.

No Man but a Vagrant Begger, ought to be ≈øent out of any Pari≈øh to the place of his Birth or la≈øt Habitation; for if any refu≈øe to work in the Pari≈øh where he is ≈øettled, or to work for the Wages a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed, then he is by the Ju≈øtice ‚Ä¢ to be ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction, Co. 2
part In≈øt. fol. 730. 7 Jac. c. 4. Re≈øol. Judges 9. Dalt. ‚Ä¢ . P. c. 73. f. 157. 39 El. c. 4. 1 Jac. c. 7.

If a Scholar in the Univer≈øity, or in a Grammar School begin to be ≈øu≈øpect, he may be, or „Äà‚óä„Äâ he doth become impotent, and is like to ‚Ä¢ e a Charge to the Pari≈øh where he is, he mu≈øt ‚Ä¢ e ≈øent to his Parents if he have any, other
‚Ä¢ i≈øe to the place where he was la≈øt legally ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ttled before he came to School, Re≈ø. Judges 633. ≈øect. 32.

If one be Born, and live 20 years in A. and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ en go to B. and there live in a Hou≈øe and pay ‚Ä¢ is Rent, and after he come to C. and there Works 20 Weeks as a Labourer in a Quarry of ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ones, where he breaks his Back, and becomes ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ potent, and there is taken vagrant and beg
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ng, in this ca≈øe he mu≈øt be ≈øent to A. the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ace of his Birth, and there mu≈øt be provided
‚Ä¢ or, Re≈ø. Judges, 14 Car. 1.

If a Man that hath a Wife and Children, take „Äà‚óä„Äâ Hou≈øe in one Pari≈øh for a Year, and during ‚Ä¢ is time he is illegally forced out of his Po≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øion; then he takes an Hou≈øe as Inmate in another Pari≈øh, out of which he is put within two ‚Ä¢ r three days, and then not having any place „Äà‚óä„Äâ be in, he gets into a Barn in the third place, ‚Ä¢ nd there his Wife is delivered of another ‚Ä¢ hild: In this ca≈øe they are all to be ≈øent to the ‚Ä¢ ari≈øh out of which they were fir≈øt illegally ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ rced, Re≈øol. Judges 1633. ≈øect. 24.

One Born in D. left that place for the ≈øpace „Äà‚óä„Äâ 20 years, then lived in S. took an Hou≈øe and ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ id Rent, and left that place al≈øo ≈øix or ≈øeven ‚Ä¢ ears, and then came to L. in another County. ‚Ä¢ nd there was twenty Weeks, did Work, and
there became impotent, and did wander, at beg in the ≈øame place, and was taken as a Vagrant, and it was ordered he ≈øhould be pa≈ø≈øed and ≈øettled at D. where he was Born, by th ‚Ä¢ Judges at Worce≈øter A≈ø≈øizes, 14 Car. 1. Boul≈øt. Re ‚Ä¢
1 part, f. 375.

No Child under the Age of ≈øeven years ≈øha ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be adjudged a Rogue within the Stat. 39 El. c.
‚Ä¢ But it ≈øeems ≈øuch Children vagrant and beggin ‚Ä¢ mu≈øt be ≈øent and placed with the Father „Äà‚óä„Äâ Husband of the Wife; and if he be dead, the ‚Ä¢ with the Mother (where ≈øhe was born, or la ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ dwelt by the ≈øpace of one year) and ≈øuch Children, once thus ≈øettled or placed, mu≈øt the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ remain, and not be ≈øent from thence to the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ place of Birth, though after their Parents die or run away, or that the ≈øaid Children gro ‚Ä¢ above the Age of ≈øeven years, yea, though th ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øaid Children after beg, and prove vagrant i ‚Ä¢ the Town, for there they mu≈øt be ≈øet to labo ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ by the Over≈øeers of the Poor, Dalt. J.P. c.
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
f. 209.

But Children above ≈øeven years of Age, going about vagrant, or begging in the Cou ‚Ä¢
try, ≈øhall be puni≈øhed as Rogues, and ≈øent „Äà‚óä„Äâ their place of Birth, Dalt. J. P. ch. 83. f. 209.

The Wife being a Vagrant Rogue, mu≈øt be ≈øent to her Husband, though he be but a Servant in another Town; and where the Husband and Wife have an Hou≈øe, (though as an inmate) and either of them Rogue about, in this ca≈øe they are to be ≈øent to the place wher ‚Ä¢ the Hou≈øe is, Dalt. J. P. c. 83. fol. 209.

The Rogue, who≈øe place of birth or la≈øt dwelling cannot be known, having Wife and Children under ≈øeven years of Age, they mu≈øt go with the Husband to the place where they were la≈øt wilfully ≈øuffered to pa≈øs through without puni≈øhment, where the Children mu≈øt be ‚Ä¢ elieved by the Work of their Parents, though the Parents be committed to the Hou≈øe of Correction; and if the Rogue have Children above ‚Ä¢ even years of Age, that Rogue about with him, then they are to be ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction al≈øo with the Parents, and when they come out again, then to their ≈øeveral places of births, Dalt. J.P. c. 83. f. 206. and Shephards Guide
‚Ä¢ or J.P. pag. 252. Re≈ø. &c. b.

If I live in a Hou≈øe in A. there with my Children, but I work in B. where I am hired by the year, in this ca≈øe my Children ≈øhall be in A. but ‚Ä¢ f I have an Hou≈øe in B. they ≈øhall be placed ‚Ä¢ here, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 158.

A. being a Wanderer with three Children born in three Pari≈øhes, comes to Dale with them ‚Ä¢ o her Si≈øter, and there dieth ≈øhortly after, here the Children mu≈øt be ≈øettled in the ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes where they were born, and not in the Pari≈øh where the Mother died, Boul≈øt. Rep. 2 part, 351.

No Man is to be put out of the Town where he dwelleth, and is lawfully ≈øettled, nor to be ≈øent to his place of Bith, or la≈øt Habitation, but a Vagrant Rogue, not to be found by the Town, except the Party be impotent, but they ought to ≈øet them≈øelves to labour, if they be able and can get Work; and if they cannot get Work, then the Over≈øeers are to ≈øet them to work; and if in ≈øuch ca≈øe ≈øuch Per≈øons wander abroad
begging out of the Pari≈øh, then they may be ≈øent as Vagabonds (from the place where they ≈øhall be taken wandring or begging) to the place of their Birth, Dalt. J.P. c. 83. f. 209.

If a Maid Servant be gotten with Child at „Äà‚óä„Äâ by her Fellow-Servant (or by another Man o ‚Ä¢ the ≈øame Town) and after both their Service ‚Ä¢ ended, they Marry, and then the young Ma ‚Ä¢ is retained at B. and afterwards the Woman is delivered of her Child, in this ca≈øe ≈øhe with her Child are to be ≈øent to the Father at B. and there mu≈øt be ≈øettled, Dalt. J.P. c. 73 f. 159.

If any di≈øturbance be made to any Settlement lawfully ordered by the Ju≈øtices, either by the Con≈øtables refu≈øing to receive and convey a Rogue where they ought to do it, or by the Churchwardens and over≈øeers of the Poor in refu≈øing ≈øuch an one as is duly ≈øent to be ≈øettled there, in ≈øuch ca≈øe they forfeit 5 l. by the 39 El. c. 4.

If a Woman unmarried be hired Weekly, Monthly, half Year, or Yearly, in one Pari≈øh, and there be gotten with Child, and then goeth into another Pari≈øh, and there is ≈øettled in Service, or otherwi≈øe for two or three Months, and then ≈øhe is di≈øcovered to be with Child, is this ca≈øe ≈øhe and her Child ≈øhall be ≈øettled in the Pari≈øh where ≈øhe then is, and mu≈øt not be ≈øent to the Pari≈øh whence ≈øhe came, Re≈øol. Judge ‚Ä¢
1633. ≈øect. 12.

If a Woman be delivered of a Ba≈øtard Child in one Pari≈øh, and then go into another Pari≈øh with her Child, in this ca≈øe the Child after it is nur≈øed, is to be ≈øent to, and ≈øettled in the place where it was born, and not to remain with the Mother, Re≈øol. Judges 1633. ≈øect. 23.

If A. have a Ba≈øtard Child by B. born in Dalt, and the reputed Father marries another Woman, and they breed the Child 10 years in the Pari≈øh of Sale, and the Mother of the Child is in Service all this while, and a ≈øingle Woman, the reputed Father dies; in this ca≈øe the Child is to be ≈øent to the Mother fir≈øt, to be maintained by her, if ≈øhe be able, and if not, it mu≈øt be kept by the Pari≈øh of Salt, where it was ≈øettled with the Father 10 years, Boul≈øt. Rep. 2 part, fol. 350.

If a Woman have a Ba≈øtard Child, and is like to be chargeable to the Pari≈øh, and ≈øhe is ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction for it (as ≈øhe may be by Law) in this ca≈øe it hath been que≈øtioned whether the Child mu≈øt go with her, or remain in the Town where it was born, (or ≈øetled with the Mother) and there to be relieved by the Work of the Mother, or by Relief from the Reputed Father, upon the 18 El. and it ≈øeems mo≈øt rea≈øonable to be ≈øo; and yet the common opinion and practice is otherwi≈øe, (to wit) to ≈øend the Child with the Mother to the Hou≈øe of Correction: And this may al≈øo ≈øeem rea≈øonable where the Child ≈øucketh on the Mother, Dalt. J.P. c. 11. f. 41.

If a Woman with Child be ≈øent to the Hou≈øe of Correction, and there be delivered, the Child mu≈øt be ≈øent back to the Pari≈øh where the Woman came from, there to be relieved. Al≈øo if a Woman be travelling, and have her Child with her, and is apprehended and ≈øent to the Goal, and there hanged for Felony, in this ca≈øe the Child ≈øhall not be chargeable to the place where the Goal is, but to the place where it was born (if it can be known) otherwi≈øe to
the place where the Mother was apprehended and ≈øo was the opinion of Sir Nicholas Hi ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
3 Car. 1.

The two next Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) in „Äà‚óä„Äâ next to the Limits where the Pari≈øh Church „Äà‚óä„Äâ may take order as well for the puni≈øhment „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Mother, and reputed Father of a Ba≈øtard Child, as al≈øo for the Relief of the Pari≈øh wher ‚Ä¢ it is born, by charging the Mother and Father with the payment of Mony weekly toward the keeping of it, or otherwi≈øe: And if the Mother or Father perform not the Ju≈øtices order therein, they are to ≈øuffer Impri≈øonment without Bail, except he or ≈øhe give Security to perform, or el≈øe to appear at the next Se≈ø≈øions, and abide the order of the Ju≈øtices there, if any be made there; and if none be made, then to ≈øtand to the fir≈øt order, Dalt. J.P. c. 11. f.
‚Ä¢ . 18 El. c. 3.

Note, That this Order may be made by any two Ju≈øtices of the County (Quor. unus) as „Äà‚óä„Äâ held by ≈øome, but mo≈øt properly by the tw ‚Ä¢ next Ju≈øtices, and the que≈øtion mu≈øt be about ≈øuch a Ba≈øtard Child as is like to be a charge to the Pari≈øh; and the Security mu≈øt be given to the Pari≈øh where the Child is born, to ≈øecure the Pari≈øh from the charge of the Child, or to keep the Child: it mu≈øt be a Pari≈øh with in the County where the two Ju≈øtices have power, and the Order mu≈øt be certain how long the reputed Father mu≈øt keep the Child, ≈øecure the Pari≈øh, &c. and it mu≈øt be made again≈øt the Per≈øon that is ≈øu≈øpected to have gotten the Ba≈øtard Child, and not again≈øt another Per≈øon to contribute towards it, becau≈øe it was gotten in his Hou≈øe, &c. and the Order mu≈øt
expre≈øs the Child by the Name of a Ba≈øtard Child, and not the reputed Child of ≈øuch an one; and the Ju≈øtices for the better di≈øcovery of the Matter, may upon Oath examine the Mother her ≈øelf concerning the reputed Father, the time, &c. Dalt. J. P. c. 11. fol. 40. 18 Eliz. c. 3. 7 Jac. c. 4. See Steels Rep. fol. 154, 245, 246, 247, 388. and ≈øee Pridgeons Ca≈øe, Hill. 9 Car. 1. B.R. and Slaters Ca≈øe, Pa≈øch. 13 Car. 1. B.R. Cro. Rep. 1 part.

div.head: CHAP. V. The Over≈øeers Office in making of Rates, and pa≈ø≈øing Accounts.
div.p:
THE Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor, or the greater part of them (for the doing and performing of the things they have in charge) may rai≈øe weekly, or otherwi≈øe by Taxation of every Par≈øon, Vicar, and other Occupier of Land, Hou≈øe or Tithes, Colemines, or ≈øaleable Underwoods, within the Pari≈øh, Town, &c. ≈øuch a Sum as they ≈øhall think fit; and this Rate they mu≈øt have allowed and confirmed under the Hands of two Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) and then by Warrant from them, or any other two Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) they may levy by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Goods of the Party refu≈øing to pay the ≈øaid Tax, rendring the overplus to the Owners, and in default of Di≈øtre≈øs, two ≈øuch Ju≈øtices may commit the Party to pri≈øon, there to remain without Bail till he be di≈øcharged by him, 43 El.
ch. 2. Dalt. J. P. c. 73. f. 148. Wingates Stat. T ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Poor People.

Now the≈øe Rates ought to be well and tr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ made, according to Mens vi≈øible E≈øtates, real i ‚Ä¢ per≈øonal, within the place only, and not „Äà‚óä„Äâ any E≈øtate el≈øewhere; at Lincoln A≈ø≈øi≈øes, 9 Ca ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
by Ju≈øtice Hutton and Crook.

Note, That a Pari≈øh in Reputation, ≈øhall be Pari≈øh within this Law: ≈øo that if A. be ancient Pari≈øh that hath Officers in it, and the ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ be a Town within this Pari≈øh, which for a long time hath been u≈øed, and reputed as a Pari≈øh and hath all Parochial Rights, as Churchwardens, &c. here this place may be rated as t ‚Ä¢ Pari≈øh towards the Poor, Huttons Rep. fol. 93. „Äà‚óä„Äâ
M. 3 Car. B.R. Hilton & Pauls Ca≈øe, Cro. 3 p ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ Rep.

This Tax mu≈øt be ≈øet upon the Tenants and Occupiers of Lands; and not upon the La ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
lords Living within or without the Pari≈øh; „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Tenant only is chargeable for the Land, B ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢
≈øtrods 1 part, Rep. fol. 354.
The Par≈øon having a full tenth Part of the Profits of the Place, may be rated to a tenth Part Re≈øol. Judges 1633. ≈øect. 33.

He that doth occupy Lands in his own Hands lying in ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes, he mu≈øt be charged in every Pari≈øh for his Land lying therein, only according to the proportion thereof, and „Äà‚óä„Äâ more; but for his per≈øonal E≈øtate it ≈øeems rea≈øonable he ≈øhould be charged for it in the place where his Per≈øon is: All Lands Ancient Deme≈øn, Guildable and Copyhold, are to be charged with the≈øe Rates, which ought to be according to the value, or by the pound, and not according to the quantity, Sed con≈øuetud ‚Ä¢ tollit Legem.
The Rate for Stock or Goods is thought rea≈øonable to be ≈øet after the proportion of Lands, (viz.) an 100 pound in Stock to be rated after 5 or 6 pound a year in Land.

Note, That in ≈øome ≈øpecial Ca≈øes a Man may be rated beyond his Ability; as where one brings a Charge upon a Pari≈øh; or under any pretence brings in a Man that may be chargeable in a Pari≈øh, he may, if there be cau≈øe for this, be rai≈øed in his Rate to the full value of his E≈øtate; and ≈øo was the Opinion of Sir Nicholas Hide, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 167.

Where the Inhabitants of any Pari≈øh are not able to relieve their Poor, any two Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) may tax other Pari≈øhes and Places within the Hundred, yea, the whole Hundred, if need require; and where that is not ≈øufficient, the Ju≈øtices in their Se≈ø≈øions may tax the County in part, or wholly at their di≈øcretion, 43 El. c. 2. Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. Poor People, 14 Car. 2. c. 12.

If any Per≈øons find them≈øelves aggrieved in any Tax, or other-Act done by the Over≈øeers, or by the Ju≈øtices of Peace, they are to be relieved at the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 160. Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. Poor People.

The Father, Grandfather, Mother, Grandmother and Children of every poor Per≈øon, ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed towards their Relief, as the Ju≈øtices of the Peace in their Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace in the County where ≈øuch Father, &c. dwells, ≈øhall limit and appoint, on pain to forfeit 20 s. a month, to the u≈øe of the Poor, to be levied by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale as afore≈øaid, and for want of di≈øtre≈øs to be committed to Pri≈øon till the
Forfeiture be paid, 43 El. c. 2. Wingates „Äà‚óä„Äâ Stat. Tit. Poor People, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 1 ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ .

Head Officers in Cities and Corporate Towns and Aldermen of London, have in their ≈øevera ‚Ä¢ Precincts like Authority that Ju≈øtices of Peace have in their Counties, and no other Ju≈øtice ‚Ä¢ of Peace are to enter and intermeddle there Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. Poor People, 43 El. c. 2.

If any Pari≈øh ≈øhall extend into two Counties or part thereof to lie in any City or Corporate Town where they have Ju≈øtices: Then the Ju≈øtices of every County, &c. are to intermeddle only within their own Limits; and every of them re≈øpectively within their Limits are to execute this Law concerning the nomination of Over≈øeers, binding of Apprentices, granting Warrants to levy Taxations, taking Account of Over≈øeers, and committing ≈øuch as refu≈øe „Äà‚óä„Äâ account, or to pay their Arrearages; and yet the Over≈øeers ≈øhall without dividing them≈øelves, execute their Office in all places within the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, but ≈øhall give up Accounts to the Ju≈øtices, or Head Officers of both Places, Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. Poor People, 43 El. c. 2. Dalt J.P. c. 73. f. 156.

The≈øe Officers within four days after the end of their Year (and that other Officers are nominated) are to yield up a true Account to two Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) of the≈øe things following, 1. What Sums of Mony they have received, or rated and not received? 2. What ≈øtock of Ware or Stuff is in their Hands, or is the Hands of any of the Poor? 3. What Apprentices they have put out, and bound according to the Statute? 4. What Poor they have ≈øet to work or relieved? 5. What Poor
they have ≈øuffered to wander and beg out of their Town, or in the Highways, or in their Town without their directions? 6. Whether they meet monthly to con≈øider of the things belonging to their Office? 7. Whether they made their Rates indifferent upon all Men, according to their Ability? 8. Whether they have endeavoured to gather and levy ≈øuch A≈ø≈øe≈øsments? 9. Whether they have neglected the Ju≈øtices Warrants to them, or any of them directed for the levying of any Forfeiture according to the Stat. 43 El. c. 2. Dalt. J. P. c. 73. f. 153.

By the Statute of 30 Car. 2. for Burying in Woollen, the Ju≈øtices are not to allow the Accounts of the Over≈øeers of the Poor, until they have given them an Account of the Burials and Certificates, and of their levying the Penalties in pur≈øuance of that Act, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

Now if the Churchwardens, or Over≈øeers, or any of them, ≈øhall refu≈øe to make and yield a true and perfect Account to the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices, of all ≈øuch Mony, and of all ≈øuch Stock as afore≈øaid, any two Ju≈øtices (Quor. unus) may commit them to the common Gaol, there to remain without Bail, till they have made a true Account, and ≈øatisfied, and paid to the new Over≈øeers ≈øo much of the ≈øaid Sum or Stock, as upon the ≈øaid Account ≈øhall be remaining in his or their Hands, &c. And if they make a fal≈øe Account, they may be bound over to the A≈ø≈øizes or Se≈ø≈øions, and there an Indictment may be preferred again≈øt them, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 154.

Al≈øo if any of the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers ≈øhall refu≈øe, or deny to pay, or deliver over to the new Over≈øeers the Arrearages (Sums of Mony or Stock) which ≈øhall be in their Hands, and due, and behind upon their Account to be made as afore≈øaid, any two ≈øuch Ju≈øtices of Peace may make their Warrant to the pre≈øent and ≈øub≈øequent Churchwardens and Over≈øeers, or any of them, to levy the ≈øame by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods, rendring to the Parties the overplus, and in default of ≈øuch di≈øtre≈øs, any two Ju≈øtices of the Peace may commit him or them to the common Goal, there to remain without Bail, until payment or delivery of the ≈øaid Sum, Arrearages and Stock be made, 42 El. c. 2. Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 154.

If any ≈øuch Stock ≈øhall be in the Hands of any of the Poor to work, and ≈øuch Poor ≈øhall refu≈øe to deliver the ≈øame, two ≈øuch Ju≈øtices may make the like Warrant, to levy the ≈øame by di≈øtre≈øs, and for lack thereof, may commit ≈øuch Offenders to the Goal, as afore≈øaid, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. ibid.

And for the≈øe afore≈øaid, and all other Negligencies of the Churchwardens and Over≈øeers, in the Execution of their Office, about the Poor, &c. every of them, for every Default, he makes, forfeits 20 s. which Default mu≈øt be proved either by the Offenders own Confe≈ø≈øion, or by Examination of Witne≈ø≈øes, and it is to be levied by the new Churchwardens and Over≈øeers, or one of them, by Warrant from two Ju≈øtices, as afore≈øaid, by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Offenders Goods; and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, two ≈øuch Ju≈øtices may commit Offenders to the Goal, there to remain without Bail, till the
≈øaid Forfeitures ≈øhall be paid; which ≈øaid Forfeitures are to be imployed to the u≈øe of the Poor of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, Dalt. J.P. c. 73. f. 155. 43 El. c. 2.

div.head: CHAP. VI. The Over≈øeers Duty about Weights and Mea≈øures, and Burying in Woollen.
div.p: THere ≈øhall be one Weight, one Mea≈øure, and one Yard, according to the Standard of the Exchequer, throughout all the Realm, as well in places Priviledged, as without, and every Mea≈øure of Corn ≈øhall be ≈øtriked without Heap: And who≈øoever ≈øhall keep any other Weight, Mea≈øure, or Yard, whereby any Corn, Grain, or other thing is bought or ≈øold, ≈øhall forfeit for every Offence five ≈øhillings, being thereof convicted, by the Oath of one ≈øufficient Witne≈øs, before any Ju≈øtice of Peace, or Head-Officer of the City, Town, or Place where the Offence is done, to be levied by the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers of the Poor of the Pari≈øh, to the u≈øe of the Poor of the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of the Offenders Goods, and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, to be Impri≈øoned without Bail until payment. And all Per≈øons, upon Suit again≈øt him or them, for any thing done upon this Act, to plead the General I≈ø≈øue, and give the Act in Evidence, and to have treble Co≈øts, if unju≈øtly vexed, Dalt. J.P. c. 112. f. 246. 17 Car. 2. c. 19.

No Corps ≈øhall be buried in any thing other than what is made of Sheeps Wool only, or be put into any Coffin lined or faced with any thing made of any material but Sheeps Wool, on pain of the Forfeiture of five pounds, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

An Affidavit under the Hands and Seals of two Witne≈ø≈øes (or under the Hand of the Magi≈øtrate or Officer before whom it was ≈øworn, for which nothing ≈øhall be paid) mu≈øt be brought to the Mini≈øter within eight days after the Party is interred, that he was not buried contrary to this Act, which ≈øhall be taken before ≈øome Ju≈øtice of Peace, Ma≈øter of Chancery, Ordinary or Extraordinary, Mayor, Bailiff, or other chief Officer of the City, County, Borough, &c. where the Party was buried: And if no ≈øuch Affidavit be brought, the Mini≈øter ≈øhall give notice thereof under his Hand to the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers of the Poor, who within eight days after ≈øhall repair to the Chief Magi≈øtrate in any Town, &c. if buried there, el≈øe to a Ju≈øtice of Peace, who upon Certificate thereof from the Mini≈øter, &c. ≈øhall grant a Warrant for levying the Forfeiture by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of the Goods of the Party decea≈øed, or in default thereof, of the Per≈øons Goods in who≈øe Hou≈øe the Party died, or the Goods of any that had a Hand in putting ≈øuch Party into any Shroud, Coffin, &c. contrary to this Act, or that ordered the ≈øame: And if ≈øuch Per≈øon were a Servant, and died in the Ma≈øters Family, the Ma≈øters Goods to be liable: And if ≈øuch Per≈øon died in his Parents Family, the Parents Goods to be liable: One Moiety of which Forfeiture ≈øhall be to the Poor of the Pari≈øh
where the Party is buried, the other to him that ≈øhall ≈øue for the ≈øame, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

Mini≈øters, Churchwardens, and Over≈øeers, Ju≈øtices of Peace, or Chief Magi≈øtrates, neglecting their Duty afore≈øaid, ≈øhall forfeit five pounds for every Offence, to be recovered by Action of Debt, Bill, Plaint, &c. wherein the Pro≈øecutor ≈øhall recover his full Co≈øts, ≈øo as the Suit be commenced, within ≈øix months after the Offence committed; one fourth part of the Forfeitures to the King; two fourth parts to the Poor of the Pari≈øh where the Offender dwells; and one fourth part to the Informer, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

Every Mini≈øter ≈øhall keep a Regi≈øter of all Burials and Affidavits: And where no Affidavit is brought as afore≈øaid, ≈øhall enter a Memorial thereof again≈øt the Name of the Party interred, and of the time when he notified the ≈øame to the Churchwardens or Over≈øeers of the Poor. And the Over≈øeers when they give up their Accounts at the Se≈ø≈øions, or to any two Ju≈øtices at their monthly Meetings, ≈øhall give an account of the Name and Quality of every Per≈øon interred ≈øince their former Account; and of ≈øuch Certificates, and of their levying the Penalties, and of their di≈øpo≈øal thereof, on pain of five pounds to be levied by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of Goods, by Warrant from the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices, or two of them: and their Accounts ≈øhall not be allowed till they have accounted for their Burials, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

No Penalty ≈øhall be incurred where the Party died of the Plague: If any Per≈øon be pro≈øecuted, for what he ≈øhall do in pur≈øuance to this Act, he may plead the General I≈ø≈øue, and give this
Act in Evidence: And upon a Non≈øuit, Di≈øcontinuance or Verdict for him, or Judgment upon a Demurrer, he ≈øhall have treble Co≈øts, 30 Car. 2. c. 3.

And now by the Statute of 32 Car. 2. (where no Ju≈øtice of Peace ≈øhall re≈øide, or be to be found in any Pari≈øh where any Party ≈øhall be interred) ≈øuch Oaths or Affidavits may be admin≈øtred, not only by ≈øuch Magi≈øtrates as afore≈øaid, but by any Par≈øon, Vicar, or Curate in the ≈øame County, other than of the Pari≈øh or Chappel of Ea≈øe where the Party is interred; and they are to atte≈øt the ≈øame under their Hands gratis, 32 Car. 2. c. 1.
The Over≈øeers Duty about Iri≈øh Cattel, See Duty of Con≈øtables, ch. 8.
Their Duty in ≈øuppre≈ø≈øing Conventicles, See Duty of Con≈øtables, ch. 9.

Note, That the Over≈øeers of the Poor, are to receive for the u≈øe of the Poor of the Pari≈øh where the Offence is committed, of ≈øuch who kill, or take in the night-time any Conies upon the Borders of Warrens, or other Grounds lawfully u≈øed for keeping of Conies, except Owners, &c. or Per≈øons by them imployed, and of ≈øuch who u≈øe Snares, Harepipes, or other like Engines, or who take any Fi≈øh by any Net, Angle, or other Device what≈øoever, in any Water or River, or ≈øhall be a≈ø≈øi≈øting thereunto, without con≈øent of the Lord, or Owner of the ≈øaid Water, what Sum the Ju≈øtice of Peace before whom ≈øuch Offender ≈øhall be convicted, ≈øhall think meet, not exceeding ten ≈øhillings (which he is to pay over and above recompence to the Owner:) And in default of payment thereof, he that takes or kills ≈øuch
Conies, or u≈øeth Snares, &c. ≈øhall be committed to the Hou≈øe of Correction for any time not exceeding one month: And the Goods of him that takes ≈øuch Fi≈øh ≈øhall be liable to di≈øtre≈øs; and for want of a Di≈øtre≈øs, he ≈øhall be committed to the Hou≈øe of Correction, for any time not exceeding one month, unle≈øs he enter into Bond with one or more Sureties to the Party injured, not exceeding ten pounds, never to offend in like manner, 22 and 23 Car. 2. c. 24.

div.head: A GUIDE FOR SURVEYORS OF High-ways and Bridges.
CHAP. I. How many Sorts of Ways there are; of the Choice of the≈øe Officers, with ≈øome few General Ca≈øes concerning Highways.
div.p:
THere are three kind of Ways; Fir≈øt, A Foot-way, called Iter, quod e≈øt jus eundi, vel ambulandi hominis. Secondly, a Foot-way and an Hor≈øe-way, called actus, ab agendo, and this vulgarly is called a Pack or Drift-way, and is both a Foot-way and Hor≈øe-way. Thirdly, A Cart-way, &c. called Via or Aditus, (and containeth the other two, and a Cart-way al≈øo) for this is jus eundi, vehendi, & vehiculum &
jumentum ducendi; and this is two-fold, viz. Via Regia, The Kings High-way for all Men, & communis Strata, belonging to a City or Town, or between Neighbours.

It is called the Kings High-way, for that the King at all times hath therein Pa≈ø≈øage for Him≈øelf and his People, and may puni≈øh all Nu≈øances therein, though otherwi≈øe the Intere≈øt be in the Lord to bring his Action for digging therein, or other like Tre≈øpa≈øs there done, Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 101. and ≈øee Rolls Ca≈øes, 1 part f. 392. 2 E. 4. 9. 8 E. 4. 9. 17 E. 3. f. 43. Bro. Chemine, 10, 11. & Leet 3. 27 H. 6. f. 9. 8 H. 7. f. 5.

The High-way is not only the Common Tract, where Carts, Carriages, and People have gone; but if the Way be Foundrous, that People cannot pa≈øs in the Common Tract, and there be Out-lets out of it, into the Soil of another adjoyning, the People may in ≈øuch extremity u≈øe tho≈øe Out-lets upon anothers Soil, although it be ≈øowen with Corn: And that is, in ≈øuch ca≈øe, the Kings High-way as well as the other; for the Kings Subjects mu≈øt have a convenient Pa≈ø≈øage, as was re≈øolved in a Try ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ at Bar again≈øt Sir Henry Du ‚Ä¢ comb, Tr. 10 Car. Rolls 1 part of Abridgment, fol. 390. Therefore where a Way goes through a Mans Land, and the Owner of the Land Fence it on both ≈øides, he, by ≈øo doing, hath made him≈øelf liable to repair the High-way, and keep it pa≈ø≈øable; and it is not ≈øufficient for him to keep it in as good repair, as it was at the time of the Inclo≈øure; for by ≈øo doing he hath ≈øtraitned the High-way, Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 98.

The Con≈øtables and Churchwardens of every Pari≈øh ≈øhall yearly, upon Tue≈øday or Wedne≈øday in Ea≈øter Week, call together a number of the Pari≈øhioners, and then make choice of two of the Pari≈øh to be Surveyors of the High-ways the Year following, who ≈øhall forthwith take that Office upon them, on pain to forfeit twenty ≈øhillings a piece, 2 & 3. Ph. & Mar. c. 8.

The Con≈øtables and Churchwardens are then al≈øo to appoint ≈øix days betwixt that and the four and twentieth day of June, for the amendment of the High ways, and to give publick notice thereof in the Church the next Sunday after, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 8. & 5 El. c. 13.

High-ways mu≈øt be ≈øufficiently amended at the charge of the whole Town: And it is not enough for the Inhabitants to do their full ≈øix days work yearly; except their Ways be all well and ≈øufficiently repaired thereby: For if all their ≈øaid Ways be not ≈øufficiently amended, the whole Town may be indicted therefore, and if ≈øix days work in the year will not ≈øerve ‚Ä¢ o amend them, the Surveyors may, yea, mu≈øt appoint more days, Dalt. P.J. c. 50. f. 101.

The Owner of Lands, if he be not the Occupier thereof, ought not to be charged towards the repair of the common High ways; but the Tenant who occupies the Lands is to be charged Bill. 1 ‚Ä¢
Car. 1. Br. in one Fo≈øters Ca≈øe, per Curiam, Roells Ca≈øes, 1 part, f. 390.

All Fines and Forfeitures a≈ø≈øe≈ø≈øed in the Se≈ø≈øions, upon the Statute 5 El. about High-ways, mu≈øt be E≈øtreated by the Clerk of the Peace, and mu≈øt be levied, accounted, and imployed as i ‚Ä¢ appointed by the 2 & 3 Ph. & Mar. c. 8. 5 El. c. 13.

The Surveyors upon Warrant from two Ju≈øtices of Peace, are to levy by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of Goods, the Forfeitures of all ≈øuch Per≈øons as offend again≈øt the 18 El. 10. in not Scowring their Ditches, &c. and if they neglect by the ≈øpace of a year after the offence committed, to levy the Forfeiture; Then the Ju≈øtices may ≈øend to the Con≈øtable and Churchwardens to levy the ≈øame, 18 El. c. 10.

By the Stat. 22 Car. 2. c. 12. All Con≈øtables and Surveyors of the High-ways ≈øhall put in execution the Statutes for repairing and inlarging High-ways, and levy the Penalties thereby impo≈øed. And every Con≈øtable or Surveyor of the High-ways neglecting ≈øo to do, or wilfully ≈øuffering any Waggons or Carts to pa≈øs through his Limits, with any more Hor≈øes or Cattel, or in any other manner than this Act alloweth, upon Conviction thereof by one Oath before one Ju≈øtice, or the Ju≈øtices own view, ≈øhall pay ≈øuch Fine (not exceeding 40 s.) as ≈øuch Ju≈øtice ≈øhall A≈ø≈øe≈øs.
All Actions brought again≈øt any Per≈øon for acting by this Law, ≈øhall be laid in the proper County, and Defendants may plead the General I≈ø≈øue, and recover treble Co≈øts.

No travelling Waggon, Cart, &c. in which any Burdens ≈øhall be carried, (except Carts u≈øed about Husbandry, and carrying Hay, Straw, Co ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ unthra≈øhed, Coal, Chalk, Timber for Shipping or Building, Stones of all ≈øorts, Ammunition or Artillery for the King) ≈øhall be drawn, or go in any Road or publick High way, with above five Hor≈øe-bea≈øts at length, and if any draw with more Hor≈øes or Oxen, he ≈øhall draw all two „Äà‚óä„Äâ brea≈øt, except one Hor≈øe.

The Surveyor, where any neglect to come ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d labour, ≈øhall complain thereof to the next ‚Ä¢ u≈øtices, who upon Oath of one Witne≈øs, ≈øhall ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ vy for every days labour neglected 18 d. and ‚Ä¢ or every Man and Hor≈øe 3 s. and for every Cart with two Men 10 s. for each day neglecting, „Äà‚óä„Äâ
Car. 2. c. 12.

div.head: CHAP. II. The Duty of the Surveyors about Setting and Calling the Pari≈øhioners to the common days Works for the High-ways, and about taking and diging for Gravel, Chalk, Sand, &c.
div.p:
THe≈øe Officers are to ≈øee that the Pari≈øhioners do their Work on the days appoint
‚Ä¢ d, and that according to the≈øe Rules following, viz. Every Per≈øon having in his own Occupa
‚Ä¢ ion a Plough Land in Tillage, or in Pa≈øture in ‚Ä¢ he ≈øame Pari≈øh, or keeping there a Plough or ‚Ä¢ raught, ≈øhall find and ≈øend on every day to ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ e place appointed by the Surveyors, one ‚Ä¢ ain or Cart provided, after the Fa≈øhion of ‚Ä¢ he Country, with Oxen, &c. fit for the Carri
‚Ä¢ ge, and with nece≈ø≈øary Tools fit for the Work, ‚Ä¢ nd with two able Men, who are there to do ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ch Work with their Wains, &c. as they ≈øhall ‚Ä¢ e appointed (by the Surveyors) by the ≈øpace
of eight hours every of the ≈øaid ≈øix days, on pain of 10 s. every day default is made, 2, 4 P. M. c. 8. Ra≈øtall. 199. Lamb. 459. Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. High-ways, Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 102.

And every other Hou≈øholder, Cottager, and Labourer of the Pari≈øh, Town, &c. (able to labour, and being no hired Servant by the year) mu≈øt by him≈øelf, or ≈øome other able Man, be then and there ready to work every of the ≈øaid ≈øix days, by the ≈øpace of eight hours, as afore≈øaid, where they ≈øhall be appointed by the Surveyors, under pain to forfeit 12 d. for every day they make default, 2, 3 P. M. c. 8.

Note, That all Per≈øons being chargeable but as Cottagers, by the 2 & 3 P. M yet if they be in Sub≈øidy 5 l. in Goods, or 40 s. in Lands, or above, they mu≈øt find two able Men to work every of the ≈øaid ≈øix days, 18 El. c. 10. Wingates Abr. Stat Tit. High-ways.

If any of the Carriages ≈øhall not be thought needful by the ≈øaid Surveyors upon any of the ≈øaid days, they may appoint in≈øtead of a Team, two able Men to work as afore≈øaid, who ≈øhall not fail on pain that the Party that ≈øhould ≈øend them, ≈øhall forfeit 12 pence for every day that either of them make default, Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. High-ways, 2, 3 P. M. c. 8. Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 100.

He that ≈øhall occupy a Plow-land in Tillage or Pa≈øture, lying in ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes, ≈øhall be chargeable only in the Pari≈øh where he dwelleth; and he that occupieth ≈øeveral Plow-lands in ≈øeveral Pari≈øhes, ≈øhall be charged in each Town or Pari≈øh where ≈øuch Land lieth (to wit) to find in each Town or Pari≈øh one Cart furni≈øhed
as afore≈øaid, though he be no Inhabitant there, 10 El. c. 18. Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f 99.

Now for the further opening of the≈øe things, note, That it is ≈øaid, that a Plow-land is not of any certain Contents, but ordinarily it is ≈øo much as one Plough may Plough in one day, which in ≈øome Countries is more, and in ≈øome le≈øs, according to the heavine≈øs of the Soil, Co. 9 Rep. f. 124. Co. on Lit. f. 69. & vide Lamb. ver. Hide 35 H. 6. f 29.

And note, That a Plow-land, or Carve of Land may contain Hou≈øe, Meadow, Pa≈øture and Wood: And if one have ≈øo much of this as will keep a Plough, and yield Tillage for it, if part of it were cared, in this ca≈øe it ≈øeems he is to ≈øend his Plough, Vide Co. 4 Rep f. 3 ‚Ä¢ . b. & 9 Rep. f. 122.

He that hath a Plough land, and no Plough, but doth ≈øuffer his Land to lie fre≈øh, yet he is to ‚Ä¢ nd a Plough for this Work; and ≈øo it hath been agreed by the Judges, Mich. 21 Jac. Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 105.

He that keepeth a Plough, or Draught for Carriage, although he occupieth little or no Land, ‚Ä¢ ut carrieth or plougheth for other Men, yet it ≈øeems he is to ≈øend his Cart to the High-ways; and if a Man keep only two Hor≈øes and a Cart for his own Bu≈øine≈øs, in this ca≈øe it ≈øeems he is to come with his Cart and two Hor≈øes, with a Man ‚Ä¢ o manage them, Vide Dalt J.P. c. 50. ibid.

It is held by ≈øome, that ≈øo many Ploughs or ‚Ä¢ aughts Men have, and u≈øe frequently about their own Bu≈øine≈øs in Summer, ≈øo many they are to bring with them to the High-ways; ≈øo that ‚Ä¢ f a Man have one Plough and five or ≈øix Hor≈øes, and ≈øhall Plough ≈øeven or eight ≈øcore Acres of ‚Ä¢ and, and ≈øhall u≈øually go in the Summer time
with two Carts or Draughts; in this ca≈øe it ≈øeems he is to come with two Carts or Draughts to this Service: And he that occupieth 40 or 50 Acres of Land, and keepeth only three Hor≈øes, and one Draught or Cart, he is to come with one Draught or Cart, Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 105.

The≈øe Officers may, if they ≈øee cau≈øe, for the amendment of the High-ways, take and carry away ≈øo much of the Rubbi≈øh, and ≈ømalle≈øt broken Stones already digged, of any Mans Quarry lying within the ≈øame Pari≈øh, without leave of the Owner, as they ≈øhall think needful, or gather the loo≈øe Stones lying di≈øper≈øed in any Mans Grounds; but they may not without Licence dig in any Mans Quarry for new Stones, nor take the great Stones already digged; and if there be no ≈øuch Rubbi≈øh to be found in any Mans Quarry within the ≈øaid Pari≈øh, then may they enter into any Mans ≈øeveral Ground within the Pari≈øh, lying near the place where the Ways are decayed, and there (if they ≈øee any hopes of finding Materials fit for the Reparation thereof) without leave of the Owner, they may dig for Sand, Stones, Gravel, &c. ≈øo that it be not in the Hou≈øes, Gardens, Orchards, or Meadows of any Man; for they are not to come there without Licence of the Owner; and in ≈øuch place ‚Ä¢ where they may dig without leave, they are not to make a Pit above ten yards in breadth, c ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ length, and they are to take care that the place ‚Ä¢ be filled up again at the charge of the Pari≈øh within one month after, upon pain to forfei ‚Ä¢ five Marks to the Owner of the Ground, to be ‚Ä¢ recovered by Action of Debt; and this by th ‚Ä¢ 5 El. c. 13.

div.head: CHAP. III. The Surveyors Duty about cutting down Bu≈øhes, Trees, and ≈øcouring of Ditches in the High-ways; and al≈øo touching Pre≈øentments and Inquiries about Defaults, pa≈ø≈øing of Accounts, Travelling of Wagons, Wains, &c.
div.p: IF the Owners of the Grounds, next adjoyning to the High-ways, do not keep their Hedges low, and cut down their Trees and Bu≈øhes growing in the ≈øame ways, they forfeit ten ≈øhillings, Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. High-ways, 5 El. c. 13. 18 El. c. 10.

And he that ≈øcours not his Ditches in the Ground next adjoyning to the Ground that is next the High-ways, to the end the Water may have the better pa≈ø≈øage out of the High-ways, ≈øhall forfeit 12 pence for every Rod ≈øo left un≈øcoured, 18 E. c 10. Wingate, ut ≈øupra.

If any ≈øcour his Ditch by the High-way ≈øide, and throw the ≈øcouring thereof into the High-way, and ≈øuffer it to lie there ≈øix months, he forfeits for every Load thereof 12 pence; and the Surveyors are to make Sluces where ≈øuch Banks have been heretofore made, for carrying away the Water out of the High-way, 18 El. c. 10.

Every Surveyor may cau≈øe any Water-cour≈øe, or Spring of Water in the High-way, (within their Pari≈øh) to be turned into another Mans ≈øeveral Ditch or Ground next adjoyning to the ≈øaid Way, in ≈øuch manner as by the di≈øcretion of the ≈øaid Surveyor ≈øhall be thought meet, Dalt. J. P. c. 50. f. 103.

Note, That the Forfeitures of the Act of the 18 El. c. 10. mu≈øt be levied by the Surveyors for the time being, (by Warrant from the ‚Ä¢ u≈øtice ‚Ä¢ before whom the Party ≈øhall be convict) by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of Goods; which Forfeitures are to be employed towards the amendment of the High-ways; and if the Surveyors neglect to do it within one year after the Offence committed‚ñ™ then the Con≈øtables and Churchwardens by like Warrant may do it, 18 El. c. 10. Wingates Ab ‚Ä¢ . Stat. Tit. High-ways.

The Surveyors, or one of them, are to pre≈øent to the next Ju≈øtice of Peace every Default upon the 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 8. & 5 El. c. 14. within one month after it ≈øhall be made, on pain o ‚Ä¢ 40 s. and the Ju≈øtice is on pain of 5 l to certifie the ≈øame at the next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, where the Ju≈øtices have power to inquire of the Default, and ≈øhall ≈øet ≈øuch Fine upon the Delinquents, as they, or two of them (Quor. unus) ≈øhall think fit, 5 El. c. 13.

That the Pre≈øentment of a Ju≈øtice of Peace in Se≈ø≈øions, upon his own Knowledge ≈øhall be „Äà‚óä„Äâ good Conviction, whereupon the Ju≈øtices in Se ‚Ä¢
≈øions, or any two of them (Quor. unus) may a≈ø≈øe≈ø ‚Ä¢ a Fine, as well as upon a Verdict of twelve Me ‚Ä¢ but in this ca≈øe the Delinquent ≈øhall be admitted to his Traver≈øe, as in other Ca≈øes, 5 El. c. 13 vide Ra≈øtal. 199.

The Defaults and Offences upon the≈øe Statute 2 & 3 P. & M. 5 El. & 18 El. are inquitable by the Ju≈øtices of Peace in their Se≈ø≈øions, or by Stewards in Leets, either of which have powe ‚Ä¢ to ≈øet Fines upon Offenders at their di≈øcretions; of which Fines, indented E≈øtreats ( „Äà‚óä„Äâ the Se≈ø≈øions under the Hand and Seal of th ‚Ä¢
Clerk of the Peace, in the Leet, under the Hand and Seal of the Steward) ≈øhall be delivered within ≈øix weeks after Michaelmas, one part of the E≈øtreat to the Bailiff or High Con≈øtable of the Liberty, and the other part to the Con≈øtables and Churchwardens of the Pari≈øh where the Offenders live, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 8. 5 El. c. 13. 18 El. c. 10. Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. High-ways.
