And the≈øe E≈øtreats ≈øhall be a ≈øufficient Warrant for the Bailiff, or Chief Con≈øtable of the liberty to levy the ≈øaid Offences by way of Di≈øtre≈øs; and if no Di≈øtre≈øs can be found, or the Party do not pay the Fine within 20 days after ‚Ä¢ awful demand thereof, he or they ≈øhall forfeit double ≈øo much; all which Fines and Forfeitures are to be employed, and be≈øtowed towards the amendment of the High-ways in the Pari≈øh where the Offences are committed, Wingates Abr. Stat. Tit. High-ways, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 8.

The Bailiff, or High Con≈øtable, ≈øhall yearly betwixt the fir≈øt of March, and la≈øt of April, render ‚Ä¢ o Account unto the Con≈øtables and Churchwardens, who have the other parts of the E≈øtreats of the Fines, of what Mony they have received, on pain of 40 s. and the ≈øaid Con≈øtables and Churchwardens have power to call the ‚Ä¢ ailiff or High Con≈øtable before two or more ‚Ä¢ u≈øtices of the Peace (Quor. unus) to pa≈øs his Account, who have power to commit him, until he have ≈øatisfied all the Arrearages by him received, ≈øave 8 d. in the pound for his own Fee, ‚Ä¢ od 12 d. in the pound for the Clerk of the Peace, or Steward of the Leet, and in this ca≈øe the ≈øucceeding Con≈øtables and Churchwardens have ‚Ä¢ e ≈øame power as their Predece≈ø≈øors had, 2 & 3 ‚Ä¢ . & M. c. 8.

Two Ju≈øtices of the Peace by the Stat. 18 El. may take Accounts of the Surveyors of the Ways, and the Petty Con≈øtables and Churchwardens, for ≈øuch Forfeitures (within that Statute) as they have levied, 18 El. c. 10 Dalt. J.P. c. 50. f. 103.

Note, There are ≈øeveral Statutes which concern particular High-ways, in which the≈øe Surveyors are little concerned; I ≈øhall therefore only name the Statutes, and they who de≈øire to be further informed therein, may look the Statutes at large.

Stat. 39 El. c. 10. for repairing the High-ways in the Wild of Su≈ø≈øex, Surry and Kent, u≈øed for Iron Works. Stat. 37 H 8. c. 3. For Huntingto ‚Ä¢ Lane near to Che≈øter. Stat. 14 H 8. c. 6. & 26 H. 8. c. 7. For laying out new High-ways in the Wild of Kent or Su≈ø≈øex. Stat. 1 P. & M. 2. c. 5. for the Cau≈øway between Dorche≈øter and Sherborn. Stat. 18 El. c. 10. about the Kings Ferry in Kent.

div.head: CHAP. IV. Some Heads of the Stat. 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17. concerning the Ways, Sewers, Pavements, &c. in London, and the Scavengers Office.
div.p:
BY the Stat. of 22 & 23 Car. 2. A Clau≈øe ≈øo a late Act of Parliament, Entituled, A ‚Ä¢ Act for Rebuilding the City of London; wherein was Enacted, That the Numbers and Places for Common Sewers, Drains and Vaults, and the manner of Paving and Pitching Streets and Lanes in the ≈øaid City and Liberties, ≈øhould be ≈øet ou ‚Ä¢ by Per≈øons appointed by the Mayor, Aldermen,
and Common Council, or ≈øeven or more of them, together with the Surveyors, or one of them within the Precincts re≈øpectively, which Per≈øons, or ≈øeven, or more of them were impowred to impo≈øe Taxes upon Hou≈øes in proportion to the benefit they receive thereby, and to levy the ≈øame by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of Goods, is made perpetual, together with the Powers thereby given and appointed to be executed: And the ≈øole Powers of ordering and regulating the keeping clear, pitching and paving the Streets, Lanes and Pa≈ø≈øages, with the manner thereof, and of making and clean≈øing Drains and Sewers in London, is to remain in the Mayor, Commonalty, and Citizens, to be executed by ≈øuch as the Mayor, Aldermen and Commons in Common Council ≈øhall appoint, or ≈øeven or more of them being all Members of the ≈øaid Court. And Per≈øons imployed in any of the ≈øaid Works, are enjoyned to ob≈øerve the Directions of the Per≈øons in that behalf authorized, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

Offenders may be proceeded again≈øt by Indictment at the next Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace, in the ≈øaid City and Liberties, unle≈øs they ≈øubmitted to the Cen≈øure of the Per≈øons ≈øo authorized, or any ≈øeven or more of them, and pay the Mulct by them impo≈øed to the Chamber of London, to be imployed towards the Works in this Act mentioned, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

The Per≈øons ≈øo authorized may impo≈øe Taxes on the ≈øeveral Wards and Precincts, and direct Precepts to the re≈øpective Deputies and Common Council Men to a≈ø≈øe≈øs the ≈øame, and like Precepts to Scavengers to collect the ≈øame: And
where any Church or Churchyard ≈øhall front or adjoyn to any of the ≈øaid Streets, Lanes or Pa≈ø≈øages, they may a≈ø≈øe≈øs a rea≈øonable proportion upon the Pari≈øh to be paid by the Churchwardens, of which A≈ø≈øe≈øsments the Deputies and Common Council Men ≈øhall return Duplicates with the Scavengers Names, within twenty days after receipt of the Precepts. And in default of the ≈øaid Deputies, and Common Council Men the ≈øaid Per≈øons to be authorized may rate the ≈øaid A≈ø≈øe≈øsments. And in default of payment within ≈øix days after demand, the Scavengers may levy the ≈øame by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of Goods, rendring the overplus, be≈øides the rea≈øonable Charge of di≈øtraining: And the Mony ≈øo collected ≈øhall be paid into the Chamber of London, not to be i≈ø≈øued thence, but by order of the ≈øaid Per≈øons ≈øo to be appointed, or ≈øeven or more of them, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

Inhabitants aggrieved through defect or decay of Pavements, or want of clean≈øing the Streets, &c. ≈øhall upon proof that ≈øuch grievance is unreformed, receive directions from the Per≈øons ≈øo to be authorized, or ≈øeven or more of them, for redre≈ø≈øing the ≈øame, and a Warrant under their Hands and Seals to the Chamberlain of London to i≈ø≈øue Monies for defraying the Charge thereof, together with any Sum not exceeding ten ≈øhillings for encouragement of his or their Diligence, who upon receipt of ≈øuch Warrant ≈øhall pay the ≈øame accordingly: And Per≈øons aggrieved by any Charge impo≈øed by virtue of this Act, within five days after demand thereof, may appeal to the Mayor and Court of Aldermen, who≈øe Order therein ≈øhall be final, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

The Mayor, Aldermen and Commons in Common Council may ≈øet out and purcha≈øe Ground for Lay≈øtals, and places for publick Stores, for receipt of Dirt and Rubbi≈øh carried out of the City, and for other Materials and Commodities. The Mony for the ≈øame to be paid out of the Monies ari≈øing by the Impo≈øition upon Coals appointed for publick U≈øes of the City, other than the Mony appointed for Building Churches, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

No Per≈øons by this Act made liable to be rated towards the altering, mending, or clean≈øing the ≈øaid Vaults, Sewers, &c. or clean≈øing, &c. Streets, Lanes, &c. ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe charged or liable thereunto, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 17.

div.head: CHAP. V. Some Heads of the 2 of W. and M. for Paving and Clean≈øing the Streets in the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter, Suburbs and Liberties thereof, the Out-Pari≈øhes in the County of Middle≈øex, the Borough of Southwark, and other Places within the Weekly Bills of Mortality, in the County of Surrey.
div.p: EVery Inhabitant inhabiting in the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, and in the Town of Ken≈øington, ≈øhall twice every Week ≈øweep before their Hou≈øes and Buildings, and take up the Dirt ready for the Scavenger, or other Officer, or el≈øe for every Offence or Neglect, forfeit 3 s. 4 d.

If any throw, or permit to be thrown, A≈øhes, Filth, or Annoyance before his Hou≈øe, Building or Wall, ≈øhall forfeit 5 s. If before any Church, Church-yard, or publick Buildings, or into any Sink, or Way, publick or private; but ≈øhall keep it in their Hou≈øes and Yards, until, the Officers come to carry it away, or el≈øe forfeit 20 s.

Churchwardens, Hou≈øe-keepers of White-hall, or other the Kings Hou≈øes, or of Noblemens Hou≈øes, ≈øhall be ≈øubject to like Penalty; ≈øo ≈øhall U≈øhers of Courts, and Porters, and Keepers of other publick Buildings.
Scavengers and Officers ≈øhall come every day (except Sundays and Holidays) and give notice that the Parties concerned may bring out their Du≈øt, &c. or forfeit 40 s. for every neglect.

Every Hou≈øholder ≈øhall pave, and keep repaired the Streets before their Hou≈øes and Ground unto the Channel, or el≈øe forfeit for every Rod 20 s. and 20 s. every Week until at ≈øhall be ≈øufficiently repaired.

Where new Streets and Ways are made, which the Ju≈øtices of Peace in their General Quarter-Se≈ø≈øions ≈øhall think f ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ and convenient to be paved with Stone or Gravel, and ≈øhall order the ≈øame to be done before every dwelling Hou≈øe or Building in ≈øuch Street or Way; Every Per≈øon neglecting, ≈øhall forfeit forty ≈øhillings for every ≈øuch Offence, for every Perch, and after that rate, for a greater of le≈ø≈øer quantity, and the like Sum for every Week till the ≈øame be paved and amended.

Where Streets, Lanes or Allies have been by Cu≈øtom otherwi≈øe repaired, it ≈øhall be done
by ≈øuch Per≈øons as are by Cu≈øtom to do it, under the Penalties afore≈øaid.

Upon Monday or Tue≈øday in Ea≈øter Week, The Con≈øtables, Churchwardens, Over≈øeers and Surveyors giving notice, and calling ≈øuch Inhabitants that have ≈øerved that Office, ≈øhall chu≈øe two Trade≈ømen to be Scavengers; who being allowed under the Hand of any two Ju≈øtices, ≈øhall within ≈øeven days take the Office, or pay 10 l. and within ≈øeven days after ≈øuch refu≈øal, they ≈øhall in like manner chu≈øe another, who ≈øhall accept, or pay 10 l. which Penalties to be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale, and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs or Payment within ≈øix days after notice at his Hou≈øe, to be ≈øent to the Goal until payment. Within twenty days after ≈øuch Election, the Con≈øtables, &c. ≈øhall call ≈øuch Inhabitants as have born the like Office, and make a Tax by a Pound Rate, which being confirmed by two Ju≈øtices, ≈øhall be quarterly paid upon demand made by the Scavengers, or other Officers appointed to gather the ≈øame, and being refu≈øed, ≈øhall by Warrant of two Ju≈øtices be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale, and for want of Di≈øtre≈øs, by Impri≈øonment of the Offender until payment. The Scavengers are to account for the Mony by them Collected, to two Ju≈øtices of the Peace, within twenty eight days after new Scavengers are Elected, and to pay what Mony remains in their Hands to the new Scavengers.

The Scavengers and Rakers for any of the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes ≈øhall have liberty, by the Order of the Ju≈øtices in the Petty-Se≈ø≈øions, or any two of them, to lodge their Soil in ≈øuch vacant places near the Streets or High-ways, a ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall be thought convenient by the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices,
for the accommodation of the Country Cart ‚Ä¢ returning empty from the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, they giving ≈øatisfaction to the Owners of ≈øuch vacant places, and in ca≈øe of unrea≈øonable Demands, the Ju≈øtices in their Petty Se≈ø≈øions may hear and moderate the ≈øame. If any Per≈øons find them≈øelves aggrieved with the Rates made by virtue of this Act, or any ways prejudiced by the determination of the Ju≈øtices in their Petty-Se≈ø≈øions, they may have recour≈øe to the Ju≈øtices at their General Quarter Se≈ø≈øions of the Peace.

And whereas there are many Common High-ways within the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, which cannot be ≈øufficiently repaired by means of the Laws now in force, an A≈ø≈øe≈øsment may be made upon all the Inhabitants, Owners and Occupiers of Lands and Hou≈øes, or per≈øonal E≈øtate u≈øually ratable to the Poor within any of the ≈øaid Pari≈øhes, to be collected by ≈øuch Per≈øons as the Ju≈øtices ≈øhall appoint at their General Quarter-Se≈ø≈øions, the Mony ≈øo collected, to be employed as the Ju≈øtices ≈øhall direct towards repairing the ≈øaid High-ways.
No ≈øuch Rate ≈øhall exceed four pence in the Pound, in any one year, in the yearly value of Lands, Hou≈øes or Tenements, nor of eight pence for every twenty pounds in per≈øonal E≈øtate.

No Per≈øon or Per≈øons what≈øoever, ≈øhall ≈øuffer his Waggon, Cart or Car to ≈øtand in the Haymarket near Pickadilly in the Pari≈øh of St. Martin in the Fields, St. James within the Liberty of We≈øtmin≈øter, Borough of Southwark, or any other place in the Pari≈øhes within the Weekly Bills of Mortality, loaden with Hay or Straw, to ≈øell the ≈øame from Michaelmas to Lady-day, after two of the Clock in the Afternoon, and
from Lady-day to Michaelmas, after one in the Afternoon, on pain to forfeit five ≈øhillings for every Offence and Neglect.

The Owners and Proprietors of any Cart, Car or Dray, the Wheels whereof ≈øhall not be made ≈øix Inches in the breadth, or ≈øhall be ≈øhod with Iron, or be drawn with above two Hor≈øes, ≈øhall forfeit forty ≈øhillings for every time ≈øuch Cart, Car or Dray ≈øhall be u≈øed, for the u≈øes; and to be levied as afore≈øaid: This ≈øhall not extend to any Country Cart or Waggon that ≈øhall bring any Goods to the Cities or Places afore≈øaid, or ≈øhall carry any Goods half a Mile beyond the paved Streets of the ≈øaid Cities and Places.

One Ju≈øtice of Peace upon View or Confe≈ø≈øion, or Oath of one Witne≈øs, may convict any of the Offences afore≈øaid, If Conviction be upon proof, one Moiety to the Over≈øeers of the Poor, for the Relief of the Poor of the Place where the Offence was committed, the other Moiety to him that ≈øhall di≈øcover and pro≈øecute the ≈øame. But if the Conviction ≈øhall be by the View, then one half to the Poor, the other towards repairing and clean≈øing the Streets, to be paid to the Scavengers of the Place, to be levied by the Ju≈øtices Warrant under Hand and Seal, to the Con≈øtable, by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale, or for want of Di≈øtre≈øs or Payment within ≈øix days after notice at the Hou≈øe, to be ≈øent to Goal without Bail, u ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ payment.

No Per≈øon (within the Cities of London and We≈øtmin≈øter, and Liberties of the ≈øame, Borough of Southwark, and Pari≈øhes afore≈øaid) ≈øhall breed, feed or keep any Swine in any Hou≈øes or Back≈øides of the paved Streets where the
Hou≈øes are contiguous, on pain to forfeit the ≈øame to the Churchwardens and Over≈øeers of the Poor of the Pari≈øh where ≈øuch Swine ≈øhall be kept, to the u≈øe of the Poor.

The Churchwardens, Chappel-wardens, Over≈øeers of the Poor, Con≈øtables, Beadles, Headboroughs or Tythingmen of any the Pari≈øhes in the ≈øaid Cities and Places re≈øpectively, in the day-time, with a Warrant under the Hand and Seal of the Lord Mayor, or any other of their Maje≈øties Ju≈øtices of the Peace, may ≈øearch for ≈øuch Swine, and if any be found, they may ≈øeize and carry them away, and ≈øell them for the be≈øt price that can be had, and di≈øtribute the Mony to the Poor of the Pari≈øh where they were ≈øeized.

div.head: CHAP. VI. Several Ca≈øes about the Repairs of Bridges, with the Names of the Statutes which concern particular Bridges.
div.p:
WHere a Common Bridge in the Kings High-way is in decay, and that it cannot be proved or known, who, nor what Lands are chargeable to the repairing thereof; in this ca≈øe four Ju≈øtices of the Peace (whereof one to be of the Quorum) within the Shire or Riding wherein ≈øuch decayed Bridges be; and if they be in a City, or Town Corporate, then fort ≈øuch Ju≈øtices of Peace there, may within the Limits of their ≈øeveral Commi≈ø≈øions, call before them the Con≈øtables, or two of the mo≈øt hone≈øt Inhabitants of every Town and Pari≈øh within
the Shire, Riding, City or Town Corporate, wherein ≈øuch Bridge, or any parcel thereof ≈øhall happen to be; and the Ju≈øtices (upon the appearance of the Con≈øtables, or other Inhabitants, and with their A≈ø≈øents) may Tax every Inhabitant in any ≈øuch City, Town or Pari≈øh within their Limits, to ≈øuch rea≈øonable Sum of Mony as by their Di≈øcretions they ≈øhall think convenient, as well for the repairing of ≈øuch Bridge, and al≈øo for the making and repairing of the High-ways by the ≈øpace of 300 Foot next adjoyning to the Ends of any ≈øuch Bridges, 22 H. 8. c. 5. Dalt. J.P. c. 16. f. 44. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 701, 702.

But Note, Where the Franchi≈øe, City or Borough is a County of it ≈øelf, and hath not four or more Ju≈øtices of the Peace, whereof one or more are of the Quorum, in this ca≈øe no other Ju≈øtices of the Peace, of any Shire or County, have any power to meddle there by this Act, but ≈øuch decay mu≈øt be reformed by the Common Law, by ≈øuch Remedy as they were before the making of the Statute of 22 H. 8. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 702.

And note, That this Taxation ought not to be made by the Ju≈øtices, without the Con≈øent of the Con≈øtables or Inhabitants, nor by them without the Ju≈øtices; and this Tax ought to be upon every Inhabitant in particular, and not to be ≈øet upon the Hundred, Pari≈øh, Town, &c. for then one or two might be di≈øtrained upon for the whole, Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 704.

After ≈øuch Taxation made, as afore≈øaid, the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices of Peace ≈øhall cau≈øe the Names and Sums of every particular Per≈øon ≈øo by them taxed, to be written in a Roll indented in Parchment
for every Hundred, and ≈øealed with their Seals, Co. 2 part, In≈øt. fol. 704. Dalt. J.P. c. 16. ibid.

And the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices may make two Collectors of every Hundred, for the Collecting of all ≈øuch Sums of Mony by the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices ≈øet and taxed, which Collectors receiving the one part of the Roll indented, have power thereby to collect all the Sums of Mony therein contained, and if refu≈øal be made upon demand, then to di≈øtrain, and ≈øell ≈øuch Di≈øtre≈øs, rendring the overplus to the Owner, if any be, Dalt. J.P. c. 16. f. ibid. 22 H. 8. c. 5. Co. 2 part, In≈øt f. 705.

The ≈øaid Ju≈øtices al≈øo are to appoint two Surveyors, who ≈øhall ≈øee ≈øuch decayed Bridges and Ways repaired and amended from time to time as often as need ≈øhall require, to who≈øe Hands the Collectors mu≈øt pay the Monies by them received, Dalt. J.P. c. 16. ibid. 22 H. 8. c. 5.

And the ≈øaid Collectors and Surveyors, and their Executors and Admini≈øtrators, and every of them ≈øhall from time to time make a true Account to the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices of Peace, of the Receipts, Payments and Expences of the ≈øaid Sums of Mony, and if any of them refu≈øe ≈øo to do, then the Ju≈øtices of Peace from time to time, by their Di≈øcretions, may make out Proce≈øs again≈øt the ≈øaid Collectors and Surveyors, their Executors and Admini≈øtrators by Attachment, Precept or Warrant under their Hands and Seals returnable at their General S ‚Ä¢ ≈ø≈øions of the Peace, and the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices may allow ≈øuch rea≈øonable Co≈øts and Charge to the Surveyors and Collectors upon their Accounts, as to them ≈øhall ≈øeem convenient, 22. H. 8. c. 5. Dalt. J. P. c. 16. ibid.

If any ≈øuch Bridge be wholly in a City, or other Corporate Town, the Inhabitants of the ≈øaid City or Corporate Town mu≈øt repair it; and where ≈øuch Bridges lie out of ≈øuch City or Corporate Town, the ≈øame mu≈øt be made by the Inhabitants of the Shire or Riding within which the ≈øame Bridge ≈øhall be, and if part of the Bridge be in one Shire or Riding, City or Corporate Town, and part in another, then every of them ≈øhall be charged to make and repair ≈øuch part as ≈øhall lie, and be within their own Limits, 22 H. 8. c. 5. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. fol. 207. Dalt. J.P. c. 16. fol. 45.
But otherwi≈øe no Village or Freeman ≈øhall be compelled to make any Bridge; but ≈øuch as of old time, and by right they were wont to make, Magna Charta, c. 15.

By the Common Law, ≈øome Per≈øons were ‚Ä¢ ound to repair Bridges, Ratione tenurae ≈øu ‚Ä¢ Ter
‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ram, &c. and this was binding, into who≈øe Hands ≈øoever the E≈øtate did come; but they which have Lands on the one ≈øide, or on the other, or on both, are not bound in Common ‚Ä¢ ight to repair the ≈øame, 44 El. 3. 31. 21 E. 4. ‚Ä¢ 6. 5 H. 7. 3. Crompt. 186. 8 H. 7. 5. b. Co. 2 part,
‚Ä¢ .
‚Ä¢ . f. 700.

If a Man which holdeth 100 Acres of Land, ‚Ä¢ ught to repair a Bridge by tenure of the ≈øame, „Äà‚óä„Äâ allen 20 Acres thereof to one Man, and 10 ‚Ä¢ cres to another Man, in ≈øuch ca≈øe every Owner „Äà‚óä„Äâ Occupier of ≈øuch Lands mu≈øt be charged ‚Ä¢ roportionably for their ≈øaid Lands, Regi≈øt. 268. o. ‚Ä¢ . N. B. 235. b. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 700.

Again, Some by the Common Law were bound ‚Ä¢ y pre≈øcription to repair a Bridge; but herein ‚Ä¢ here is a diver≈øity between Bodies Politick or
Corporate, Spiritual or Temporal, and Natural Per≈øons: For Bodies Politick, &c. may be bound by u≈øage and pre≈øcription only, becau≈øe they are local, and have a perpetual Succe≈ø≈øion, and never die; but a Natural Per≈øon cannot be bound by the Act of his Ance≈øtor, without A≈ø≈øets, or ≈øome Profit to be taken therefore, 21 E. 4. fol. 38. b. 27 A≈ø≈ø. 8. Crompt. 187. Co. 2 part, f. 700. Dalt. J.P. c. 16. f 45.

By Common Right, Bridges are to be amended by the whole County, if it be not known who ought to do the ≈øame otherwi≈øe, Pa≈øch. 19 E. 3. 28, 29. Co. 2 part, Inst. f. 701. Crompt. 186. b. Tr. 10 Car. 1. the Ca≈øe of Longford Bridge, Rolls Ca≈øes 1 part, f. 368. & Cro. Rep. 3 part, the ≈øame Ca≈øe.

If a Man erect a Mill for his own particular Profit, and cut a new Cour≈øe for the Water to come to it, and makes a new Bridge over the ≈øame, and the Kings Subjects u≈øe to ride over the ≈øame as over a common Bridge; ≈øuch Bridge ought to be repaired by him who hath the Mill, and not by the County, becau≈øe he erected it for his own Benefit, 8 E. 2. B. R. adjudged for Bow Bridge and Channel Bridge again≈øt the Prior of Stratford, Rolls Ca≈øes, 1 part, f. 368.

Such as are chargeable to repair a Bridge, may enter upon any other Mans Land or Soil adjoyning, and lay their Stone, Lime, Timber, or other Things nece≈ø≈øary there, for the repairing and amending thereof, and the Owner of the Lands ≈øhall have no Action therefore; for it is for the common Profit; and the Party that is chargeable to repair a Bridge, mu≈øt al≈øo maintain the Way at each end thereof (thoug ‚Ä¢ the Soil be to another) and if the ends be broke ‚Ä¢
by the Water-cour≈øe, he mu≈øt follow the Water-cour≈øe, and repair the Way, &c. Crompt. 186. b. 43 A≈ø≈ø. Dalt. J.P. c. 16. f. 46.

The Names of ≈øome Statutes for particular Bridges follow, 8 H. 6. c. 28. For the making of Burford and Culhamford Bridge. 18 E. 1. c. 7. & 27 E. c. 25. For the maintenance of Roche≈øter Bridge. 18 El. c. 20. For repair of the Bridges within a Mile of Oxford. 23 El. c. 11. For the maintenance of the Bridges over To≈ø≈øe in Wales. 39 El. c. 23. For making and repairing of Newport and Carlion Bridges over the River Usk. 39 El. c. 24. For building and maintenance of a Bridge at Wilton upon Wy, near Ro≈øs, in Hereford≈øhire. 43 El. c. 16. For erecting and repairing Edon and Presberk Bridges in Cumberland. 3 Jac. c. 23. For making and repairing Chep≈øtow Bridge.

By the Stat. 22 Car. 2 c. 12. It is Enacted, That the Surveyors and Orderers of the Work, of amendment of the High-ways, ≈øhall be yearly cho≈øen in Chri≈øtmas Week, according to the Stat. 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 8. Which Per≈øons ≈øo cho≈øen, ≈øhall take upon them that Office, and ≈øhall appoint ≈øix days for providing Stones, Gravel, and other Materials, and for working in the High-ways, having re≈øpect to the Sea≈øon of the Year and Weather, and giving notice publickly ≈øome convenient time before the ≈øeveral days. At which day all Per≈øons liable to the ≈øaid Work, ≈øhall attend and work: And the ≈øaid Surveyors and Orderers ≈øhall make return of the Defaulters, and every of them within one Month, to ≈øome neighbouring Ju≈øtice of the Peace of the ≈øame County.

div.head: DIRECTIONS for the Keepers of Fairs and Markets.
div.p: FAirs are accounted things of Franchi≈øe and Priviledge, as well as of Profit; and whether they be held and claimed by Charter of the King, or by Pre≈øcription, which ≈øuppo≈øes a former Charter, they ought to be holden for no longer time, than ≈øuch Grant or U≈øe will warrant: And after ≈øuch time, what is done there, is not warranted or ju≈øtifiable, nor amounts to more than a private Tran≈øaction; and the Sheriff ought to make Proclamation, That tho≈øe that have Fairs keep them no longer then they ought to do; and every Lord of a Fair, ≈øhall at the beginning thereof, make Proclamation how long the ≈øame is to continue, upon pain to be grievou≈øly amerced to the King; And if they hold them longer than they ought, they ≈øhall be ≈øei≈øed into the Kings Hands, until they make Fine for the Offence; and if a Merchant ≈øell Ware after the time the Fair ought to end, he ≈øhall forfeit to the King double the value of what is ≈øold, and the Pro≈øecutor ≈øhall have the fourth part, Dalt. J. P. c. 62. f. 138.

The Owner, or Chief Keeper of every Fair and Market-over ‚Ä¢ , are to appoint and limit out a certain and open place within the Town, Place, Field or Circuit where Hor≈øes, Mares, Geldings and Colts mu≈øt be ≈øold, and they mu≈øt appoint one ≈øufficient Per≈øon, or more, to take Toll, and keep the ≈øame place from ten
of the Clock before Noon, until Sun-≈øet of every day of the fore≈øaid Fair or Market, upon pain to lo≈øe for every Default 40 ≈øhillings, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 7. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 715.

The Toll-gatherer, his Deputy or Deputies are to take their due and lawful Tolls for every Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. at the place and times afore≈øaid; and they are to have before them at the taking of the ≈øaid Toll, the Parties, to the Bargain, Exchange, Gift, Contract, or putting away of every ≈øuch Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. and al≈øo the ≈øame Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. ≈øo ≈øold, exchanged, or put away, and then the Toll gatherer mu≈øt write in his Book the Names, Sirnames, and dwelling Places of all the ≈øaid Parties, and the Colour, with one ≈øpecial Mark at the lea≈øt of the ≈øaid Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. on pain to forfeit for every Default 40 ≈øhillings, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 7. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 7 5.

And the ≈øaid Toll gatherer is within one day after the Fair, &c. to bring his Book to the Owner, Governour or Ruler, &c. of the Fair or Market, who is then to cau≈øe a Note to be made out of the ≈øame; of the true number of all the Hor≈øes, Mares, &c. ≈øold at the ≈øaid Fair or Market, to which Note he mu≈øt ≈øet his Hand or Mark, on pain of 40 ≈øhillings: And if the Toll-gatherer neglect to bring the Book, as afore≈øaid, he al≈øo forfeits 40 ≈øhillings, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 7. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 715.
Where no Toll is due, the Book-keepers Fee for entring every Contract, is one penny and no more, 2 & 3 P. & M. c. 7. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 716.

Now ≈øince the making of this Stat 2 & 3 P. & M. It is further provided by the 31 Eliz. That
every Seller or Exchanger of any Hor≈øe, Mare, &c In a Fair or Market, which is unknown to the Toll-taker or Book-keeper mu≈øt procure one credible Per≈øon that is well known to the Toll-keeper, or Book-keeper, who is to vouch and te≈øtifie his Knowledge of the Seller, and the Toll-taker, or Book keeper, is to enter both the Names and Sirnames, My≈øteries, and Places of Dwelling of the Seller and Voucher into his Book, with the Colour, Mark and Price of the Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. ≈øo ≈øold or exchanged; and he is to give the Buyer, if he require it, a Note in writing out of his Book, concerning the Contract ≈øub≈øcribed with his Hand, for which he is to have two pence, 31 El. c. 12. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 717, 718.

Every Toll-taker or Book-keeper that ≈øuffers a Sale to pa≈øs without a Voucher, unle≈øs he know the Party of his own Knowledge, as afore≈øaid, and every Per≈øon making fal≈øe Te≈øtimony or Avouchment in the behalf afore≈øaid, and every Seller unknown to the Toll-taker, not bringing a Voucher, and cau≈øing the ≈øame to be entred as afore≈øaid, forfeits five pounds, one Moiety thereof to the King, and the other to the Pro≈øecutor; and al≈øo the ≈øale of ≈øuch Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. to be void, 31 El. c. 12. Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 718.

And note, That though an Hor≈øe, Mare, &c. be at the ≈øale u≈øed in all the Points afore≈øaid, with Voucher, &c. yet the right Owner, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, may redeem a ≈øtoln Hor≈øe, if they claim him within ≈øix months after the ≈øtealing, at the Pari≈øh or Corporation, where they ≈øhall find him and make proof within 40 days after, by two ≈øufficient Witne≈ø≈øes, before
the next Ju≈øtice of Peace of the County, or before the Head Officer in a Corporation, that the Hor≈øe was theirs, and repay to the Buyer ≈øuch price for the Hor≈øe, as the ≈øame Buyer ≈øhall upon his own Oath before ≈øuch Ju≈øtice or Officer, te≈øtifie he paid for him, 31 El. c. 12. Wingates Stat. Tit. Fairs and Markets, Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 718.

If a ≈øtoln Hor≈øe be not ≈øold in Fair or Market, according to the Rules afore≈øaid, then ≈øuch Sale does not alter the Property of the right Owner, but he may ≈øeize or replevy him where≈øoever he finds him, 31 El. c. Wingate ubi ≈øupra, Co. 2 part, In≈øt. f. 718.

No Per≈øon ≈øhall buy any Oxen, Ronts, Steers, Kine, Heifers, Calves, Sheep, Lambs, Goats or Kids alive, and ≈øell the ≈øame again, unle≈øs he keep the ≈øame five Weeks in his own Grounds; or where he hath Herbage by Grant or Pre≈øcription, upon pain to lo≈øe double the value of the Cattle; one Moiety to the King, the other to the Informer, 5 Ed. 6. c. 14.
By the Stat. 22 Car. 2. c. 8. There ≈øhall be no Bu≈øhel but the Winche≈øter Bu≈øhel, containing eight Gallons, and none ≈øhall ≈øell by other Mea≈øure, on pain of 40 ≈øhillings.

If the Clerk of the Market of the Kings Hou≈øe, or others authorized to mark or ≈øeal Mea≈øures, being required, ≈øhall neglect or refu≈øe to ≈øeal or mark any Bu≈øhel, Half Bu≈øhel, or Peck duly gauged, he forfeits 5 l. for the fir≈øt Offence, and for every other Offence 10 l. or if the Kings Clerk of the Market of his Hou≈øe take more than his Fees, or if any other take above one peny for ≈øealing a Bu≈øhel, one half peny for the Half Bu≈øhel or Peck, or more than one farthing for
any le≈ø≈øer Mea≈øure, he incurs the Penalties in the Stat. 17 Car. 1.

That at the charge of ≈øuch Per≈øons who have the Toll, or profit of the Market where no Toll is taken, there ≈øhall be before 29 Sept. 1670. one Mea≈øure of Bra≈øs provided and chained in the Market-place, upon pain to forfeit 5 l. 22 Car. 2. c. 8.

By the Stat. of 22 & 23 Car 2. It is further provided, That who≈øoever ≈øhall ≈øell or buy any Corn or Salt by the Bag, or without mea≈øuring, being thereunto required, or in any other manner than as by the Stat. 22 Car. 2. c. 8. is directed, and without ≈øhaking the Mea≈øure by the Buyer, ≈øhall forfeit be≈øides the Penalty in the former Act, all the Corn or Salt, or the value therefore to the Per≈øon or Per≈øons complain ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ g, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 12.

Upon complaint to one or more Ju≈øtices of Peace, the Proof ≈øhall lie upon the Defendant, to make appear by Oath of one or more Witne≈ø≈øes, that he or they did ≈øell or buy according to this and the ≈øaid former Act; wherein if he fail, he ≈øhall forfeit as by this Act is directed, to be levied by di≈øtre≈øs and ≈øale of Goods, by Warrant under the Hand and Seal of one or more Ju≈øtices before whom ≈øuch Conviction ≈øhall be. The Penalties to be di≈øtributed, one half to the Poor of the Pari≈øh where the Offence ≈øhall be committed, the other to the Informer, 22 & 23 Car. 2. c. 12.

div.head: DIRECTIONS to Trea≈øurers, for the Relief of Poor Maimed Soldiers and Mariners.
div.p:
THE Ju≈øtices of Peace are yearly at the Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, about Ea≈øter, to choo≈øe or appoint one or two Per≈øons (according to their Di≈øcretions) of the County, for the taking and di≈øtributing of the Monies collected for the Re
‚Ä¢ ief of poor maimed Soldiers and Mariners: And the≈øe Trea≈øurers, by the Words of the future, ought to be Sub≈øidy Men of 10 pounds ‚Ä¢ n Lands, or 15 pounds in Goods, and the≈øe Officers are to continue in their Office one Year, and new ones then to be cho≈øen in their Rooms, 43 El c. 3. Wingates Stat. Tit. Captains.

Now for the rai≈øing of Mony for the≈øe Trea≈øurers, the greater part of the Ju≈øtices in their Quarter Se≈ø≈øions, have power to charge every Pari≈øh within their Limits, towards a Weekly ‚Ä¢ elief of maimed Soldiers and Mariners, ≈øo ‚Ä¢ hat no Pari≈øh pay Weekly above 10 pence, nor ‚Ä¢ nder 2 pence; nor any County, which con≈øi≈øts ‚Ä¢ f above 50 Pari≈øhes, pay above 6 pence, one ‚Ä¢ ari≈øh with another, 43 El. c. 3.

When the Tax is levied, the Con≈øtables and Churchwardens are to deliver it quarterly (ten days before every Quarter Se≈ø≈øions) to the High Con≈øtables of their Divi≈øion, who mu≈øt deliver to ‚Ä¢ he Trea≈øurers of the County, at the ≈øame Quarter Se≈ø≈øions all the ≈øame Mony; and if the Con≈øtables or Churchwardens, their Executors, &c. fail in the payment, to the High Con≈øtable,
within the time afore≈øaid, then they are to forfeit 20 s. and if the High Con≈øtable fall to pay the Trea≈øurers every Se≈ø≈øions, then he forfeits 40 s. which Forfeitures, as it ≈øeems, the Trea≈øurers may levy by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of the Offenders Goods, without any Warrant, rendring the overplus to the Owner: And the≈øe Forfeitures are to go in Augmentation of the Trea≈øurers Stock, 43 El. c. 3.

The maimed Soldier or Mariner which was Pre≈øt, ≈øhall repair (if he be able to Travel) to the Trea≈øurers of the County where he was Pre≈øt; if he were not Pre≈øt, then to the Trea≈øurers of the County where he was Born, or were he la≈øt dwelt by the ≈øpace of three years, at his Election; but if he be not able to Travel, then to the Trea≈øurers of the County where he Lands; and he is to bring with him a Certificate under the Hand and Seal of the Chief Commander, or of the Captain under whom he ≈øerved, containing the particular of his Hurts and Service, which Certificate ≈øhall al≈øo be allowed by the Mu≈øter-Ma≈øter, or the Receiver-General of the Rolls for the Mu≈øter, under one of their Hands, 33 El. c. 3.

Then upon ≈øuch a Certificate, the Trea≈øurer ‚Ä¢ afore≈øaid may allow the Party Relief to maintain him till the next Quarter Se≈ø≈øions; an ‚Ä¢ then the major-part of the Ju≈øtices may allo ‚Ä¢ him a Pen≈øion, which the Trea≈øurers mu ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ pay him quarterly, until it ≈øhall be revoked „Äà‚óä„Äâ altered by the ≈øaid Ju≈øtices; and this Allowanc ‚Ä¢ is not to exceed 10 l. per annum to a Commo ‚Ä¢ Soldier, not 15 l. to an Officer under a Lieutenant, nor 20 l. to a Lieutenant, 43 El. c. 3 Wingates Stat. Tit. Captains and Soldiers.

Where Soldiers and Mariners arrive far from the place where they are to receive Relief, the Trea≈øurers there ≈øhall give them Relief, and a Te≈øtimonial whereby they may pa≈øs from Trea≈øurer to Trea≈øurer, until they ≈øhall come to the place required; and this ≈øhall be done upon the bare Certificate of the Commander and Captain, although they have not as yet obtain'd any Allowance from the Mu≈øter-Ma≈øter, or Receiver-General of the Mu≈øter-Rolls, Wingates Stat. Tit. Captains and Soldiers, 43 El. c. 3.
If any Soldier or Mariner beg, or counterfeit a Certificate, he ≈øhall be puni≈øhed as a Common Rogue, and ≈øhall lo≈øe his Pen≈øion, if he have any 43 El. c. 3. Wingate, ut ≈øupra.

When out of the County where the Party was Pre≈øt, a fit Pen≈øion cannot be ≈øatisfied, it ≈øhall then be ≈øupplied by the County where he was born, or el≈øe where he la≈øt dwelt by the ≈øpace of three years, Wingate, ubi ≈øupra, 43 El. c. 3.

The Trea≈øurers are to Regi≈øter all their Receipts and Disbur≈øements, and mu≈øt enter the Names of the Parties relieved into their Book, and al≈øo the Certificate, by virtue whereof the Disbur≈øements are made; and where they di≈øallow of a Certificate, they are to ≈øet down the Rea≈øons of their Refu≈øal under the Certificate, or on the back thereof, 43 El. c. 3. Wingate Stat. Tit. Captains and Soldiers.

If any Trea≈øurer wilfully refu≈øe to give Relief in the Ca≈øes afore≈øaid, the Ju≈øtices of the Peace, in their Se≈ø≈øions, may ≈øet a Fine upon him, which may be levied by Di≈øtre≈øs and Sale of his Goods, Wingate, ubi ≈øupra.

The≈øe Officers at the end of their Year, within 10 days after Ea≈øter Se≈ø≈øions, are to give „Äà‚óä„Äâ a ju≈øt Account to the ≈øucceeding Trea≈øurers o ‚Ä¢ all their Receipts and Disbur≈øements within the time of their Office; and then if they have any Mony in their Hands, they are to deliver it to their Succe≈ø≈øors; and if any ≈øuch Officer his Executors or Admini≈øtrators ≈øhall not give up ≈øuch Account within the time afore≈øaid, o ‚Ä¢ ≈øhall be otherwi≈øe negligent in the Executio ‚Ä¢ of his Office; The Ju≈øtices at the Se≈ø≈øions may a≈ø≈øe≈øs what Fine they plea≈øe upon him; ≈øo tha ‚Ä¢ it be not under five pounds, but what the ‚Ä¢ plea≈øe above five pounds upon him, his Executors or Admini≈øtrators, Wingate, ubi ≈øupra 43 El. c. 3.

In Corporations, the Ju≈øtices there are t ‚Ä¢ put this Act in Execution, and not the Ju≈øtices of the County: This Act is not to prohibit the City of London to make a Tax if nee ‚Ä¢ require, differing from that above limited i ‚Ä¢ this Act, ≈øo that no Pari≈øh pay above thr ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øhillings Weekly, nor under twelve pen ‚Ä¢ Weekly, one Pari≈øh with another, 43 El. c. 3.
